column10:
Lots of good puzzles to solve with your friends or significant others with more content compared to previous WWHs. The puzzles were challenging at times but they were all fun and without nonsenses.

Would easily be the best WWH if only [spoiler] the ending was not sooo DISAPPOINTING... Without the possibility to find a secret good ending whatsoever. The game is fantastic, but in the end it made us sad. [/spoiler] I hope the devs will amend this in potential future WWHs.
The fact that you cant pick the mic to use and cant talk to your friend in game is so fuckin annoying

Really fun puzzle game. All of the levels are very solvable, just with enough brainpower. Great to play if you're bored of the same game all the time. Takes about 15-25 hours total to complete. Well worth it.

This game has a ton of charm and some banger puzzles. Some of the puzzles are stupid and seem like "try these permutations until it works" but some of them are really well put together. It's not a very polished game but that's what you expect from a small studio. Also I have no idea what the story was about and I think the end was supposed to be emotional but I had no grasp of anything. Don't use walkietalkies though. Just call over discord because the walkietalkies are stupid where only one person can talk at once, which just isn't fun at all. I'm saying a lot of negative things but that's because I want these things to be changed because I really want more of this. The only other game that has been like this experience was It Takes Two, and although this game isn't as good as ITT, it outshines it in a lot of ways, with some of the puzzles being very creative

A great end to the original WWH series, and the longest one yet! 

The puzzles are well designed and have great presentation as well. The length of the game is more than double of the the previous installment, so make room for multiple days of playing. The price is more than worth it if you have a great puzzler partner.

I'm really sorry but I can't recommend. I love the series, I enjoyed all the previous games but this one just does not work. Upon launching the game it crashes to desktop. No error message, nothing in game logs. Literally unplayable for me. I tried everything I found on the internet as well as all the steps that developers provides here on the forum including using their tool to clean up steam cloud but nothing helps. It's in this state for 2 months now. Maybe one day they will fix the game and I'll be able to play it. I'm happy to update my review once this happens.
Was here for: 13.2hrs
Was an amazing time.  Played through the entire series with a friend and we came out the other end still friends!

We Were Here Forever has emotionally ruined me.

SPOILER WARNING!!!

In a good way, of course. I played this game a while back with a friend of mine, unaware of the little scare factors that were in the game, but was intrigued by the puzzle co-op aspect of the game itself. After playing it, I knew that I had to play the sequel, We Were Here Too, as well.
Though a little embarrassing, I don't do well with horror or jumpscares. As such, I may have let out one, two, maybe ten, screams throughout gameplay. But nonetheless, I grew to love these games, because of how fun it was. With the addition of We Were Here Together, with an added amount of lore and worldbuilding, I was hooked. Since then, I've replayed the first three games many times with other friends, and even got the secret ending of We Were Here Too. But, at the end of those, it pained me that one always stayed behind.

When I witnessed the trailer for We Were Here Forever, featuring the two previous explorers from We Were Here and We Were Here Too, I was shocked, and hopeful. Perhaps, we would get a good ending for the explorers left behind, and I could not wait to enter Castle Rock once again in order to help these explorers.
The game itself, is fantastic. Some puzzles were extremely difficult, and required a pencil and paper for me, but were so much fun. My friend and I tackled it with sessions, surprised at how long the game turned out to be (we finished at about 8-9 hours). It was a fantastic experience that I would absolutely play or watch through again.
It also gave us more story and lore to the people of Rockbury, and Castle Rock; something I expected, but still nonetheless loved in its entirety. It's a grim tale that our explorers have unfortunately been a part of... but a thrilling one, still.

But this game has ruined me entirely. [SPOILERS!!!]
[spoiler]My hopes of both my friend and I escaping Castle Rock... turned out to be for naught. We took turns on the floating piece of wood in the freezing ocean... until I couldn't swim up anymore, and was lost to the depths. The fact that the Jester had escaped scott free, while my friend and I struggled so desperately to help each other onto the piece of wood... it was heartwrenching. I remember clearly, saying to myself as I drowned, "no, no, that can't be it. We must have missed something, that can't be it". After a quick google search, well... that was it. And it broke me.
These explorers who had been through so much, and one still died in the end. The explorer, drifting alone in the ocean. It pains me in a way I can't describe; in a way that I can only hope that one day, maybe a happy ending can happen for our beloved explorers. For our lost friends, may they rest well.
In the next installment: should there [i]be[/i] a next installment, I hope to the ends of the earth, that the Jester receives his rightful due... given a place right in hell, where he belongs.[/spoiler]

But as a game series, and as a longstanding fan... thank you so much for giving us a wonderful game. The We Were Here series is a series that I doubt another co-op puzzle game will ever live up to, not with its storytelling, nor the uniqueness of the game itself.

I hope that, though our journey in Castle Rock may be over...  we will be able to return to the We Were Here series, someday in the future.

For me? I can't wait.

My friend and I had been playing the "We Were Here" franchise together for the last few weeks, starting with the first game and continuing onto this one (the most recent installment). 

Funny enough, every "We Were Here" game seems to be better than the last, and the developers improve more and more with each installment, but for this game specifically, I was concerned that it might not live up to the hype that I had built in my head.

I was absolutely baffled to find that not only did it exceed my expectations, but it came with an amazing story to boot! The puzzles were the most fun and flashy they've ever been, the story was so interesting, and the adventure and interactive atmosphere was absolutely perfect. "We Were Here Forever" was such a nice follow-up to their other already amazing installments.

If you have a friend, bug them, grab this game, and play it.

We Were Here Forever blows every other game out of the water. The Story is a direct continuation of we were here together. Every puzzle is satisfying to complete and involves a lot of simultaneous puzzle-solving compared to just call and response puzzle solving. (Even though a good portion are call and response, it still requires at least some work on the other person's end to complete). The story is great in this game and really tells a story through puzzles as well as just having great puzzles. This game is home to my absolute favorite puzzles in the series. They have a hint system which is 90% of the time useless. They give you 3 hints per level (per person). and you can only open them 30 seconds after one another so you really think about it. But the hints are usually just "1. communicate with your partner" "2. look around for hints!" and then the third hint usually had substance. I only used hints on a few levels. It doesnt rely on hard-to-describe symbols as its only sense of difficulty and it is just a blast to play. If you want to get the complete we were here experience definitely play Forever as it avoids most of the pitfalls of the other games.

You should play we were here Together before to get the story, but before that you can play The first game and Friendship if you just wanna feel out the games without a huge time/money commitment
Not to mention that we were here forever has about 5 hours worth of playtime more than together

The best game in the series and my absolute favorite game in puzzle co-op games!
The best part is actually seeing how much the game has developed in the few years. Not only have the puzzles improved, the story has also been extensively added. The graphics round off the game. The fact that crossplay was introduced with this game is also an absolute plus.

There are a few bugs in the game, for example you could only hear your partner via the walkie talkie in a puzzle in one ear, or the individual parts of the astrolabe that you get after solving a puzzle caused a few problems.

But otherwise you can't complain too much. In addition, the last big update shows that the developers are trying their best to remove the bugs. Overall a great game, I'm an absolute fan of the series and I'm looking forward to all the other games that will hopefully come because I'll play them all. Lots of love to the developers.

Endured this game. Several puzzles don't even have clues in the game so you have to just guess your way to a solution or look up a guide. Wasn't really fun as a result - the first game was the most coherent in the series, but they became more guess-die-retry as the series progressed & you just have to brute-force your way to solutions. Like "reply to the octopus and always tell the truth" but there's no way to understand what the octopus says so you just have to pick random words to transmit and hope it doesn't kill you

Loved the game just as much as the previous installations. Music is excellent. Great array of new puzzles. We already have The Friendship on our list to play ASAP. Highly recommend if you liked the previous games.

The story was fleshed-out a little more in this game, but still left a lot up for interpretation. A few lingering questions I had about the Jester were explored just enough that I was satisfied.

I did not like the spiders at all. I was lucky that my partner [spoiler]fell down the well in the cemetery[/spoiler] during our first play-through. I was prepared and they kept socially-distant enough to be bearable when we replayed only the dual-achievement part of that chapter.

The only element that's missing from Forever is a third "secret" ending where both explorers escape clean. I'm not a huge fan of the "one or the other" forced choice, but it did create narratively satisfying endings in the previous games. It was lovely to have that third option in Too to end the playthrough with a little more agency. [spoiler]I actually liked that the one chose to go back to find the rest of their friends. The explorer turned back just as I said, "Wait, what about the others?" haha[/spoiler] After finishing Forever, I'm more disappointed and irritated than anything else. The cut-scene during the credits seems to be setting up the next sequel, but that's really unnecessary. We happily followed all of the contrived mechanisms that separated the partners through 4 games + Friendship. It's weird to start trying to explain it now.

tldr; I liked the game enough to complain about the ending, but only after making plans to play the next game as soon as possible. And sat listening to the lobby music while writing this review.

I really didn't want to leave a negative review, but the latest update forces me to do so... This update has broken the game for my friend, and he can't launch it anymore, no matter what he does. This review doesn't reflect on the content of the game itself—it's fantastic, just like the entire series. However, the treatment of players with weaker devices is disheartening. It seems that this issue isn't isolated and primarily related to the user's weaker device. Meanwhile, the previous installments in the series were fine (they didn't break, at least). All that's left is to wish success in future endeavors and the series' development, and hope that there will be fewer "broken" updates in the future.

Right off the bat, I have to say first that I EXTREMELY enjoyed the whole series~. Thus: I suggest you play the other 3 games before this one!
They try to hint and/or even bring back some puzzles from the other 3 games, but with changes of course so it isn't exactly the same at all. But for me, this was a really nice little 'easter eggs' and just nice reference and connection to their other games.

BUT! Not just for that: There is a story~! The first game didn't have it much at first to me but one hint, but by game two, and really 3, you start to learn of a developing story that I thought fit very will for the game's atmosphere. And this game, 'Forever', brings the story to a conclusions- or does it~?- and more explainational depth.


Overall: The story I thought was really well done, and yet will still leave you questioning a few things but I think is intentional. Either for a future game, or just to make you wonder forever (just as the title hah). The actual 'gameplay' mechanics I think honestly degraded, *just slightly* though. I felt they could of just stuck with game 3's keybindings and all, but nothing was annoying or confusing to say the least. We still played with no problems. Graphics: Just better of course following the other games showing their progress. And the Puzzles. . ho boy.

Puzzles: I will say, started off great and wracks your brain to think with your partner- although me and my partner were rather too smart and flew through pretty fast but still enough to satisfy thinking hard enough :3. But.. the later half or near endgame, I will say became VERY confusing. Two puzzles had me and partner confused and lost on where to even start. We're pretty sure one puzzle we just 'accidentally' completed, as we never really figured out what the puzzle was. But overall 80% of the puzzles were clear on what you needed to figure out after some thinking, and was really fun and unique each time :3.

Pros:
+ Graphics nice
+ Puzzles you really will need to think and have patience on.
+ Awesome, unique story!
+ Lengthy enough to feel engaging and not too short at all.

Con:
- Two puzzles really give you no idea where or how to start and what to do.
- Half the puzzles are pretty one sided on working together to help, but + they do balance back and forth on this position for each player.
- Sadly may not be replayable even with new partner as you'll already understand the puzzles after.


* This series was fun :3 and would love to play it again, but the puzzles are not randomized T^T. Even if I returned years later, I'm sure i'll at least remember what to do, even if not how to solve it instantly. But I still LOVED the experience and had a great partner to join me on the adventure beginning to end :3.
Cool part, but its worth mentioning that we've had a soft blocker on the octopus puzzle in our playthrough. Nonetheless, it was worth it.

I loved this game and all entries to the series. Played them in order of release and It is delightful to see how every sequel is a more fleshed out version of the same concept expanding on the core mechanics with more and more detailed environments and lore.

You and your freind will each assume one of two roles. The more recent entries allow u to "switch" after each puzzle, the original sees each player in the same role for the hole game. In the original, there is usually one person that needs to take action and another that provides Information. In later entries, the roles are more fluid.

Grab a friend and try the first game "We were here" (its free) or the very affordable "Expedition: The Friendship". If you had fun playing those, I recommend the whole series.

The overarching plot is a little vague but gets the job done setting the mood. 

The only frustrating memory with this game was a game breaking glitch with a puzzle involving gates. At one point one of us had glitched through one of the gates leaving us softlocked for the better part of 2 hours until we decided to reset and solve it within a minute.

Very fun game! If you like mental torture.

I absolutely love the we were here series. Each game has definitely gotten better compared to the last; more in-depth puzzles, higher difficulty, lengthy enough, and the story was really compelling. The raise in difficult was counteracted with a hint menu, after looking through all the hints to see how much they would help, some of them were kind of self-explanatory and didn't help much (the mannequin head puzzle is one example).

The only downside I would say to the game is the sidelined ending that felt a bit weird comparing to how the other games had their endings. [spoiler] It felt as if it was trying to copy titanic and just felt weird considering we were just stuck in a medieval fortress which all of a sudden turned in to a freezing sea with a single raft in sight. I also feel like having a save both option for the finale of the trilogy would have been a nice addition, it wouldn't have to be a 1/3 type ending but could be a secret ending like the 2nd game, involving a "meta-like" puzzle to solve. [/spoiler]

all-in-all this game, hell even trilogy, was amazing, even if this may be the end of "We Were Here", I hope you continue making even better games that I can thoroughly enjoy with my friend :)

Finished 100%, both sides done, no bugs involved, We Were Here Forever splits the two players up a lot less than the other games- which I do not prefer. It also adds onto the idea on why there is no proximity chat to begin with for these specific puzzles besides the VERY ending! The whole concept of We Were Here started with two players separating into two distinct, and decently randomized paths- which could have been expanded upon throughout the series but wasn't. 

And for the first time in this game, hints were introduced! Which instead of involving a decent and perhaps a descriptive hint as its pretty easy to get lost and confused in this game, it instead takes timed intervals [up to ten minutes] to remind the player to... read and talk to their partner. GEE! I would've have thought about that myself without the hint button!

There also appears to be a lot of fluff in areas where it likely should not have it, and several of the puzzles are possibly cut up into sections where it is almost impossible to be explained to the player unless there is SERIOUS trial and error. IE completing the timed trials several times or even switching sides in general. 

While there are a lot of fun puzzles in this game entry that I had tons of fun with, few were painful and unbearable that when completing another run, we were grateful we didn't have to go through them again. While We Were NOT Here Forever, We Were Here for a good amount of time. 

Get on sale, and remember Uuuwwuuu. [Also add back the catboy symbol from the first game!]
yes
Amazing experience

This is a fantastic game that tragically runs like garbage. While a little clunky my computer can usually handle most intense games with not much issue, but no matter how low I make the settings this game is just a mess. Thankfully it never really interfered with any of the puzzles, but if you have a lower end computer I would be wary. 

Optimization aside, We Were Here Forever is another amazing entry to this series. The location and grandeur of the story have increased tenfold, giving the Explorers more varied and interesting places to explore. Similar to the third game there are many occasions where you and your partner can see and interact with each other, but it never really detracts from the atmosphere and puzzles. The hint system is a nice touch, though we did not use it almost at all so I can't say how helpful it was. While this game has some really fantastic puzzles and creative interactions, it also has some of my least favorite ones in the entire series. Several of them felt more lopsided than I would have liked, with one person standing around doing nothing but talking and the other person "does all the work". Despite that this is still one of my favorites of the series and it finally gives us some closure for this story. [spoiler] Even if that ending is extremely unsatisfying. I can't believe they pulled a Titanic on us sheesh [/spoiler]

A step down from We Were Here Together. The game starts to explain everything, so the story is no longer interesting or creepy (or believable, it's not a very well put together plot, clearly not the game's focus). The first 2 games were janky and not too well balanced, which is understandable given the developers'  inexperience. Together was great. A lot less scary than the first game, as they tried to introduce a more clear plot than necessary, making the game a bit less believable. The puzzles, on the other hand, were really fun and very well polished. We Were Here Forever is just annoying. The puzzles are much more linear and easy. Once you figure them out they make you grind out another 3 identical puzzles to increase playtime, it's just not fun, and the narrator overexplains everything. I appreciate the effort that went into getting proper voice acting and prettier assets, but I'd really just have preferred the smart puzzles from the previous game that don't overstay their welcome. I am writing this review during a puzzle that's way too long and boring and extremely dumbed down. I feel really bad about leaving this review, but they really did a good job on Together, progress that they threw away in Forever. We hope the next installment goes back to elegant puzzles that you avtually have to think about!

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] Worth its price, even without discounts
[*] Offers fresh takes on classic puzzle concepts, such as circuit/pipe completion
[*] Aesthetically pleasing visuals
[*] Engaging story complemented by solid voice acting
[*] Runs smoothly on Linux/Proton without any issues
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*] Time-limited levels (specifically arena and alchemy) were not enjoyable. However, this does not apply to "quick-to-fail" puzzles that resolve in seconds, but rather to longer levels that can take many minutes to fail.
[*] Traveling (whether on foot or in some vehicle) fairly often felt quite tedious and drawn out
[*] Occasional minor animation delays with the other player, possibly due to latency
[*] Animations of the other player could be enhanced, as they often feel robotic
[/list]

Great game with nice puzzles, but deserves more alternative endings. It'd be cool to even see an ending in which both explorers survive like the previous games. I also think that the ending puzzle was too short and straightforward. It was just one simple task (not puzzle) quickly led to another simple task. It didn't feel satisfying after doing all the hard work before. Maybe it was intentional, as it could be to "cool down" from all the harder puzzles, but that's just how I personally felt. Personally, would've loved more of a puzzle to end the game.

As my introduction to the franchise, I find We Were Here Forever to be a great game that offered memorable moments. The settings are varied and beautiful, each filled with their own unique details. The puzzles being directly linked to the main story is always great. It offers great immersive scenes and funny situations that made me really enjoy my time.

The game utilizes communication to its full potential. That gimmick allows it to create a very assymetrical experience between the two players, which is very impressive. I find that the puzzles vary in difficulty greatly, and not particularly is an ascending way. Though it depends on one's personnal taste, I personally enjoyed the earlier puzzles better as I found them more mechanically interesting. All the puzzles are varied, with a great repartition between searching, mechanic manipulation and reflexion. No puzzles soured my experience of the game, and a few will stick with me for a while.

There are dead moments in the game that I find pacing-breaking. I don't really understand why they exist, besides prompting/forcing us to enjoy the scenery or set a particular setting? They didn't work for me, especially since the game does already a great job at that. But they're still just a tiny spot in an otherwise clean canvas.

Overall a very cool experience ! This game is unique for sure.

We Were Here Forever is an absolutely *gorgeous* entry to the We Were Here puzzling series. Along with continuing the story in a satisfying way, it also has visuals that will rope you in, and fully leans into the potential of the magic-infused world it sets up to deliver some of the most memorable puzzles you can find!

Exploring underwater lairs, powering up old generators, exploring the trickery of the warped worlds the Jester puts you through, has all been an incredible experience.

The only things I can say I didn't like is playing the Underwater-Area before the Graveyard and Mineshaft/Light-Puzzle ones, because it was by FAR the best and made the other two areas pale a little!

What's to be said about this series and this game especially?  I've spent the last three harrowing years working my way through this series with a friend who told me about them.  So much arguing and sharing one brain cell as we trudged our way through this masterpiece and tested the limits of patience and understanding to come out on top and stronger as people, if not a little weirder from the experience.  The opened Castlerock was beautiful to immerse in and the puzzles, while seemingly tough as heck a few times, were not unbeatable with some good communication.    10 out of 10, epic and concise ending to an amazing story.  Perfect if you're an emotional masochist.

This game was a blast to play.  Puzzles were challenging, but also solve-able.  So they were not extremely frustrating.  I also enjoyed the variety in the puzzles.  The game was not repetitive in the puzzles at all.  We did get stuck on one portion, when we thought we had finished the puzzle, and it wasn't fully clear that there remained a single step to complete.

The communication mechanism through the walkie talkie interface was a nice novelty, but I will admit, since a friend and I played together, we found it easier to just connect via discord to chat, without having to press/release the comms button.
This game became my favorite game of all times.
This game simultaneously makes my brain hurt and feel like a complete genius. 10/10 with a friend.

In my opinion, this game stands out as the best in the series. Those criticizing the repetition of puzzles seem clueless in their complaints. I've never had the feeling of solving a duplicate of a previously solved puzzle. Some complained that there's the lack of aimless wandering to figure out the next step is a positive change. I can't stress enough how this alteration has made the game more enjoyable. Focusing on what needs to be done rather than endlessly pondering not how to solve puzzles, but going crazy trying to comprehend the developer's intention, has revitalized our enjoyment of the game. It's a fun, it's very enjoyable, it's got a compelling story, great visuals and music and absents perplexing puzzles that previously hindered progress. Some narcissists had a strong urge to review not the game, but express their delusion of how smart they are. We enjoyed it a lot and can't wait to play another installment of this unique series.

Much like the third game, but better in every way. Just a quick list of what the improvements are, which is not an exhaustive list.

-More lore

-Better and grander graphics

-Longer playtime

-Bigger, more unique and harder puzzles

-Better animations

-Improved art style

-Better voice acting 

-More and varied environments

And so on so forth, you get the idea.

 If you still not sure if you want to get it, check out the 1st game in the series (which is free!) then think of it but improved by 10 times in every aspect, and you've got this game.

As a side note, out of all the Co-Op games out there (and no, duos in Fortnite or other FPS's don't count) in this small genre, this has to be one of the best ones yet, only beaten by A Way Out and It Takes Two, which you definitely should get as well. 

One last thing, but like I've said in previous reviews, grab a good mate to play it with, as it will be 10 times more fun then with a random person.

[h1] The grand finale, yet the start for something great [/h1]

We Were here Forever is the final game in the storyline of castle rock, also not the last one. Its the longest of all games and the one I might recognize as the first game that could compete with games made by bigger studios. Hazelight for example. 

The game offers a bunch of fun and challenging puzzles and every step you make in this game feals earned. This time we get to experience different sets from castle to underwater a lot of stuff to freshen up the gameplay is included. It even has boss fights. Really for the first time you have boss fights and they are great. 

With We Were Here Forever we finally got see the outcome of a great narration giving us a satisfying end to a great series. The built up, the expection I had where filled to the brim and the game as all games plays with your emotions. 

Puzzlewise games like the big dimensional puzzle or the side scrolling one where a great expierence to make. It might be that the second game is my favorite but this is surely a good competitor for that spot. The only let down I experience is the overwhelming input some rooms and puzzles have. Were the first two games where easilier to grasp the third and this sometimes needed time understand and getting used to some rooms and puzzles. 

I did wrote some line about the lessons this game series tells. A lesson about bonding further with a friend or partner. The grand finale combines the best of all lessons. While the first focused on communication, the second strengthen collaboration and trust and the third tested your patience, the final one does everything to break you and your partners bonding. The result if withstanded is a deeper and stronger bond. 

Sometimes I wished I could rediscover those games as if I never played them before and then playing them for the first time again. Its so great to take each new person in my life to get to know them with playing the great We Were Here Series. 

I am so gratefull for those games and I hope total Mayhem can bring us more great games. I mean we got a smaller one shot set in the world of We Were Here but with this being the final new oportunities like new settings open up. I d like to see a game that kinda resembles a great Indiana Jones adventure in forgotten jungle temple or buried desert civilizations.

if you want to play a game with a friend to laugh, cry, scream, and want dead by the end of the day. this is the perfect game for you. this game will show you just how stupid you and your friend are and how bad your communication skills are. though the rage, your friendship will grow after the smoke settles.

The game is about 5 hours of puzzle content with twice as much filler.

The capstone of this filler is at the end where a hub to three puzzles require you to get three mcmuffin pieces. Each spoke in the hub has a long unskippable travel sequence to a separate puzzle level. Once complete you must trudge back carrying a heavy object to a gondola up through a loading door to place the object then immediately walk back through the same loading door to ride the slow gondola back.

The puzzle quality has diminished when compared to previous entries in the Were Here series. The most memorable one I took issue with required one person to submit items one at a time to hear their description. So it literally couldn't be solved except by trial and error submitting one item at a time until finding the one that makes sense.

All told I feel that the increase in production "value" decreased the overall experience. Taller ceilings, greater environmental detail, and longer cutscenes made the experience of solving puzzles with a friend more frustrating. Especially when the design was compromised to slowly show off one of the value elements. I was completely willing to tolerate the poor visuals in previous games as none of the visuals in this one were worth the cost in time.

Some of the levels are beautiful but I feel that this game has a ton of issues. 
Main one: me and my friend, who played all of the games in the series, got hard stuck in 2 of the puzzles. We had to restart the game and the whole puzzle. Pretty frustrating.
Second: This game is way more linear in its puzzles, it also makes one of the players work way more than another.

At the end of the first chapter, you can get locked in the exit area. One of the players is behind and cannot proceed by himself, while the other is stuck in the exit area without being able to help his friend. We looked up on the internet and found in reddit other people stuck the same way. (Two posts, actually.) This is utter crap.

Don't get me wrong. I love this kind of game. I played all the previous installments with this same friend. And it never had happened before. In the previous games, you could die, but that would only send you to the start of the puzzle. There never was a puzzle that would leave you locked. The only way is to exit the game, then load and start again.

It shows a complete lack of testing before publishing. Quite regrettable.

EDIT: We've completed the game. We got hard locked again on another puzzle. And in a third puzzle there was one dial that would open three windows each time you turned it. But it glitched, stopped opening the windows and we had to load game once again.

Clearly this game was not made with the care it required. Quite a downturn for such a good series.

When I initially reviewed this game, I completely glossed over the EULA agreement. To be frank, I don't remember agreeing to the privacy policy, but it is very likely I subconsciously did and let my inner fan boy for the We Were Here series take over. In my previous positive review I said this:

"A significant improvement over the previous game. I appreciate the implementation of colors and shapes in puzzles to accommodate those with color vision deficiencies. However, the menu is wonky and the price tag is still fairly steep when you consider an average playtime at 11 hours."

I think Total Mayhem Games was originally well-received because it started as an Indie company comprised of a small group of students tasked with creating a game in a few weeks. Unfortunately, I will no longer be a customer of the series in the future if they continue to use this 3rd Party EULA agreement to collect, process, and store your personal information. 

Oh, don't worry gamers, you can exercise your rights to delete your personal information. All you have to do is "include your name, street address, city, state, and ZIP code" in your deletion request. Lol. You for real Total Mayhem Games?

I got what I wanted from the adventure (asymmetrical co-op), but the game has its issues. Puzzles feel overly curated and focus tested, there are too few moving parts. Some puzzles can be solved without understanding the logic, just by looking at restrictions and getting the right way by elimination (egregious example of this is the light and mirrors puzzle, I literally didn't think for a second about possible angles and positions and just put items in only possible slots left by designers). Expanded maps are a blessing and a curse -- they are pretty, but you often run around for some minutes without anything happening. The final puzzle was underwhelming and extremely easy. And the ending itself, well, frankly it's so horrible that we laughed in astonishment. Last portion of the game left a poor taste in my mouth.

My friend and I first accidentally stumbled upon We Were Here back when it first released and were absolutely delighted to have found a fun, co-operative puzzle game that really tested our problem solving ability and really pushed us to work on our communication and teamwork skills. This series has been incredible, with each new game bringing even more intense puzzles on a bigger scale and really intuitive and complex ways of solving them. This has been an incredible series of games to play and we're always looking forward to the next one. WWHF really blew the whole series out of the water. Absolutely the most content rich game they have made to date. The puzzles were probably the most difficult ones we have encountered yet but the amount of a dopamine rush you get when you finally have that Eureka moment and something just clicks is what makes us come back every time a new game is released. The story, the animations, the mechanics of the puzzles, the ending - everything about this game was top tier. Play this game, play it again with the roles swapped, you won't be disappointed. This way, you'll have the entire adventure and plenty of cooperative puzzle fun for hours.

"We Were Here Forever" builds upon the previous games and is quite the improvement. The graphics are much better, the puzzles are more challenging and enjoyable, and the game offers a much longer gameplay experience. It's the pinnacle of the 'We Were Here' series. Highly recommended!

Title: A Journey of Connection: We Were Here Forever and the Power of Friendship

We Were Here Forever, the latest installment in the captivating puzzle-adventure series, brings forth a unique blend of mystery, collaboration, and camaraderie that strengthens connections in unexpected ways. The game's intricate puzzles and engaging narrative set the stage for players to forge strong bonds, much like the heartfelt connection you share with your friend David.

At its core, We Were Here Forever presents an exquisite co-op experience that transcends traditional gaming dynamics. The seamless interdependence required to unravel the mysteries of Castle Rock fosters an environment where teamwork flourishes, mirroring the profound connection between you and David. The game's carefully crafted challenges serve as metaphors for the challenges that life can present, emphasizing the importance of open communication and trust in overcoming obstacles.

Much like the way We Were Here Forever celebrates collaboration, mu relationship with David has evidently blossomed into a unique and cherished connection. As you navigate the enigmatic puzzles together, the joy of discovery and the elation of overcoming hurdles reflect the shared journey you both embrace in your friendship. The game becomes a canvas upon which my bond with David deepens, painting a picture of resilience and unity.

We Were Here Forever not only delivers an engaging gaming experience but also encapsulates the essence of meaningful connections. Just as the game's puzzles are solved through mutual understanding, so too is my relationship with David nurtured by empathy and shared experiences. my sentiment about the game's romantic undertones is a testament to the transformative power of friendship, and your heartfelt connection adds an extra layer of beauty to an already captivating narrative.
The best puzzle game on steam in my opinion, I strongly recommend playing the entire series. A great game to play with a close friend or a partner.

Its a good game, but the lack of any threat whatsoever is what holds it back from being the best in the series.

We Were Here is a series of co-op escape room games all set in or around an antarctic castle. The thing that defined the series from every other co-op escape room game is the sense that the castle is trying to kill you, and the story is of survivors trying to escape. Unfortunately, We Were Here Forever decided to forego that sense of danger - its uniqueness - to tell a narrative at the forefront, rather than supplementary to the game itself as seen prior.

As a standalone game, without looking at any of the previous games in the series, it is a good co-op escape room game that has a story that follows the players.

But looking back and comparing to the series as a whole, it is sorely lacking in what made the series magical.

I've played all the games in this series with a friend of mine.
We loved them all.
However, this one falls short compared to the previous one.
Now don't get me wrong, some of the puzzles are amazing and a few of these may be my favourite.
Yet some of them feels like there's more one sided puzzles. For example, the ocean maze seemed to have had next to nothing for the person in the maze to do.
Another has 1 person creating a picture while the other just exists to rotate some things and tell you if pieces seem wrong or not. Sure they can try to help but if they can't see the images they can't do much better than say "right, wrong, flipped"

There's also a lack of time trial puzzles. Think the Potion one is the only one in the game and while its alright, it provides you with all the information to solve it beforehand and you activate things then have to wait for them to be finished, meaning it's a much more lax experience than previous puzzles of similar vein which had the puzzles and information revealed over the course of the puzzle, leading to panicked communication discussing what needs to be done.
Funnily enough, the maze one was more panicked and pressed for time than the Potion, even though the Maze's time limit was long and had plenty of reset points.

Overall, good game, some great puzzles, but also a lot of misses that makes me feel like the previous game was superior overall.

We Were Here Forever is a two person co-op puzzle game where you must work with a friend to figure out a variety of puzzles after (usually) being placed in two different areas (on occasion you're in the same area). One person has the role of being responsible for instructing the other person who typically has the more interactive role in solving a puzzle. These roles change/are random, so one person won't be stuck doing all the work in one playthrough. There are six different chapters, each of which has multiple subchapters, that must be solved this way, using clues that are in each area.

Overall, I found this game quite fun. It's a little unclear what you're supposed to do when you first start, but you can generally figure it out by clicking around and communicating what you're seeing to your teammate. The game glitched three separate times throughout my entire time playing it, including once in the first 15 minutes, which can add to the confusion/feeling like you're stuck (because you literally are lol). The Memento, The Illusions, and The Assembly were the best subchapters, in my opinion. 

This game is the fourth in the We Were Here series. One playthrough took ~13.5 hours and a second playthrough for achievements (switching positions) took ~2 hours. If a co-op puzzle game sounds like something you'd enjoy, I'd recommend this game, though I definitely recommend playing the original as it is free and will give you a good sense of the type of gameplay you'll be getting into. This game and the others in the series follow the original very closely, so if you enjoyed the original/second/third game, you'll likely enjoy this one too.

I found "We Were Here Forever" to be a visually stunning co-op puzzle game.
The game takes me and my wife through various environments, from castle interiors to surreal dreamscapes.
The puzzles are the star of the show, testing our teamwork, observational skills, and communication.
The game requires two copies for co-op play, which can be a barrier.
The game's plot is self-contained, making it easy to jump in without prior knowledge of the series.
The game is best enjoyed with a like-minded friend who loves escape rooms and asymmetrical puzzle games.
The puzzles are tough, but there's always a logic to them, and hints are available if we hit a wall.
Overall, I consider "We Were Here Forever" a W for the series, offering one of the best co-op experiences around.

10/10 I recommend the entire series. Start from the first one  and work your way here. By the time you get here, you'll be primed to think in the way the puzzles are asking you to. Also, this one is the most story-heavy and, while not required, players will really benefit from having the set-up from the previous games.

We discovered the first one back when it came out, and have both bought every subsequent one as it was released. I hope they never stop making them, even if they have to switch to a different story-line at some point. It was such a new and innovative way to approach a puzzle game, and now it is familiar but still so unique to these games that we've never gotten tired of it. Make sure to find someone who is communicative and willing to think out loud with you, or the game'll be a bust.

There are definitely puzzles that have appeared over the years that we have had more trouble with than others (we seem to be particularly bad at snow-based mazes...). And yes, glitches have appeared in both this one and the second one (and the second game is still my favorite of the set) that I remember specifically, but none of them have been enough to break the enjoyment of the game for us. Each game makes sure to have a fun set of new things to sort out, keeping the puzzles fresh, including a different set of consequences for failure. Aesthetic call-backs to previous games make for a fun consistency without requiring you to have played all of them to catch the gist of what is going on (but you still should! ^_^).

I absolutely recommend playing each of these games twice so the second time through you can switch and see the other side. Even better? The first game in the series is free. It's a much simpler version, but a great way to see if you think the play-style is something you'd find fun.

One thing I cannot stress enough about playing any game in this series the first time around:
PLAY IT WITH THE WALKIE-TALKIE FEATURE. Don't jump on discord with open mic or play it in the same room. I promise you are missing out on a huge aspect of the game in doing so.

I've played the previous 3. This is the worst one out of the series. The first puzzle is the "tutorial". Alright nothing too difficult and teaching the controls that's fine I guess, but we're sitting at #4 in the series and there are no new mechanics being introduced so a little unnecessary in my opinion. The area you reach next with it's own set of puzzles right after that I didn't have an issue with. More of the area opened up as you solved your puzzles together, eventually making it all connect together. After that though, it started going downhill from there.

As many others have explained in their own negative reviews, there are a number of puzzles where one person is doing the thinking and solving and the other player is just sitting there bored and waiting for whatever input they need to either relay or insert themselves. They don't actually get to interact with the puzzle themselves, in turn making them feel useless and wondering "When is it my turn?"

Unfortunately after that area, the same player that was sitting there waiting for the other, has to endure it again, and again, and again, and again. Yes 4 times in a row. They carry a heavy ball very very slowly as the other player tells them where to walk. At first, I thought we failed and restarted the puzzle somehow because these four puzzles are extremely identical but no, it's just the same thing 4 times in a row. Then a very long walk through a sewer, then a cave, then to a cutscene. That walk felt extremely out of place and we felt like we were missing something because of it. A few of the previous puzzles just had a loading screen so why is there a long walk here when there is nothing on the way? After the cutscene you enter another puzzle where we eventually called it quits and requested a refund because we soft locked our selves by getting one of us stuck forcing us to restart this very long puzzle.

I don't recommend this game and I agree with other reviews saying that they were trying to make it more commercially safe and less intense. It's a shame for I really liked the other 3 games in the series, with the third one being the best, and was hoping for this one to top it.

I'd give this game a 9,5 out of 10.

PS, the way it elaborates on the story of the previous games is a nice bonus.

The Pros: Some of the puzzles are quite good and unique and certainly creative. There also seems to be a lot of content. I'm ~7 hrs in and the game is still going.

The Cons: This game has very poor indication of when your progress was saved. Saving occurs infrequently. Game breaking bugs will force you to start a section over again from the beginning. And it has tedious sections where you have to spend a long time to effectively burning time. I've encountered not one, but two bugs that soft locked the game preventing progress, requiring restarting the section and having to do the entire section again. Also one of the puzzles was extremely difficult - not sure if it was me or my partner - or neither, but we ended up just brute forcing the puzzle mostly. Even after finding the solutions, a lot of the options didn't make sense to us. Keep in mind we had no issues on any other puzzles, just that one (the graveyard area).

Overall, I'm mostly unimpressed. The key part of any game is being able to play it and to not have it waste your time. In that regard, This game does not get a passing grade.

I loved the first three entries in this series, but I just cannot get into this game. While a good many of the puzzles are fun to solve, the ones that aren't (like the Sunken Mines and the Dome of Creation) are so unfun that they make me dread playing. A friend and I have been working our way through these games, and I think the Dome of Creation is where our journey is cut short. After several tries, we can't make all the ingredients in the short amount of time provided, and it's frustrating and honestly, a bit rage inducing. This following so shortly after the Sunken Mines, where we quite literally had to use a play by play guide to get through. I consider myself a fairly intelligent person, but something about these puzzles isn't clicking and it was felt good to finally call it quits and uninstall the game.

As a small pro, deciphering the Guardian's language was quite possibly one of the funniest gaming experiences ever. I was talking to the Guardian, my friend had the key, and it was a hilarious twenty minutes of us making random noises back and forth and each other. 10/10 would translate for the Guardian again.

First of all I’ve played other parts of the series - the previous one was better.

This part is just asking for negative.

[b]Communication[/b]

This part is totally broken. There are a lot of situations where sound is getting chopped in middle of talking or its not getting transmitted at all even though You see that the device is running. This is not acceptable! Especially when the communication is the most important thing in this game. We’ve had some disagreement with other player after the game because [i]“I didn’t provided information”[/i], and vice versa however I did provided some clues and other person provided them to me (but I’ve never heard them).

We’ve ended up playing with discord – this breaks the immersion.

This has to be fixed because it can lead to amazing frustration and misunderstanding. 

[b]Game saving[/b]

The auto save is annoying. There are days where You just want to jump in for a moment, as You don’t always have time to play - so I ended up with case where I had to go to sleep, but I couldn’t as I was in middle of the puzzle, that was amazingly annoying.

As a developer I can understand that it’s probably easier to implement because You have to revert world to always to the same state, with less things to care about.

This auto saving was an issue before, and still is.

[b]The story[/b]

Story itself is “not so bad”, it provides lot of information about the “King” and his subordinates (sadly jester is rarely present on the scene), also finally got some explanation of “what the We Were Here” stands for.

[b]Tasks / puzzles[/b]

[i]Turns out there were many situations where only one of us was thinking and other was just waiting for some input from the thinking. Feels like there were less of such situations in previous part of the game.[/i]


[h1]“This section contains spoilers!”[/h1]

[list]
[*] Brute force
[/list]

[spoiler]There are way to many puzzles that can be solved with just a brute force. Like for example the one with Graveyard, where instead of checking the family tree lines, trying to understand what it is about it was faster to rush through all the graves. No fun in this at all. Yes – could’ve agreed on doing it the slow way but easier to say than to do, You can’t always stop the other side from going the brute way.[/spoiler]

[list]
[*]Colors based episode (garden),
[/list]


[spoiler]The water based transportation and recycling machine are both very annoying. There is a time limit here and it’s amazingly annoying to watch the bowls swim so calm and slow – ended up with picking them up and moving them manually to the curve, this way it could reach the other player.[/spoiler]

[list]
[*]Ending
[/list]

[spoiler]Titanic ending? Never liked that specific scene. In this case both could stay on the plank, just creating some balance on both ends, also why sticking to it instead of swimming to some other floating objects? It’s really hard to believe that 2 characters that beat all the puzzles were to stupid to think about other solution.[/spoiler]

[b]Summary[/b]

Well the game ain’t so bad, but was more frustrating than previous part. The immersion is lost somewhere. It’s still the same game as before, same rules – communication wise etc. but it just doesn’t fit for me. Kind of hoped for next part and enjoyed the announcement of that one, but not really waiting for any next episode (if there is any planned) after this episode.

There are probably more things I could mention about but guess I just forgot them.

This is probably the best game in the series, and is ultimately a great time for you and a friend to complete over a few play sessions. I think this type of game is a lot of fun and I wish there were more like it. However it's still not perfect and I'd love to see them take another shot or two at this. 

My biggest complaint for the game is that too many of the puzzles are one-sided. Which would be more okay if you were forced to switch back and forth between roles. Typically speaking you have a solver and a "doer" for lack of a better word. The solver is the one doing all the solving. The doer will sometimes have info the solver needs in order to solve the puzzle but it's easy enough to relay that info - it's not "hard" except for maybe the one part of the game where you need to mimic sounds to the solver. Then the doer has to actually do it. Like press the buttons in the right order or walk along the correct path or whatever. This in a vacuum works but when you accidentally find one person in the solver role over and over, I think it gets both tiring for the person doing all the solving and boring for the one always doing. The other side of this is if there is one person who isn't as good at solving you could always have them in the doer position and it could just be fun coop for them, except, there's no indicator in any given puzzle which path will take you to a solving or doing path. That aspect of the game could just be polished up a bit.

The one minor complaint I have is that this game makes you just sit and wait thru long transition scenes occasionally. And especially at one point you are forced to go up and down a slow moving lift like 6 times. This just feels like padding. There are some other transitional spots that at least have better views/spectacle but at the end of the day these felt like a waste of time. 

One last note is that I think it's cool there's a story going on and I also think it's smart how a few of the puzzles incorporate the lore to get you a bit engaged with it. Unfortunately the characters talk too esoterically about it and it just feels like it's slowing us down or getting in the way. Like I think I know the basic outline of what happened but I don't really understand how it got us to where we are now and so much of what is being said feels like gibberish. I think you should actually just simplify it more. Why not just have this jester guy be a mad puzzler dude who is just playing games with two random dudes? The jester puzzles were some of the best in the game anyway.

As with the other games in the series, the walkie-talkie system forcing you to take turns speaking really makes the whole thing feel just that extra bit special, however, we again had issues with the in game mic. The other games wouldnt always even detect the mic, but in this one it at least managed that. Unfortunately the quality was crackly and poor, and would cut in and out even when adjusting the settings to try and make it more consistent. Luckily due to previous experience, we have an almost perfect solution:

-Adjust whatever settings you need to in game or in steam, such that your mics are not picked up by the game or heard by each other. We just turned the voice transmit and receive volume in game to the minimum.
-Be in a voice call with each other on Discord.
-Set your Discord mic to push-to-talk.
-Go into your Discord keybindings menu.
-Set a new keybinding for "push-to-talk (with priority)", using the same key as the in game walkie-talkie, for us it was right mouse button.
-This will duck the other person's audio when you are trying to speak, and light up their in game walkie-talkie so they can see that you are trying to speak if they are also trying to speak.

This is a decent enough solution that achieves the goals of the walkie system, whilst maintaining the quality and reliability of Discord voice chat.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/] Please follow [b]United Critics[/b] for quality reviews[/url]

[h1]Bring a coat and bring a friend[/h1]
We Were Here Forever is a beautiful exploring, action adventure, puzzle, Co-op only, escape room game as it is the last Sequel of the “We Were Here” series.
The whole game has in complete six chapters and it takes around 10 hours to complete, more or less. It all depends on the players and how good they are at puzzles.
The game is about communicating. Each player gets a walkie in the beginning to be able and speak with the other player. As all walkies work, only one person can speak at a time and the player has to hold down the button to speak.

The two players has to make their way through a ton of obstacles, made of puzzles. Each player will have their own walkway, so to say. And will have the answer for the other player in a clue of an icon, or simply a lever that will open a gate or door for the other player.
At some points, the players will be able to work together at the same place but most of the time they will be split up. For certain tasks it requires both players to help in either: moving a bookshelf or pulling a lever.

[h1]The Game of The Play[/h1]
As the game starts, both the players will wake up in some mushroom prison. They will find walkies laying in their cell and discover that the cell doors are unlocked. The players will see that they weren’t in the same room as their cells were in and has to start looking for which door that’s unlocked.
After finding their way to a tunnel, they will walk upon their first puzzle in the game. Where one player has to tell the other some symbols that they see on a wall behind some metal bars, as the other player just has to pull a lever to open the first players door.

When reaching the point of where the players are able to obtain the torch they will shortly after stumble upon some metal bars that keeps them apart but atleast lets the players meet.
The players will then find two levers for each players that they have to pull down together to open a spiked door that will lead them to an abandoned mine but also used to be a home. Who’s? we don’t know, but we do know that this brings more puzzles.
Once again the two players will be split apart and can use a basket to travel items or keys over to the other to be able and unlock some objects to get new items or unlock more of the area to get deeper into the puzzle.
At times both players has to be on the same side or even switch side depending on if one is overthinking about the puzzle and unable to look at it from another perspective from their side. So his companion has to take over and see if he can explain or understand the puzzle themselves.

Each chapter has a completely different puzzle, so its never the same and won’t get boring that easily over time while playing. Though the mind can get fried from all the puzzles.
In fact each chapter has its own worlds or places with total new puzzles and new areas for both players.
The game has it set so there is a player 1 and player 2, the choosing of who’s who can be made in the main menu before starting the game.
Depending if your player 1 or player 2, only gives you different tasks and achievements after completing different puzzles.
Each player will see their own area when split up. So they will have to try and find a common ground/object or puzzle in their area that might give any clues or ability to unlock further into the game.

The areas or biomes that the players will see under their journey are underground mines, Some kind of torture games, the ruins of rockbury castle and town, the rockbury church, Underwater laboratory, the riddle’s play box and much more under the journey. There is big and small areas with different amounts of detailing, and every place you visit will be a new view for the eyes and mind.

[b]Spoiler[/b]
[spoiler]For the last game sequel of the series they had to give it a sad end. After the players destroys the castle, the church demolishes to bits. Making them fall down into the sea beneath.
Both players will swim towards a light that’s hanging from a wooden pole on a small raft that sadly only can fit one player.
The players can choose from either saving their friend and sacrificing themselves or getting saved by their friend but loosing them aswell. One man keeps his life as the other sinks to the freezing bottom of the sea, when out of nowhere a cargo ship arrives to the rescue.
Only one player survives, but at what cost...[/spoiler]

[h1]Visual & Audio[/h1]
[b]Visuals[/b]

[u]Game Textures and lights[/u]
The visuals and surrounding in the game are quite beautiful and are very well done. The ground and objects doesn’t collide into one and other and the small detailing in every little corner. It’s just a good-looking game that also makes it more fun to play.
At the beginning of the game, the shading in the tunnels/corridors had bright spots in the corners up by the roof.
Where it should be darker it’s just some brighter small light. As if it is cracks in the stones with some kind of light coming from inside of nowhere.

The texture quality of the game makes no disappointments, anywhere you look you will see how beautiful the game really is. The smooth combinations and perfect size and color fit for the objects around on the worlds. Adding the small details to the game just gives it a little extra without the player thinking about it, they just feel it and see it while exploring the world and solving the puzzles.

[u]Game Animations[/u]
Along through the chapters I saw the animation for everything around and for the actions we did. Pulling levers, going with rides, breaking stuff. It all went so smooth and no problem in sight with anything.
The cutscenes runs fantastically and the moving animation of objects and players, like bridges or mechanisms and the puppeteer/the Riddler.

[b]Audio[/b]
[u]Background Music[/u]
The music for the game doesn’t get boring. It changes along with the progress that happens in the game and depending on situation, the music will change.

[u]Voice actors[/u]
The voice acting in the game is quite stunning, The passion and emotion putted into the characters. Beside the Castle/King’s voice actor, his voice sounds deeper but its missing the power and emotion in it. Its like he’s just saying the words with a deeper voice and not speaking the words, expressing them.

[u]Sound effects[/u]
The sound effects in the game have been specially made for each object, for example: The crackling old wood or heavy stone grinding against the same material as the object moves, falls, or grinds against something else. With the echo to make it sound like the sound travels through the area like real life and muffles the further your away from it.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
•	Always different puzzles.
•	Interesting story and lore.
•	Smooth object animations.
•	A lot of creativity.
•	Longer gameplay with more content.

[b]Cons[/b]
•	The in-game communication with the walkies isn’t that comfortable or different then just simply using, for example: Discord.
•	Sometimes the torch doesn’t want to respond to the “R” button, short time after it works.

[h1]My final little thoughts[/h1]
The game is a lot longer with more content and puzzles then the earlier games in the series. And I was having a blast while playing it. The game is a Co-op only but luckily I had my friend Hulp to the rescue for he had the game already.
We tried out the walkies in the beginning, but they didn’t do anything specific or given any extra spark to it, so we just communicated through a discord call.
I highly recommend this game but only if you do have a partner, companion, friend, or person to play with.

Rating: 9/10

We where here for sure

We Were Here Forever is the perfect game for those who want to experience a unique and challenging puzzle adventure with a friend. As the title suggests, you and your partner will feel like you've been playing this game for eternity, but in the best possible way!

The game's premise is simple: you and your partner are two explorers trapped in a mysterious castle, and you must work together to solve puzzles and escape. However, the execution is anything but simple, with mind-bending puzzles and unexpected twists and turns at every turn.

The game's graphics and sound design are top-notch, creating a haunting and immersive atmosphere that will keep you on edge throughout the entire game. The puzzles themselves are cleverly designed, requiring both communication and teamwork to solve. And the best part? You and your partner will likely make plenty of mistakes along the way, leading to some hilarious and unforgettable moments.

Overall, We Were Here Forever is a must-play game for anyone who loves puzzle-solving and cooperative gameplay. Just make sure to bring a friend, because this game is designed to be played with a partner. So, grab your best buddy, put on your thinking caps, and get ready to be trapped in a castle for eternity (or at least a few hours)!

An honest review for the game:

[b] Pros [/b]
- The game has the most beautiful setting out of all the games.
- It felt like a nice open world and you could make choices on what chapter you wanted to play first. [spoiler](chapters 3-5)[/spoiler]
- The game explores so much more lore than the previous games.
- Most puzzles were very fun! They were also a lot more challenging and required good teamwork.
- Level design was enormous and gorgeous.
- Great little easter eggs towards the Netherlands and the voice actors are on point.
- The music is just spot on. The game definitely deserves the great soundtrack tag!

[b] Cons [/b]
- The game is [b] too often [/b] very tedious. Sometimes animations take literal minutes. [spoiler]Prime examples are: Going into the skilift, going in the elevator from chapel to the statue, going up and down in the water level. Like seriously, why does it take so long!? It's also unskippable[/spoiler] The loading screen also took a long while, long enough to make you think the game may have crashed.
- Another point to add regarding the pacing of the game: sometimes when you finally solved a puzzle, you got the same one again! [spoiler]For example the illusions (portal room) had the same puzzle twice. Also  you did the trial (game where you hold the boulder) 4 times. All times not very challenging[/spoiler]
- The ending was a little dissapointing and was over before you even know it.
- Sometimes you got stuck in puzzles, but not because they were too hard, but  because the clues were too well hidden. After minutes of searching we finally found them. It was pretty frustrating. Could just be us being blind though.
- General bugs and lag (luckily we didn't find any gamebreaking ones)

Don't get me wrong, I love the franchise and I like the game. I also think the developers have done an amazing job involving the community and delaying the game to make sure everything is good. But for me and my friend it genuinly felt like a bit of a downgrade from the previous game. Also, I was an alpha tester for the game, but 2/3 games didn't make it into the final game. I was curious as to why that was as the alpha levels we played were quite fun! Finally, this is my own preference, but what I liked about the previous games is that both players experienced different stories. In this game, it's the same story for both, but just the puzzles that were different. [spoiler]Sometime after playing, one player got a puppet hand attached to him. We were excited to see what it meant. However in the ending the jester just takes it from you? So why all that build up. It seems like wasted potential[/spoiler] This makes it so that we don't feel like replaying the game.

TL;DR
I [b] 100% recommend [/b] this game, but it does not go without its flaws. The game is objectively bigger and better than the previous one. However me and my friend preferred the story and puzzles of We Were Here Together.

Every single one of the games in this series are absolutely amazing. The puzzles and joy and frustration of figuring them out with your partner quickly took the backseat to the captivating story for me. That's not to say the puzzles are lacking, because they aren't. It's the most fun I've had playing a puzzle game - Ever. My friend and I, my partner consistently throughout the series, constantly find ourselves wishing for the next installment when something reminds us of them. Total Mayhem Games swiftly became one of my favorite developers in the span of months and the growth that is evident from the first title to this most recent is astounding. I hope they make games like these for many years to come.

I'm not particularly great at expressing myself but hopefully that only serves to help you understand just how much I love these games. My only complaint (which isn't really a complaint) is that I go through withdrawals waiting to see what Total Mayhem Games does next. If you love puzzle games and story and you have someone enthused to experience them with you(Communication is key!), then I recommend you do yourself a favor and go buy all of these games. You won't regret it!

I hate having to say that I wouldn't recommend this game. I have played every single game in the series, but this one fell flat to me. The story was alright, but convoluted. The puzzles were subpar to what they could have been. The only good puzzles were the jester puzzles in chapter 1. The kraken puzzle was a terrible idea. having to describe a sound to someone when people can't really make those sounds anyway is so terrible. The cutscenes for transitioning was so terrible. Most of the time was literally spent dealing with the cutscenes for transitions. The position mixing on the Nautilus was an unnecessary time constraint because the puzzle was "too easy." Having to do that puzzle so many times due to one machine taking FOREVER to make a red or green potion was just UGH. I don't think it was worth the money for the lack of gameplay. This game is an absolute pleasure to play. From the moment I started, I was completely engrossed in the fascinating world and the challenging puzzles. The graphics and sound design are perfect for this type of game, creating a haunting and atmospheric environment that perfectly complements the gameplay.

But what really sets "We Were Here Forever" apart is its unique cooperative gameplay. The game requires two players to work together, communicate with each other and solve puzzles in real time. This not only makes the game incredibly fun and engaging, but also encourages teamwork and communication skills.

The puzzles themselves are well-thought-out, challenging but not too difficult. They require a mix of logical thinking, observation and communication to solve, so the game always stays fresh and interesting.

Areas need to be explored very carefully so as not to miss any clues or puzzle pieces. Solving puzzles unlocks new areas, which in turn contain new puzzles. I found myself lost in the world of the game, uncovering hidden secrets and unraveling the mysteries of the castle. With the Fool, I was never quite sure if I was about to be surprised by a Jump-scare attack.

Overall, I would recommend We Were Here Forever to anyone looking for a unique and addictive cooperative puzzle game. The game is an absolute gem that should not be missed. It took us about 15 hours to play and we were a bit stupid at times. Thank you @freizeitrobin for the wonderful adventure.
