I love this series but for the amount of play time I would never be able to just suggest the full price. That and the replay value. I do love love love these games, all four of them had a special spark. But I'd just catch it on a sale to make sure you get the most bang for your buck.

[h1]Together Forever[/h1]
Having a tradition of writing a review for every title from the We Were Here franchise, I would do this game a huge injustice if I have skipped it. Especially given that Forever is, without a shadow of a doubt, the best of the series. The biggest, the most complicated and by far the most expensive of all four games, We Were Here Forever takes you on one (and probably last) adventure. But is it worth it? 
You can bet your ass it is. There really are no obvious flaws that I could talk about. This game is simply great and you should buy it. Without hesitation, if you happen to have a friend or a loved one up for some logical puzzles. Hell, even with internet strangers this game might be one hell of an experience.

[h1]In awe at the size of this lad[/h1]
I am honestly astounded by how far this game series has come. It’s mind-boggling that something that used to be a tiny free game to be completed in one sitting has become a giant, highly-polished product which gives so much content it is difficult to overstate how fun it can be.
The very first thing I have to note is that from previous experiences with We Were Here games, both myself and my mate Alvarion who I had a pleasure of playing all four titles with, expected this game to be short. Or at least short-ER. Short enough to complete it with one, monstrous 8h sitting. Maybe 10-12 hours if need be. Needless to say, we weren’t even close. It took us well over 14 hours to complete the title for the first time. [b]And that’s worth a praise.[/b] Because literally at no point was the game boring or time wasted. No, it was a blast through and throughout this many hours. It’s a puzzle game with an enormous number of things to do in it. We Were Here Forever is an absolute unit. There is just a puzzle, after a puzzle, after a puzzle and it really doesn’t seem to end until you really are reaching the conclusion of the story. 

One thing that you might want to take away from this is… I’m not saying you [i]can’t[/i] complete WWHF in one sitting. There is a certain threshold after which that fragile pink mass hidden within your skull cavity starts giving up. I think we have reached our maximum brain capacities at 6 hours mark on the first day. With logic games you should really watch out for that. Cause there is a moment in which you become tired of playing, no matter how fun the title is. Keeping a high level of focus necessary to solve complex puzzles gets more and more difficult as the time goes on. Take my advice, go for short or longer breaks after each chapter to come back fresh and be the best “you” you can be.

Having that in mind, the developers neatly divided the game into chapters. Each of them consists of a couple of themed puzzles. To give you a better look into the world of We Were Here, every puzzle also presents some narrative elements. Big enough for you to notice how tied to the game world each puzzle is, small enough to let you go to the bathroom without worrying of losing an important piece of storytelling. 

Speaking of storytelling – the story that was first hinted in We Were Here, then shyly expanded in We Were Here Too, and then pushed to something I could call an actual piece of narrative in We Were Here Together, and is FINALLY focused on in Forever. Merely speaking of it could be too revealing so let me just tell you what I think about it.
It's good. It’s nothing groundbreaking but it does make sense. It ties the previous games together and gives you more information about the lore behind all those events. Total Mayhem Games was not scared to put a short cinematic cutscene between each chapter and then create a great visual finale before and after the actual story climax. It was a great decision because nothing seems out of place anymore while still keeping that elusive masquerade of not telling you everything.

[h1]Use your brain[/h1]
Something I should perhaps touch on is the game’s difficulty level. [i]Well? What is it, Tank?[/i]
I’m gonna say… it’s perfectly balanced. For the first time in the series.
What do I mean by that?

There are multiple puzzles to go through, from matching shapes, through describing sounds, playing spot the difference, planning routes, placing things in correct spaces to doing all of these things in correct order under the pressure of time. And it’s fantastic. This is the first game in the series, where Alvarion and I made a list of puzzles we liked and disliked each and while our lists varied… we were never like [i]“this one thing sucked”[/i]. All of the challenges were fun and engaging. Obviously to a different degree, but neither of them was downright bad. Well, maybe except the underwater labyrinth.
As you can imagine some things had us scratching our heads for a nice little while… but it was never because the puzzle was too convoluted to understand or because it was designed poorly. Every puzzle can be solved. We just had to figure them out first. We were actually surprised that the difficulty level does not go through a sudden spike but rather goes at a steady pace through the entire title.
I would really hurt your experience by telling you about the puzzles themselves but there is one thing you need to know:

[h1]This game is like a good psychological horror movie[/h1]
We Were Here Forever is best experienced [b]ONCE[/b]. And only once.
When I said that every puzzle can be solved, I wasn’t lying. It can be. Sadly, there is only one key to every quote unquote “riddle”. ONLY one. Everything you go through will be EXACTLY the same on all other playthroughs, to the point where after completing the game once, when my friend and I switched roles… we could complete some of the puzzles without even communicating. Memory alone was enough to lead us straight through them.

Is it a bad thing that the game can be completed only once? I don’t believe it is. But that is a one step back from the previous titles. In other entries of the series the roles that you take were distinct enough from one another to keep you invested into a second playthrough. After completing WWHF once you probably will never start this game ever again. Is it… a problem though? I’d say that the longer time it takes to complete the We Were Here Forever makes up for the fact that you’re better off playing it only once.

Played all of the other We Were Here games leading up to this and the one word i can use to review this game would be "disappointing".  Puzzles arent that complicated and never had the dopamine rush of finally understanding the puzzle after being stumped on it for so long. No time based puzzles that put someone in danger (the closest thing to it would be the water oxygen puzzle but it never arose any sense of imminent danger). 

The story explained some new stuff but was disappointing to never see it used. The king binded/signed his soul to a demon/evil and is now on castle rock while his kingdom is cold and empty. The kingfolk left to escape his growing corruption and built one last contraption for the people in the future to use against the king. Only for it to be a portal to neverland for the jester to leave with the kings contract. 

The ending was very upsetting and felt rushed. The king found your existence and had the power to remove half the tower roof but then chose to just sit there while you and your partner do the most easiest puzzle in the whole game. The climax the final puzzle the confrontation was just "push wood off beacon, hold these two levers together). Then brings you to the final "who lives" decision. in other we were here games it was "only one could keep the gate open" "a soul is needed for a sacrifice to trap the jester" for this it was just who wants to hog the raft?? It made it look like the devs felt like they NEEDED to put that conclusion in and the ending result was lackluster.

Another small nitpicking was lack of individual cutscenes for separate players like we were here together which made your experience very unique and different from your partner but instead you spent most of the game with eachother and experienced the same story instead of each person having two parts of the story and putting it together.

Being a game that was made after We Were Here Together i had high hopes they would remain on the idea of an "individual unique experience" but sadly it dropped in quality
I hope they make more.  I would pay in an instant

This is by far one of the best co-op puzzle and just game in general. If you ever are thinking of a game to play with that one best friend of yours that have been inseparable for life, this is the one. Absolutely phenomenal experience. I will not spoil a single second, just never forget that We Were Here.

Only was able to get through half the game before getting bored but ultimately frustrated too. The puzzles felt like child's play and not very enthralling. The only one that knocked my socks off was the Jester's Realm. Even at that we soft locked ourselves at the very end of the puzzle and just gave up the game. We played the previous games and we're very excited for this one, but I personally think it doesn't compare. The puzzles lack the creativity the previous games did especially when comparing it to We Were Here Together. I found the puzzles were absent of hazards, where tension was built to finish the puzzle in a time constraint or your character dies. I strongly feel the puzzles were also very symmetric. Meaning that once one person figured out their side, they could just tell their partner exactly what to do to solve it. It took away the magic you get when both you and your partners problem solving skills and teamwork are what complete the puzzle. All in all I can say that you may have more fun with the previous games than this one.

Once again, the devs busted through the ceiling with their newest addition to the series. Not only is this one twice as long as the previous one, it also has harder,  more thought provoking puzzles that are also more fun in my opinion compared to other games. My partner and I enjoyed every second of playing this one and we plan on returning to it soon to nab the other half of the achievements. Something else that I always commend devs for is the ability to make a co-op game that is wholly different from both perspectives so that the players have the urge to go back and replay it from the other side of things. I can also appreciate that while there are quite a few achievements, almost all of them just have to do with playing through the game from both sides and aren't reliant on something specific that makes you want to pull your hair out. Overall, their best game yet and as I stated in the review for the game prior to this one, I hope they either continue on with this series or start another one as they know exactly how to make solid co-op games. Love it!

I played through all four games recently, and this was by far the best. It had a large variety of interesting puzzles, and the use of asymmetrical information in the puzzles made for a fun challenge in communication. 

There is one puzzle towards the end of the game which outshines the rest though.

*** LIGHT SPOILERS AHEAD ***









In this puzzle, one player is tasked with talking with a kraken in a language they don't understand. Their job is to listen to the often-unpronounceable sounds the kraken is making, then repeat them back to their partner, who then flips through an audio phrasebook to attempt to translate those sounds into words. Once you understand the kraken's speech, you then find the appropriate response and translate it back into symbols to continue the conversation. The players have choice in how they respond, but disappointingly there is no dialogue tree to explore. This is still a puzzle game, so each of the kraken's prompts has one correct answer.

The combination of the endearing but terrifying design of the kraken and the hilarity of trying to reproduce the kraken's gurgles, hisses, and songs made this the most memorable puzzle of the entire series. For a moment the game seemed more like a first-contact simulator a la [i]Arrival[/i] than an escape room, and I couldn't be happier for it.

On the series first:
These games are great to play with someone you know. My husband and I have played all of them. If you're a fan of puzzles, escape rooms, etc. then you'll love these. Way cheaper than an in-person escape room! This will test your communication skills as you often have to describe something that only you can see but your partner can't.

On this game:

This one was by far the best! It's the most expensive, but the puzzles are better (more challenging, more interesting) and it's the longest so far. It took us 13 hours to complete. There's a good variety of puzzles - ones where you're together in the same space, ones were you're separated, ones that are mechanically easy but are difficult because of a time limit, others that are difficult to figure out but have no time limit. There's also a good mix of using sight and sound puzzles. I think this has the most variety of puzzles of them all. Definitely worth the price!!

Some puzzles really take some thinking. I do not recommend looking anything up because it will take away from the experience. There is some "jump scare" scenarios, which I feel is important just in case that is not your thing, but will not spoil when and where. The graphics can possible cause "dizziness" so it is far to warn you about that as well. Over all the scenarios are trippy and really fun. I recommend it. I have played and completed both of the previous We Were Here titles, but I could not bring myself to finish this one.

Compared to the more intuitive puzzles of past entries, We Were Here Forever's are often frustrating and boring. Not because the puzzles are comparatively difficult, but rather they have been drained of creativity and intuitiveness in favour of scale. The 'puzzles' are padded out with obnoxiously long walking sections where the 'puzzle' revolves around both partners reading nonsensical information off of posters back and forth to advance.
That said, there are some puzzles that are well done in between the garbage. The jester's realm was immaculate (and the scale that I previously complained about complimented it well). The intro, owl head, and the tile walk/matching puzzles were also very good. 
Perhaps I was just in a mid-game slump and the latter part of the game rises in quality once more, but I don't know and refuse to waste more time trying to decipher random garbage written on the walls to find out.

This is one of my top favorite games and in my opinion the best in the series. The puzzles were cooperative and fun (unlike some puzzle games where it feels like one person has to do all the work and the other person just inputs the answer, and then repeats). The different areas were so vibrant and I loved the style and graphics of the game. This game lasted me multiple hours of playtime not including previous series. The best puzzle game I have ever played. Also has the best voice acting I've heard in a long time (Thank you Jester!!!) and some AMAZING cutscenes - like come on, the huge jester reaching out with his hand in the hexagon puzzle, the cutscene where the puppet cuts the name and the detail of the puppet throwing the paper to the hand of the survivor (that I completely missed the first time around) , and the final cutscene? I have Jester's final lines memorized because it was THAT impactful. THANK YOU SO MUCH TOTAL MAYHEM GAMES, as an aspiring game developer this game was a masterpiece!

This game series came out of nowhere to me and its so good, its the first game series i wanted to write a review for and give input. The first three games are masterpieces. The concept of having an asymmetrical gameplay with your friend where both parties have to articulate an abstract object or pictures in order to logically solve the puzzle is genius and i loved every minute of it. The first three games all built on top of eachother and executed flawlessly with very little bugs or glitches. We Were Here Forever however felt watered down. It kept the basic concept but drifted away from the center concept of communicating abstract visual cues in order to appeal to a wider audience. Which i understand and do not blame. Still a fantastic game but the first three games were masterpieces. Dont get me wrong, i would play this entire series again.

This entire series is definitely one of my favorites! This one was kind of a step back from the other 3, however, I understand that expanding to consoles requires broadening of the player base so in order to make it worth it, it needed to be slightly watered down. I think that allowing both players to see what was going on with each side was the major drawback, the other games made you describe every detail in depth in order to progress whereas this game most of the puzzles allowed the players to switch positions and figure out the solutions a lot easier. I will gladly replay all of the We Were Here games though.

I absolutely love this series. Each game gets better and better and the puzzles actually get you thinking. Highly recommend playing this with your friends. Looking forward to more games in this series. 11/11

The We Were Here series has been the gold standard in coop puzzle solving. I have thoroughly enjoyed and and every game. The puzzles rarely overstayed their welcome, and were both ambiguous along with enough clues to be able piece everything together. It always required two people to solve every puzzle to both communicate information, and to brainstorm the solution.

However, you will not find the same experience in We Were Here Forever. I refused to believe the other reviews in their experiences, but found myself living through the same hell as them. The game starts off strong, but midway through the first chapter you will experience the first puzzle ("The Trail" - ball and chain maze) that sets the low standard for the puzzles that are ahead. You will notice that the puzzle only requires one player to solve something and the other player to become "the slave" who will become the player who simply follows commands. This practice of having one player with all the information and the other player who cannot participate in the discussion will continue all the way to the end of the game.

There are just too many puzzles that follow this tread, "The Trial", "The Pledge", "The Resistance", "The Hymn", "The Seal", "The Lost", "The Reflections", and "The Expedition". That is a total of 8/18 (44%) puzzles that the second player has come down to playing "Simon Says". Only one player has the clues, the other follows the directions. There is nothing that other player can do - they literally have no clues or context of the puzzles.

Moreover, to make matters worse, there are several puzzles that are far too obtuse (specifically "The Pledge" and "The Resistance"). These puzzles give too much information all at once that lead me and my partner confused on what to do. We thought we used the information given to us in the first puzzle were done and were to be disregarded only to discover 2 hours later that only half the information in the first puzzle were used and the other half were used for the 2nd portion. In other words, we accidently solved the first puzzle. All the while, there was no need for this puzzle to be a coop puzzle at all, as both players had access to the same information and manipulated the same exact parts. This was the second puzzle we brute forced - something that you could never do in the previous games, which unfortunately could be used in many puzzles in the game (the first puzzle being "The Pledge" - which it's clues were too vague).

Unfortunately, the icing on the cake is the long wait times for absolutely no reason. There are several instances where the players are traveling on a lift, gondola, a submarine dome, or other modes of transportation that last to upwards of 2 minutes where absolutely NOTHING occurs. You may be able to excuse this if the game was loading, but no... it sometimes would actually be continued into a loading screen! It added nothing and only distracted from the gameplay. 

During one of the lift instances, there was a glitch (this is a more than half a year after release) that caused me and my partner to skip an ENTIRE CHAPTER. Many other reviews at the time of release suggested similar glitches and we found ourselves in the same boat and that the glitches haven't been fixed. Luckily, my friend and I decided to replay the game starting at that chapter so we could see it's content.

And fortunately, that was the best chapter in the game. Inside of that chapter, every puzzle resembled what this series was known for - communication, beautiful visuals, interesting puzzles, puzzles that fit and add to the lore (rather than forcing it in cutscenes), and most importantly, puzzles that required both players to communicate information in order to solve the puzzle.

If you have played every We Were Here game, this is one to skip. This game is 3 times as long in length as the others, is riddled with bugs, took a different approach in it's puzzles that don't resemble the series that leave one player to become "a slave", and it tops it all off with a story that is easily forgettable and only gets in that introduce long sequences of waiting.

I admire the devs for trying to make a larger product and aim higher, but it came at the cost of brining us an unpolished product, which is not the standard that they have become known for with the past games in the franchise.

Compared to the other installments in the series, this one felt like a step back in terms of puzzles. Many of the puzzles felt like I was solving the puzzle by myself or waiting for my friend to solve them because only one of us had access to the puzzle. Whoever wasn't solving the puzzle was essentially a pawn to the other player who guided to finish the puzzle. The real exception to this was the Nautilus section, which had excellent puzzle design that reminded me why I love this series. I would not recommend buying this game unless it was on sale and you understand going in that this game is weaker in puzzle design than the rest of the series.

A great game to play with a friend, some puzzles easier than others. One thing to note is that few if any of the puzzles are explained in any way, which means that you may have to figure out [i]how[/i] to even [i]do[/i] the puzzles - I don't mean how to solve the puzzle once you understand the mechanics, I mean understanding the mechanics in the first place - What to click, what's important etc.
Some of the achievements are dependant on which "side" of the puzzle you do, so you might get some more replay value of playing both sides

One thing I didn't like was the use of a voice server as opposed to peer-to-peer voice. It's understandable that the developers have chosen this path considering possible hassle or issues with port-forwarding and such, but I'd much prefer at least having the [i]option[/i] to [b]NOT[/b] sign the EULA for the voice service. It states that "if you choose to use voice communications" or something to that effect, which is ridiculous as it's built in, a core part of the game [i]and[/i] there's no option to disable it. If you're very privacy-minded, you might want to simply use discord or steam voice instead and use windows 10 settings to not allow the game access to your mic.

With that being said, very much a great puzzle game, gave me and my buddy about 10-12 hours of enjoyment, confusion, a-ha (and sometimes "ah man I'm an idiot") moments. Some frustration aswell, but not really from anything the game did wrong aside from the above criticism. Definitively worth the price of 200 NOK (approx €20) I paid for it, when it was on a 20% sale. Probably worth it up to €25 as well, as one of the [i]very few[/i] true co-op games made recently.

There’s only a few coop puzzle games with over 10hrs out there(we spent 15hrs to beat this…) So that’s a plus for anyone looking for a coop game with good length.

Many puzzles will require some good effort to solve. If you are looking for a casual chill experience without readying your pen and paper at sides, this is probably not for you.

With that said, I will say some of the puzzles are not very intuitive or rather the information is just unclear and confusing. (Namely the church area with the seating puzzles and the Kraken puzzle….the sound Kraken make is basically impossible to communicate clearly…)

Though it has good parts as well. 
The diving part and the Alchemy part (Overcook part) are very fun, had a blast.

Overall good game to play with your friend, but being stuck on some puzzles for hours only because of confusing information is pure suffering…..

The worst one of the series IMO. Despite being released quite a while ago there are plenty of issues and it's not very well optimized even for mid-tier rigs that would have no problem running any of the previous games. This is also the first Windows-only game in the series, which is a shame. 

The game itself, if you can get past the bugs, is quite mediocre. The puzzles are inferior to the ones in the previous games and very poorly balanced - it's usually one person doing everything while another one is left to wander aimlessly between remote locations just to keep them busy. You have to carry stuff for long distances too which prevents you from running and your partner just has to wait for you which is no fun at all.

I hope they go smaller next time and replicate some of the fun of the first two games.

I've enjoyed their previous games a whole lot. You can play the first one for free, but this one was on a whole 'nother level. They have really figured out how to make really satisfying and diverse puzzles that require both people to participate - Both players feel heavily involved, and neither player is the only one solving puzzles; it's a group effort. Despite this, none of the puzzles feel obtuse or too difficult, and never leave you asking, "How should I have known that" or yelling at your partner.

In addition to that the world is a lot bigger and prettier than I expected(or in their previous games), and it is a lot of fun to explore as well. Highly recommend this one, if you enjoy co-op puzzle games.

The best of the series so far, without a doubt. Feels like a full game, moreso than any of the other games.
No puzzles were annoying (like some have been in previous games) and there's lots of puzzle variety (asymmetric communication, pattern matching, time based puzzles, etc). Much longer than the other games, and it's for the better!

I had a lot of fun playing We Were Here Forever (despite getting frustrated when my sister and I got stuck on some puzzles but I feel like that is to be expected for an escape room game). The gameplay makes you think and work with your partner, the story is engaging, and the game generally looks beautiful. 

However, one of the gripes I have for this game was the ending. The ending was EXTREMELY disappointing. After everything you and your partner go through, and then...that happens. I won't exactly spoil it, but I felt like it was extremely disheartening, especially after all of that work that you had to go through, just to essentially lose. I am curious if there will be another game that covers what happens after this ending, but I do not know if this is the last game of the We Where Here series or not. Another gripe I have was the gravestones puzzle. The hints my sister got were very confusing, and eventually I just randomly guessed which grave in each mini graveyard was correct until I got it right. Other than that, I thoroughly enjoyed the game and despite the ending, I would recommend the game for the journey alone.

It's a great co-op game and series. Totally worth your time. We Were Here Forever is the 4th game in the series, but you can play it without ever playing previous ones (I won't recommend though if you're interested in lore). 

Game has asymmetric gameplay, puzzles are based on communication between you and your co-op partner as each of you has only half of the puzzle. You need to let other know what you see and can do to figure out the task and help each other to finish it. And believe me, devs tried to make puzzles as challenging as it was possible.

Compared to other co-op room escape games this one focuses more on your coordination. Puzzle itself could be not that hard, but explaining to each other what you see and combine knowledge to solve the problem is a tricky part.

Compared to previous games in this series puzzles become noticably harder and require more talking to explain and making sense out of hints. Game also lost a lot of replayability as more puzzles have scripted solutions instead of being randomized. Appearance of several timed puzzles which require coordinated timed input from you both also added to the level of the challenge. But everything was possible to figure out, so we greatly enjoyed this ecperience.

Technically game is also better optimized than previous ones in the series. There were no crushes this time and "surprize" levels where fps dropped to zero because of additional details on it.

Can't wait for the next game!^.~

I just realized I might be a little bit of a sadist because this is my favorite game! Yes we had fun, we lost our freaking minds, and it was an absolute treat for the co-op and puzzle lovers like myself, who have played the previous games of the series! 

The game had a HELL of an improvement. The visuals, models and environment had the biggest glow up of the century, and I dare to say specific locations are really breathtaking! The soundtrack was really good, I have two favorites; the voice acting and animation is all spot on, making the cutscenes and game very immersive with the classic We Were Here feel. They did a great job tying up loose ends from the previous games too (for the lore lovers). Finally the secondary characters have a face to be associated with, and they went all out with the antagonist and player models and animations, we can even see our own feet.

I think this is THE must-play of the series, as overall it is the coup the grâce (really wish they'd continue) and THE LONGEST yet, so obviously worth the money. The rest really depends on you, the synergy between you and your partner! Try to not lose your minds much!

GOOD LUCK, and remember that We Were Here! 🏰🃏👑

We Were Here Forever is the refined crescendo the series has been building up to in past iterations. And one of my favourites.
The previous games established much of the basic premise and puzzle structures, but were clearly still unrefined and had a lot of things that detracted from the nicer aspects. But We Were Here Forever fixes all of those detractors and more.

This review will not contain spoilers, but if you want a TL'DR; the game is superb and an example of co-operative puzzle games and instantly one of my favorite puzzle games period.
Regardless, time to get into the nitty gritty.

---- Visual & Audio ----

Put simply, I love the design of this world. The art style and level design are not only incredibly beautiful, but incredibly fitting thematically. The world feels simultaneously magical like straight out of a fairytale, but also still makes total sense to navigate and explore. The detail in designs is fantastic and the variety of areas and environments is diverse and at times breathtaking. Visually the game is a master class of using effective design decisions to showcase the story and the world as you navigate it.

Levels are unique and feel refreshing to look at, while the puzzles are integrated organically into the surrounding world. With lighting and use of props the world highlights what it needs to to make navigating intuitive, and also does an effective job of conveying emotion and tension.

The sound design is clear and beautiful. The music of the game is gorgeous, and the voice acting of the characters has no right being as good as it is for a puzzle game. The Jester's voice actor in particular brought their absolute best, and I was continually impressed by their performance in various parts of the game.
If it were up to me, they'd get an award.

The use of cutscenes and animations, while subdued and not excessive, is very effective. And the visual and audio design of those cutscenes is fantastic and truly left an impression on me.
All of this combines into a style that I truly think will stand the test of time and will still inspire joy in people years from now. And all the kudos to the artists and sound designers, as well as the voice cast.

---- Puzzles ----

The puzzles are plentiful, and yet incredibly unique. The puzzles didn't repeat themselves past their welcome, and were always intuitively designed to fit into the environment and to be easily approachable and understandable. As well as requiring you to move around whilst doing so, making it feel more kinetic and memorable than simply staring at a piece of paper or a machine. Offering a nice variety of both difficulty and type of puzzle means that you're not likely to get bored at lack of new things to try or puzzles to figure out. So if you want to be truly tested on various kinds of puzzles, this is the game for you without a doubt.

The communication between co-op partners is intuitive and encourages you to learn to communicate more effectively. The puzzles are designed in a way where you can describe the situation very well once you wrap your head around it, and all it often takes is for your partner to say one thing to set the light bulbs off in your head. In addition to this many levels involve changing around the perspective between you and your partner, as well as converging your paths only to separate them again.
This all makes for a far more organic feeling and free environment, making it feel less constrained and boxed in than previous We Were Here titles, or many other puzzle games.

Communication in-game is done through a simple but effective voice chat system incorporating a walkie talkie. (Though granted I played it with a friend over Discord, but it's nice to have for those that don't have that option or want the extra immersion.) Communication is key, and this is a good way to practice how well you and a friend can sync up and learn to convey information.

The puzzles never got on my nerves, though you might of course be different in this regard, but I was simply enjoying my time far too much. And overall the puzzles are fantastic and deal with so many unique concepts and gameplay methods that I can't help but applaud the developers.

---- Gameplay ----

Playing the game is incredibly intuitive, navigating is easy and straightforward and the game does a fantastic job of introducing the environments and puzzles to you. The tutorial the game begins with is very effective at conveying all the basic skills you'll need to get started, and once the game proper begins it's a steady curve of improvement and challenge from one location to the next.

The gameplay is solid and functions as expected with the exception of a few slight bugs here and there, but nothing game breaking as far as I or my friend experienced. The controls are responsive and the way you interact with the environment or the puzzles are all simple to grasp on a technical level. The levels are designed in a way to make them quite easy to wrap your head around and figure out where everything is, with clever uses of memorable landmarks as well as good use of lines of sight.

This also extends to your partner, and locating each other is usually not too difficult. And if you have trouble figuring out where you are, just describe what you see and turn on your torch and finding each other is quick and easy. The co-op aspect of gameplay works without issues and I encountered no problems that prevented us from progressing during the entire duration of the game. Connection seems a non-issue (though that's to be expected) with the only slight desync happening for some animations.

Overall the game is very accessible even if you're fairly new to first person games, and wrapping your head around the ordeal won't take too long to figure out.

---- Technicals ----

The game runs flawlessly, with one notable exception. Transitions from level to level often cause lag and choppiness for some amount of time as the levels load in. However, it subsides quickly and once the game has finished loading everything in, all problems are gone. Performance is rock solid beyond these load moments, and I had no issues playing the game what-so-ever.

The controls are responsive and the menus are a vast improvement over previous titles in the series, and the UI is well designed and clean allowing you to take everything in properly.
A lot of people kept referring to a bugged puzzle in the graveyard section of the game, but we encountered no bug in said area. Not sure if we simply got lucky, or if there's something else going on. But overall there was no real hindrance at any point to our playthrough or enjoyment, and overall the experience was pretty flawless.

---- Closing thoughts ----

Ultimately it comes down to one simple fact. Do you like puzzles?
If you do, then this game is undoubtedly worth checking out, and a great way to spend some quality time with a friend. However it is worth noting that as a co-op only puzzle game.
I would recommend either bringing along a friend, or finding suitable players on the community page or through other means. Since it definitely is a commitment, albeit a fairly small one.

Overall We Were Here Forever is one of my favorite puzzle games of all time. Up there with games like Portal or Talos Principle. A unique and refreshing experience with beautiful designs throughout, a fantastic style, absolutely stellar voice acting and audio, and some of the most breathtaking and varied environments.

The developers have refined their talent, and have put out a game that truly is one of the best of its kind.
And the amount of love and effort put into every corner of the game is undeniable.

The name of the game is incorrect, since we were only there for a couple evenings. But the game certainly makes a compelling case for why I would want to be there forever. Since it was truly a wonderful experience made with care and love.

And I'd be lying if I said I didn't want much, much more of it.

We Were Here Forever is a great 2 player online co-op puzzle game that relies on communicating with your partner.
The storytelling has been improved with cinematics. While there is an overarching story, this game works as a standalone because the focus on the story is about setting the mood for the next puzzle.
The idea of puzzles that have no given rules, until you figure them out, and the necessity for describing sights and sounds that the other player may not hear or see strengthens bonds and gives a good laugh. We Were Here Forever allows the player to get hints.
I really like the maps and feel of it. The story kinda fun. 
Overall, this is a fun time, it's more and better!

Having enjoyed the previous three 'We Were Here' games with a friend, we were very eager to play this latest instalment and it didn't let us down.

You can tell that the creators/developers have really listened to the fans of the series and have refined the game-play each time. It's moved away from the earlier frustrating puzzle types but kept up the level of challenge. They're more skill-based and logical now than simply stumbling alone trying to work out some vague or arbitrary associations. More thinking and execution, instead of abstract solutions. In this, paying attention to detail and your surroundings will serve you all the better, not to mention honing your communication skills (knowing the way your partner thinks definitely helps!). And as a result, each section is all the more rewarding when you complete them.

We were thoroughly entertained with We Were Here Forever and felt a sense of real achievement that you don't get often with games nowadays. We'll be here for the next one if they make it!

An absolutely stellar game. Forever continues the trend of improving with each entry into the We Were Here series: higher production values, even more intriguing and complicated puzzles, and easily the longest game in the series yet. The devs have shown their competency again and again, not only delivering a quality product but also acutely listening to their fans and beta testers, which is reflected in the changes made to the final product

For what may be the finale, Total Mayhem Games sends the series out with a bang, especially with the absolute truckload of easter eggs and callbacks to the previous titles. Anyone who's liked We Were Here so far should pick this up immediately, and anyone just now looking to get into the series should know that it's a treat from beginning to end.

Plus it's only $18, not even $20. The absolute madmen developed their biggest game yet, alongside the absolutely delightful and free to watch Chronicles of Castle Rock promotional series, and then put it out for less than $20.

[h1]This new We Were Here game is the best one yet ! [/h1]

If you’re not familiar with the We Were Here games, they are coop puzzle games, think escape rooms but in video game form. 

The graphics have improved, I think they are way better in this title, a lot of attention seems to have gone to the atmosphere, lighting and details.

One of the biggest change is that roles are not assigned from start to finish anymore ! Anytime a puzzle splits you up, it could have been either one of us on each side. And moreover many puzzles allow you to just switch with your partner mid-puzzle. I also like the fact that we spend less time without seeing each other at all even if separated by a barrier of some kind.

I also would say the quality has improved overall, we encountered less bugs than in previous titles.

We still chose to use discord rather than the in-game voice, but at this point we’re just too used to not using the talkies.

While the story of the game is better than the previous ones, I didn’t like the ending of that one. [spoiler]It felt rushed and gimmicky.[/spoiler]

This game is again a bit longer than its predecessor, sadly that maybe because of the “walking simulator” parts of it where you just need to get from point A to B with nothing much happening.

Even if it can still be improved on, I want to reiterate this is the best We Were Here game to this day and I hope Total Mayhem Games keeps making more !
The best coop-game 10/10! Also the colors are very nice!

Excellent game.  Even better than the last one.  We plan to play it again with the roles reversed.

The puzzles were a bit on the easy side for us but we've beat all the other We Were Here games (twice each) as well as other puzzle/escape room games.  They train you well for the puzzles here.

I agree with the criticism that the game makes you wait several times when it could just fade out and take you to your destination.  The ski lifts were notorious for this but once or twice you're running down a long path unnecessarily.

I hope there is another game like this already in the works.

This is pretty great. A co-op puzzle game that builds upon the previous games in a technical sense to make We Were Here's grandest game yet. The environments all look really nice and the atmosphere the game makes is very sort of Halloween-y, NOT horror, but kind of tongue in cheek spooky stuff. A bit like the haunted house at your favourite theme park I imagine. The game is fully voiced and the voice acting is excellent.

Pretty much all the puzzles heavily involve both players and you'll need to communicate a lot in order to solve them and find your way out. Most are very satisfying to solve but there was one puzzle sort of early on involving see-saws making bridges with a player on each side and we didn't really like that one due to poor visibility. But all the rest are excellent and rather different to each other too, there is a good puzzle variety here.

[h1] If you like coop, try this game[/h1]

This is a very good coop game. It's not about who takes the axe and who casts the spell to proceed. You have to solve puzzles and riddles together. Switch, maze, music, logic, ..... riddles/puzzels. Sometimes in the same room or while being separated. Talking to each other is crucial to be successful. So a microphone is mandatory.  The graphics are good but not high end. Overall the atmosphere the game creates is dense and fits well to the castle/trap/escape - setting.
Played it with a friend and honestly we've gotten so much closer as a result, tremendously fun experience if you have someone else to dedicate the time to it.
The story is not the reason you should play this game, most of the puzzle were good, but some felt very unrewarding, all in all I'd say it's worth a play, but not because of the story.

I had my doubts initially, but I'm glad to say this is one of the best async co-op puzzle games out there, as far as I'm concerned. A big relief, considering the boring, confusing disappointment that was WWH: Together.

The puzzles in this game ranged from pretty simple to pretty tough, but they were almost never unintuitive. Perhaps their greatest aspect is how well of a job they do dividing tasks between players. Neither party is ever sat doing nothing more than relaying info/flipping switches on command, which is what tends to really make or break a game of this type.

Besides that, the game looks pretty good. The performance overall wasn't great however, even after reducing the game's graphical fidelity. It struggled to keep a steady 60 in the outdoor areas. That, and not every puzzle was amazing, but in a game with so many of them they can't all be winners.

Overall a great experience that I'd highly recommend to anyone who likes a good co-op puzzle game.

[h1][url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=17KmNrG9pE4]The TL;DR to this game.[/url][/h1]

Easily the worst in the series. From bugs to stuttering, to a convoluted storyline that tries a lot but does nothing.
[hr][/hr]

[h1]The bugs[/h1]

I like puzzles. [i]I also like playing them in a somewhat steady frame rate[/i]. Each time elements of the game world load in, there is this horrendous frame rate drop that turns your game into a slideshow. I am not one to complain about frame rate drops here and there but f*ck me, the game sh*t the bed so many times I might've missed half of the f*cking cutscenes.

Some game elements were also f*cked. Around mid-game, for some reason, during [spoiler]the boulder pushing thing, after the thing was done,[/spoiler] I remained locked.... like actually locked, my character wouldn't do jack sh*t, I couldn't move, I couldn't look around, all I could do was get f*cked and spam the walkie-talkie. I had to restart the session. During the [spoiler]potion making thing, for the forgery, for some reason, I wouldn't get the prompt to pick up the star-square-circle things after I would craft something. At first, I thought I was just being ret*rded because I didn't have a bowl to put them in but no, it would bug out and the only fix I could find was to spam sh*t like I was weapon spamming or pick another empty bowl[/spoiler].

[h1]The puzzles[/h1]

Why? Why would you put some of the most autistic puzzles during the first 3/4 of the game, just to end it with the [spoiler]Candy Crush equivalent of the Titanic[/spoiler]? When I say autistic, I don't mean neither good nor bad, I just mean.... weird. Don't get me wrong, they were good but I feel like this game became something far more complex than it should've been. From [spoiler]translating whatever a f*cking kraken looking a*s squid was saying[/spoiler] to [spoiler]piecing togheter a f*cking ray gun like it's a zombies map from Black Ops[/spoiler] it just felt weird man.... It's just not enjoyable when you tease me with the [spoiler]jester box platforming thing with teleporting doors[/spoiler] just to castrate me with the f*cking cringe a*s [spoiler]sitting of the puppets puzzle where you put 100 f*cking clues for 100 f*cking riddles, all at once, so good luck, f*cker, in figuring out who the f*ck asked[/spoiler]. Quantity over quality is all I'm saying.

[h1]The story[/h1]

A Brazzers show with Johnny Bravo, Johnny Sins and the newly announced Scooby Doo: The ballad of gay Velma would've been far more enjoyable than that God awful [spoiler]Titanic welcome to the Fortnite metaverse rip off[/spoiler].

It's just painful to watch a story devolve so dramatically, from intriguing to confusing to "what the f*ck is that DiCaprio?". The ending was so unnecessary man, atleast give us an alternative, some secret ending, something that makes sense. [spoiler]And what happened to the king? Where the f*ck did the jester go? Why can't we obey him? Why is the king such a little b*tch?[/spoiler] Why is there so much downtime? Why do I have to [spoiler]ride that f*cking platform back and forth just to get TWO CUTSCENES IN HALF A FRAME PER HOUR out of.... 6 trips?[/spoiler] Why is the [spoiler]chairlift ride so... meaningless? You make me spend so much time for a wannabe cutscene to see some fog and some mountains, just to end the game on a rushed Titanic soap opera[/spoiler].

So much potential wasted. From the [spoiler]mysterious jester[/spoiler] to the [spoiler]good king gone mad[/spoiler] to the [spoiler]plot by the "families"[/spoiler] just to get an ending that.. just doesn't fit.

[h1]The goods?[/h1]

The game makes huge improvements on the foundation set by previous titles. Puzzles got more complex (in my opinion, this damages the game more than it does good), visuals are gorgeous, controls feel sturdy. It really pains me to give it a negative review but I had to go through a roller coaster of emotions just to be greeted by f*cking [spoiler]Leonardo f*cking DiCaprio. You're laughing but that's what it is. It's literally the f*cking scene from Titanic, except Rose is replaced by my f*cking buddy who doesn't say jack sh*t except "farewell" as he drowns like a f*cking c*nt and I keep saying "nah, it can't be. It can't f*cking end like this, that's cringe" but the game actually ends, credits roll and all you have to say is "Jesus f*cking Christ" because the f*cking boat that could've saved you both just keeps blasting that f*cking horn, almost mocking you for thinking the game would end well[/spoiler].

[h1]The other "We were here" games are good though. Please make another one, this can't be the last one, it's just cringe[/h1]

Played it with a friend who's also played the other games in the series, and it still took us 15 hours to complete the full game. Absolutely worth the price several times over.

Legitimately the single best puzzle game I have ever played. An extraordinary success in every field that the game was making an attempt in and then some. Phenomenal puzzle design, a gripping and fun narrative, and legitimately impressive spectacle make this game, and by extension its predecessors, an automatic recommendation for anyone interested in co-op puzzle games. All of this on top of really intuitive mechanics, easy readability on color based puzzles (even for colorblind people due to every color based puzzle automatically having a shape assigned to each color), and the most nonbinary protagonists I've ever seen in a game. This is the only game I have ever written a review for on steam and I am only doing it because I feel so incredibly compelled to do so by the sheer incredible quality of the game. Borderline Flawless 10/10

[h1] Overall: 8/10 [/h1] A complex and surprisingly emotional game to play. They kept the story relatively simple, not trying to set up some instant classic or anything, but keeping it simple and doing it right.
A game you should play with someone close to you to really feel what it has to offer.
[h1] Graphics: 8/10 [/h1] I personally REALLY like the look they have and I'm happy they kept it for all of the games.
[h1] Performance: 7/10 [/h1] Not as good as I'd hoped for the look it has, but it ran well enough.
[h1]Story&Characters: 7.5/10 [/h1] For a puzzle game, it managed to put the two games together really well with a cool plot and some neat lore.
[h1] Movement/Combat: 7/10 [/h1] Kinda sluggish in some ways, but it's not the focus of the game anyway.
[h1] Multiplayer: 9/10 [/h1] Nothing's perfect, but damn, this game was exceptional with its multiplayer game-play.

We were here forever co-op gaming pushed to perfection. Is it a bit lacking in some areas, of course, I would have appreciated a more compelling story and villain, but that would only be the cherry on top of some incredibly enjoyable cooperative puzzles. The very basics of the We Were Here series is that one person explains what to do while the other does the things, and this formula is twisted and/or pushed to its limits to make creativity rich puzzles that are so diverse I can barely tell they come from the same series let alone game. Highly recommend playing, especially with a close friend or partner.

My husband and I love this game and all of the previous ones!

 If you are looking for cooperative game play with a spouse, partner or friend... look no further because this is the one! Ultimately, this game is all about working with your partner to solve puzzles and riddles.  You have to rely on communication to advance through the game. Your characters are often separated, and naturally, information that you need will be accessible by your partner while the information they need is accessible by you. 

You will need a microphone to relay the information back and forth to each other, or if you are in the same room you can talk to one another. Try not to look at their screen though, that's cheating! ;-)

Some of the puzzles and riddles are hard to get through, but be persistent! The developers have made the game pretty straight forward... meaning, you can't progress without doing things in order. If you're stuck, retrace your steps and see what things in your surroundings you can manipulate or interact with. That will often jump start something and get you on the right path to solving the puzzle. 

Overall, be patient, talk clearly, be kind to your partner! and enjoy this amazing game and franchise. 

Best of luck!

Towards the end of the game were very creative and enjoyable puzzles. The ambience, environment, mood of the game, and the ways it forced me and my friend to tackle its problems were a blast. Would highly recommend for anyone. I know that for years to come, whenever I think of We Were Here Forever. I'll be reminded of how much fun I had, and the great memories me and my friend made playing together.

at least half of my 8 hours playing this game was sitting through boring cutscenes and gondola rides. one gondola you have to ride back and forth SIX TIMES. i just wanted to puzzle

You will be here forever. You will enjoy the gondola ride. You will be happy about the puzzle design. You will carry the chunks of random crap for way too long and you will like it. You will especially enjoy the gondola ride the fifth time.

Escape or die trying.

Story:

Like the previous three We Were Here games, it puts you into the shoes of two explorers who awaken deep underneath Castle Rock. Suddenly you're freed from your cells and this begins your journey to escape, but you find that the stakes are much higher than ever before.

Even though there's much more story this time around, it again takes a backseat to the puzzles and such. However this time around a lot of the puzzles have lore written into the puzzles, so while you're solving the complex enigmas thrown at you, it tells you the story of the castle and what led to it's downfall. However a good chunk of it is information that we learned from the previous games, although with added explanations. 

The only major negative is that the story ends on a very sequel bait ending which feels incredibly abrupt considering the journey to the end is much longer this time around. The fact that we're likely pretty far away from the next entry, I feel like they should have went with something else.  

Graphics

From game to game the graphical leap has been impressive to say the least. What started as a simplistic looking game has now turned into a really visually stunning game. The environments you visit throughout are grander in scale and in visual fidelity.

Some of the moments you witness are actually jaw dropping and the developers have totally outdid themselves. Of course there are still a few minor issues like some textures being re-used from the previous game and some of the models looking low quality, but they are so minor they do not detract from everything else.

Audio:

Out of a game full of strengths this is probably it's biggest weakness. First of all let's start with the music. The music throughout the series has always been pretty weak for me and I'm glad to say that this one has the best soundtrack hands down. There's plenty of great new tracks that help build atmosphere, get your blood pumping etc. 

However I've noticed that quite a lot of the games sound effects and even some minor tracks have been re-used from the previous games. Again since the development team is so small, I feel like I can excuse this, but I wish that they wouldn't rely on re-used assets as much as they do. Also the tradition of so bad it's good voice acting is still here front and center.

Gameplay:

We Were Here Forever follows the same basic formula as the previous three games in the series. You and your co-op partner have walkie talkies and use them to communicate to solve increasingly difficult puzzles. So let's talk about the puzzles. 

The puzzles start off simple enough, but quickly become incredibly complex. The scope of the game is much larger in scale and because of it, the puzzles seem scarier before you comprehend everything that goes into solving it. That's not to say that they are simple, they range from simplistic, to pretty difficult. 

There's not many puzzles this time around that can cause death, but they are traded with more puzzles that take longer to complete cause they force you to walk around a large area, flipping different mechanisms. For some these puzzles might seem much more tedious than what was in the other games, purely due to the size of them, but I felt like that was one of this games strength. 

My biggest gripe with the puzzles is the a poor difficulty scale. It felt like each puzzle in the previous games gradually got harder and harder with some minor breathing room puzzles, Forever has puzzles that are incredibly difficult, followed up by incredibly easy puzzles and vice versa, however since basically all of them are incredibly fun to solve. 

Verdict:

The fourth entry in the series is by far the most complex and fun. Every game has been a vast improvement over the previous and if there is a number 5 I can't wait to see what crazy puzzles will the devs come up with next. If you want to play something with a friend and have nothing to do, you can't go wrong with these games, so go and check it out.

Final Rating:
9/10

Pros:
+ Puzzles are the best yet
+ Visuals are stunning 
+ Interesting lore 

Cons:
- Difficulty scaling is all over the place 
- Ending is sequel bait

If you liked this review please consider joining https://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog and https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews

It was much longer than the others, and i felt like me and my roommate got a lot more choices as to where we were going in the puzzle dynamic (as in the previous ones they'd have the clues and i'd be in the field so to speak) 

The puzzles in this one felt really good to solve and the logic was sound! The first game in the series where we didn't need to look at any hints or a walkthrough, which felt really nice! 

As for others saying they wish there was more tension, i honestly felt like the puzzles had enough tension and wasn't any unnecessary tension like the third game. I feel like timed puzzles are fine but too many just makes it too stressful and i honestly liked that there wasn't as many in this one 


definitely recommend! Can't say what the online experience is like with randoms, but can say this was great fun with a great friend :)

This game is absolutely wonderful ♥ It continues with the story from previous games and brings it to an epic end.. The Jester is an amazing character with a lot of depth, to me the story made perfect sense. [spoiler] I got interested in the Netherland paintings very early in the game (I think it was at the ceremony), but I didn't think it was important, it cracked me up that it actually was a little clue to the story! :D  [/spoiler] The voice acting is awesome ♥ 
What we really didn’t like were the hints.It’s like the devs didn’t really know where the players could get stuck or what could go wrong - like [spoiler] we were stuck at the ceremony and never figured it out (had to google the solution), because we misunderstood that men and women cannot sit together.  [/spoiler]
The audio is great, sounds are really good, graphics are the best from all games in this series and some of the scenes are soooo pretty ♥ Cutscenes were very well done, they were at the right places, maybe some smaller ones (like looking at each other while opening the portal (which we had to do several times) makes it unnecessarily long. There is a room for improvement when it comes to animations.
Overall we found one bug (and I am still not sure if that was a bug or if the place I needed to click is just really super small (while trying to dig at the graveyard).
Most of the puzzles were super fun (my personal favourite is the one with the Kraken ♥). It got a little repetitive when we got separated in the prison cells [spoiler] it was always that one is trying to describe a path for the other, and even though the puzzles themselves were different, the princip was always the same - one person (and it was the same one for the longest time) is creating/describing a path for the other.  [/spoiler]
This game is worth every penny, it is an epic end to the whole series and I certainly recommend anyone (who wants to play a game with a friend) to try it ♥

Me and my we were here partner have been obsessed with this series for a while now and we have both been blown away with We Were Here Forever. Trust me, it was worth the wait for release! It's puzzles are far more diverse to the others in the We Were Here series, which is always a good thing. These puzzles are creatively made to show how we go about solving and understanding them differently to our partner. It's lovely how communication is vital in puzzles to complete this game, and plays on your trust in one another.  Its visuals are stunning, storyline & lore is a strong addition and well crafted in comparison to their other games. It is a beautiful game to play and definitely my favourite puzzle game I've ever played, and even after the game has ended, it leaves you with more questions than what you began with. 

We only experienced two bugs in our entire game of playing, they were minor and did NOT affect our gameplay whatsoever. (eg, the script that was on my partners arm, and the next day it was on mine. It didn't affect the story). I have seen many reviews saying they found many bugs that did not allow them to play the game without disruption, however we found none of the sort.

This game and series, as well as it’s developers, deserve way more hype and far more popularity and this game is very cheap considering how incredible it is, for me personally I believe it should be worth much more! It is clear Total Mayhem Games has put so much effort into this game and I hope they either conclude this series or continue with the amazing work. 100% would recommend!!

I've played all the We Were Here games, and so far (haven't finished this one yet) this one is my absolute favorite. It's much longer than the others, with challenging puzzles that are challenging for their logic, not challenging because of a time limit. And the ongoing story line remains just as creepy as it's been all along. I also found that there were fewer points in this game that induced motion sickness in me than in previous titles (looking at you, maze race) which has made it a more enjoyable experience overall. It's also been easier to switch roles with your partner - there are more points of choice instead of being shunted into one role or the other for the duration. Whole-heartedly recommend!

A great addition to the We Were Here series of 2-player coop games. I recommend playing this with a friend. And I absolutely recommend to play the other games first, We Were Here, We Were Here Too, and We Were Here Together (but it is not mandatory). And We Were Here is free.

We Were Here Forever also pushes the formula a bit farther. The players will sometimes be together, and sometimes will have to separate. The very beginning is just a tutorial, But then you will have to work with a couple of fresh puzzles Some of the puzzles can be a bit tough, or a bit frustrating sometimes, but in a good way still. Sometimes, the solution is not immediately visible. This will force you to communicate and to work together.
Do you have a great friend but for some reason you don't want to be friends anymore? Well, this is the game for you!

We Were Here Forever is a cooperative adventure puzzle game for 2 players. It’s a game where you truly cooperate, not just play together with your friend and do your own thing. In order to solve the puzzles, you need to communicate and describe to each other what you see or hear to get the whole picture of the puzzle.

It’s very entertaining. All puzzles are different from each other so it never feels repetitive. This is also amazing because even though it’s already their fourth We Were Here game, they can still come up with new fresh ideas for great puzzles.

This is not a game you want to watch before playing. For the best experience I recommend going in knowing nothing about the puzzles and solutions. I also recommend starting with their first game We Were Here, which is for free and is very short. This way you will know if you like this kind of gameplay and then you can decide if you want to buy the rest or not. 

There might still be bugs in the game. We experienced one during our playthrough and honestly it was very hard to know that it’s unsolvable. We were lucky to find out before we started pulling our hair out.  

I made a short spoiler free video review of the game - StingeReview. It’s also showing the bug we encountered in case you want to check it out. It’s probably still not fixed by now. It starts at 3:33 in the video. 

https://youtu.be/NpJV1pnDQWs

100% recommended. We Were Here games are getting better with each game made and we are already looking forward to their next game!
10/10 would bang again

I'm writing this after one play-through of the game. This game had some incredible moments (all of the puzzles in the Jester chapter were incredible.) The aesthetic, the world, the story... there's a lot of great opportunity for all kinds of moments. That said, upon finishing my first play-through, I think this game was too big.

There are several moments where the momentum of the game completely halts (no spoilers):
- As you travel from location to location, you're almost always on some kind of "lift" machine, there's almost nothing to do while you're travelling and there's barely anything to look at
- Sometimes even after a minute-long hurry-up-and-wait travel sequence, the game still fades to black so it can load the next area instead of using the travel time to load the next sequence
- The frequency of slow, nothing-filled travel is frequent enough to become tedious and a drag [spoiler]especially when you're travelling to and from the church. That is so slow and there is no good reason for it. Another example would be the hot-air balloon vehicle that takes you back to the town square: the player is stuck in a chair for almost a minute while the vehicle is almost completely dark, a siren is going off, and you see vague lights outside. Why have it be that long? Why have it be that intense if really all it is is just getting back to the main area?[/spoiler]

The game had one game-breaking bug:
- Not sure if this was a technical issue on our end, but my friend and I experienced a bug in the [spoiler]Nautilus[/spoiler] section that cost us a full 45 minutes because [spoiler]the pipe junctions were bugged such that the visual orientation of the junctions didn't match to what the game engine thought they were. So we'd send air somewhere and it wouldn't go the way things looked like they did.[/spoiler] When we finally gave up and looked at a walkthrough and saw we were doing everything right, we reloaded the game and everything worked again. This may not be a developer issue, but it shook our confidence in the game from that point onwards.
- While this bug isn't game-breaking, it was very odd: In the [spoiler]alchemy section[/spoiler] there was an audio glitch where the player's voice chat became a directional audio signal. Nowhere else in the game did this happen and there was no puzzle reason for it as far as we could tell.
- This isn't really a bug per-se, but there are a lot of areas where the animations were very obviously not present. There are some times where, as the players are transported from area to area, the full animation doesn't play; instead the screen fades to black, fades up in a new area, and play continues. Some wheels that need to be turned don't have animations for the characters to place their hands on the wheels while others do.

The story and the execution of the story have some issues:
(I know, this is a puzzle game primarily, but TMG has done a great job setting up a world with lore and have done a decently good job of developing that story throughout the first 3 games. This game lacked in some areas like the others hadn't)
STORY SPOILERS:
[spoiler]
- In general, these following nit-picks can be summed up as follows: Approaching story with a "and now this happens?!" approach leads to a weak story that is obviously cobbled together to get to some puzzles. That's fine, but it's mediocre and could be an area of improvement. I'm not saying We Were Here needs to become a story-based game, but when you've taken the time and effort to develop a world with central characters, I would have liked the story to be more strong.
- The king not being able to see anything outside of his castle but also somehow being the lord of the whole domain seems inconsistent. Why give him any ability to affect the world outside of his castle if he can't see anything? Why take away his sight of the church and town so he's "forced" to send the Jester to hunt the players when he can clearly send lightning and wreak havoc on the town?
- The Jester's motivations don't line up with his actions. If the Jester hates the king and wants him destroyed, shouldn't the Jester be helping the player to open the portal at the end instead of antagonizing the player or waiting idly? It seems odd the Jester would hamper the players' progress by trapping them in his music box if he secretly wants the players to succeed. (btw, just want to add another note that the Jester's puzzles were the best in the game by FAR. Absolutely loved this section, just commenting on how this seems to go against his motivations.)
- The squid was a very odd character to through into the lore. The puzzle with the squid was very unique and super fun to work out. But this is sentient squid! That's fascinating! Why is it here? Why does it hate the king, too? The story didn't really explain this. It just kinda threw in a new character with a "and now this!" kinda attitude purely to set up some loose context for a puzzle. And that's fine... it's just also kinda lackluster and empty from a story perspective.
- The king's daughters had zero impact on anything. There was absolutely nothing the king's traitorous daughters did to affect the plot in any way and therefore they had no impact at all on the puzzles. So throwing in a detail that they sacrificed themselves to lock the king away forever didn't really seem all that important or incredible because we never learned about them, never understood why they needed to do this, etc.
- Also... where did the Jester go at the end? It was my understanding (and I could be completely mistaken) that the realm was controlled by the king, so if the king dies, the realm dies with him. But then after the final fight, there's a boat that comes and picks up the surviving player? Where did that boat come from? Is this realm bigger than we thought? Is the king not tied to the realm? Instead he's just kinda loosely tied to the area around his castle? Was the portal not to another dimension but instead a portal to another area on Earth?
[/spoiler]

Nearly all of the above culminates in the final "puzzle." This, honestly, was the most disappointing part of the game. This wasn't a puzzle, it was a linear sequence of steps with a inferred time limit on it. Nothing was happening to actually communicate a sense of urgency. The "puzzle" was just "go over here and flip this lever" then repeat like... 8 times. For the climactic puzzle where [spoiler]we're supposedly killing the king[/spoiler], this left a TON to be desired. This also wasn't nearly as fun a puzzle as literally any other puzzle in the game, so to have this be the last one was a confusing choice.

In summary, I acknowledge I've written a novel here. And I've brought up a lot of things that aren't really core to the "puzzle" element of this game. I'd like to think I'm critiquing this hard and this much because I really love this series. WWH has become one of my favorite co-op puzzle games right up there with Portal 2 and It Takes Two. I want it to be amazing and while this installment in the series was fantastic in several ways, it was equally as "un-fantastic" in several other ways.

I wish the studio well and can't wait to see the next thing they do! I just hope they either take on an equally-sized gameas WWH: Forever but take the extra time to really polish that big of a game or cut out the weak parts of the game and make a smaller, but excellently executed game.

So far the best one of the franchise. Each puzzle is unique from the others, with really intuitive ways of deducing them: always keeping a good level of difficulty without being frustrating. Some of the other entries in the franchise involved a lot of explaining minor difference between paintings and symbols, which got a little tedious, but this one has kept all of the describing and symbol recognition easy, while making the puzzles they are used in tricky. Also the most visually impressive of the franchise yet, with amazing settings, crisp colours and an impressive sense of scale. I'll be sad if this is the last one, but if they're looking to end the franchise, this will be a strong note to do it on.

We Were Here Forever is a great addition to the series, the puzzles, atmosphere and experience are all very similar to the previous games. The puzzles were challenging but not too much that you get bored, and most made sense after a few minutes. Although there were a couple puzzles were quite confusing. Even after finishing some of them we were left confused on how we just did that correctly. The atmosphere is very well crafted with fantastic sound design and music. One of the only things that I believe that the other games did differently, that added a lot to the experience was the slight static you hear when talking to your partner. I understand that better voice chat quality can be good in some cases. Me and my partner both felt that the static added a bit more to the whole feeling. But other than that its a well made game that is worth a try after you play the other games.

I would consider this a must-play for anyone who loves the co-op puzzle genre. Although, that doesn't say much on its own given the relative lack of such games. The [i]We Were Here[/i] series has quickly cemented itself as one of the premiere franchises in the genre over the last few years. Each game has built upon the last, further exploring the largely untapped designed space of co-op puzzle games. The original was essentially a prototype, with the third being closer to a full game. 

Essentially, if you liked the other games in the series, you will enjoy this one, as it evolves more of the same qualities of the previous entries. However, it is also noticeably different in some ways.

What can you expect from [i]We Were Here Forever[/i] compared to the other games in the series? The first thing you will notice is how absolutely massive the game is in scope and size compared to the previous games. This is by far the longest game in the series. It took my very experienced puzzling gamer friend and I about 11 hours to get through, and I think that's on the quicker side of things. Each puzzle is longer and has more stages. The graphics and world design are at their most beautiful. And the story is at its most developed. The amount of development time and the growth of Total Mayhem Games certainly shows in this game.

None of that necessarily makes for a good game on its own, but it'll certainly be a welcome change for fans of the series, and should be comforting to newcomers worried about getting their money's worth in playtime.

Fortunately, [i]We Were Here Forever[/i] matches its increased budget with some of the best puzzles in the series. It also has a high quantity of puzzles, which unfortunately means not every single one is a hit. While the pacing is generally good in terms of giving the players breaks between lower and higher tension puzzles, I did find the middle of the game dragging a little bit with some less intuitive puzzles. The last third of the game, however, is absolutely pristine in puzzle design and pacing. 

It should also be said that this game has some of the most unique puzzles of the series. For those wondering if the game might start feeling repetitive after playing the previous three, Total Mayhem knocks out of the park in terms of coming up with new and inventive ways to play with the mechanic of co-operative communication. The asymmetric design lends itself not only to replayability but also one-of-a-kind puzzles. Although, in its weakest puzzles, the asymmetric design can leave one player feeling less involved, but never for more than a few minutes.

Overall, this game is a smashing success and a shining culmination of the franchise. If you're a newcomer to the franchise who isn't super sure about how fun the core mechanic of the game is, then maybe start with a shorter earlier entry to the series. Otherwise, this game works as a great starting point for anyone wanting to hop into the puzzling fun.

The series as whole has been an enjoyable co-op experience, especially off the back bone of the third entry, and this final entry did not disappoint. We Were Here Forever was an incredible and immersive experience and it shows how great co-op campaigns can be. It includes fun puzzles, great atmosphere and brings the series to a satisfying conclusion. 

Overall a great co-op experience to play with your friends or significant other. I highly recommend!
