A fantastic game, and definitely the best in the series so far.

The good:
- Bold, innovative puzzles, which don't suffer from the same "slight variation on a puzzle from another game" that plagues the genre
- Provides an enjoyable sense of learning and discovery as you uncover how each puzzle works
- Similar to The Witness, We Were Here Forever often takes a similar "here's a basic puzzle, OK now that you understand how that works, here's a more complex version of the same puzzle" approach. It works just as well here as it did in The Witness.
- A large amount of content, worth the asking price. We took ~14 hours at a fairly relaxed pace
- There is a story, but not much of one. I'm listing this as a "good" point because the story really only needed to be there at all to hold the puzzles together, and it does that well.

The not-necessarily-bad-just-suggestions:
- The "only one player talking at a time" mechanic doesn't add anything to the experience except frustration. We ended up switching to Discord after one of the rooms had a bug which allowed both players to speak at the same time and we realised how much better that was. I would have a different opinion if the game did anything interesting with the mechanic (e.g. one of the players drops their walkie talkie where it is audible but inaccessible, communication becomes one way only, puzzle design allows players to come up with a way of communicating in the other direction through visible responses to interacting with puzzle elements?), but there is nothing like this.
- While most of the puzzles are quite innovative, this can be a double edged sword. For example, the way you're supposed to solve the puzzle in 
[spoiler]the Nautilus where you talk to the seamonster[/spoiler] is so difficult to do with accuracy and different from any solution in a puzzle game we'd seen before that we came up with the right approach, tried it, and then discarded it saying "no this can't possibly be it". It wasn't until half an hour later when we gave up and Googled it that we realised we had the right approach, but were just so bad at doing the thing the puzzle required that the approach seemed infeasible.
- There are multiple puzzles which will be difficult or impossible for certain classes of users. E.g. [spoiler]the Nautilus sea monster translation[/spoiler] for anyone who is hard of hearing. [spoiler]The Nautilus alchemy puzzle[/spoiler] will also be difficult for those who may not be able to perform actions quickly enough, and felt out of place given that there are no other puzzles which require such high levels of interaction in a limited time throughout the game.

This is hands down the best coop puzzle game I've played.  Puzzles were unique and interesting, and super satisfying to solve with a friend.  Our huge massive brains usually make games like this too easy but the puzzles were challenging and we both had a lot of fun.  Length felt perfect, longer than I expected but didn't drag on too long.  Only piece of advice I can give/slightly negative review: just use 3rd party chat if playing with a friend, the built in VC is a handheld radio that can only go one way at a time, it never added anything to the game (radio doesn't like cut out for certain puzzles or anything) and it just made my friend and I get annoyed with each other because we'd have to wait for the other person to finish talking or we would miss something one of us said because we were both trying to talk.  But like I said just use discord or whatever and you'll be totally fine.  Amazing game and I really hope this team put out more they seem to just keep getting better.

The only way I can describe this game is a regression.

It's not a terrible game, but it is a regression from the previous titles in nearly every way except graphically. Credit where it's due, this game is the best looking one in the series and the team clearly put a lot of effort in. The Jester area with the gravity shifted platforms was a real highlight for me.

But graphics alone does not a good game make and it seems like the team kind of lost focus of what really made the games enjoyable. (Spoilers from here on in).

The first thing my buddy and I noticed was several bugs on the main menu.

* Changing your region in the settings is basically cosmetic. Every time you restart the game it defaults you to Europe no matter what you've actually set it too.
* The Steam invite thing bugged out quite a few times and forced us to restart.

This was our first impression on the game, and this being the forth in the series, one would expect that such basic issues would have been addressed before launch. And after you get past the title screen into the game, we still ran into a bunch of issues:

* In every new area, the game chugs HARD. I'm talking 10-15fps for up to a minute or two upon entering a new area. This is strange given how much transitional space is given. You would think the game would use the downtime to load stuff, but that doesn't appear to be the case. (I'm using an SSD by the way, so it's not a slow disk).
* If one player has even a momentary internet issue, their character model either becomes invisible or just stands in one place for the other player. This happened a lot in our playthrough and since many puzzles need you to see the other person, it was a real pain.
* There are a few softlocks in the game, one of which is in the graveyard. The person below can "pickaxe" through a wall without having the pickaxe and be stuck on one side of it.

However, we can lay that all aside if the game was excellent. Bugs are one thing (and some of them may be fixed by the time you read this), but how is the game?

Unfortunately, it's just lost focus. I mentioned before that there were regressions from the previous games. Let me name a few:

* Lengthy periods of "dead air". There are several points throughout the game where you're doing nothing but walking around. Even worse, there are parts that seem to just be wasting your time. There's a ski lift that takes you to one area, and it's enormously slow for no reason. There's nothing to look at, there's nothing to do, you just wait. There's also a big lift that you have to go back and forth on four times to deliver parts for a big machine. There was some story stuff mixed in, but even so it just seemed like a huge waste of time.
* Many puzzles are very one-sided. Most of them can either be brute-forced without much effort, or otherwise solved by one person while the other just kind of goes around and does what they're told. There were some great puzzles like the aforementioned Jester area, as well as some others, but there are a lot of not great puzzles in the game. The "arena" one stands out as a particularly lame one since one player has to lug around an iron ball and just be told where to walk. 
* There are no "life-or-death" puzzles. These were always exciting to me because you have one person yelling that something is going to kill them unless they figure out the puzzle fast, and the other person standing in front of a bunch of complex machinery. 
* The final "puzzle" is a completion deflation and not worthy of the climax. You can "solve" the puzzle basically without knowing why you're doing anything. The music and scene are supposed to make it epic, but it's just not.
* Still trying to push the "lore". This is probably the most subjective part of the game, and where most people will likely disagree, but the story/lore has done nothing for me throughout the entire series, and despite the effort to make the story parts more impressive, it just falls flat. The entire story is that the Jester corrupted the king, but then we help the Jester escape? The lore was much better when it wasn't the main focus. In fact, one of the early games (the first or the second, I can't remember exactly) had a sort of light horror feel to it, and some genuinely creepy moments (putting on a play while the black figure slowly gets closer and closer). I would love to see a return to the horror-ish feel with a more subtle story, but that doesn't seem to be the direction they're going.

Overall, it's not a bad game, but it just doesn't reach the level I would expect these games to have hit by the forth iteration.

The We Were Here series relies heavily on communicating the information you have to the other, who lacks that info, to solve puzzles. We Were Here Forever... partially follows that rule? About half of the puzzles, both members share the same physical space, with very little not shared, which robs the game of the joy of having to communicate and translate information back and forth. While there are a few puzzles like that, they are not the rule, which is a shame.

Is that enough to not recommend this though? No. This is definitely the highest quality game in the series— every puzzle and area has new assets and visual spectacle far beyond its predecessors. The puzzles are more diverse than ever, for good and bad. It also has the best puzzles in the entire series, with the entire Nautilus area being the peak. Timers are largely gone, with most puzzles having a 3 strike system that means you're not just free to cheese the puzzle.

There's actually a very nice sprinkling of lore both directly and indirectly that gives the story more context, which is done very well; you'll do a puzzle on the families that created a secret rebellion to fight the king, and then later, visit their graves. It's not extremely important, but it's nice. 

There are a few bad quirks in the game, like lugging the machine pieces back up to the tower, but it was never enough to ruin the experience.

Look— the co-op puzzle scene is [i]very[/i] small, so it's nice to have something to play with a homie, no matter its strengths and weaknesses.

This game is a great addition to the series. This would be game number four. The puzzles are a lot of fun and unique enough to not really feel like a rehash of the previous games. In fact one of the most unique ones, along with humorous and difficult, is where one player, me in my game, has to mimic sounds from a creature, and the other has a list of sounds and has to pick the right one to decipher the message of the creature. And then provide the correct response. 

I have only two complaints. One is that like games 2 and 3, this doesn't support VR. I do wish it did as that was a lot of fun in the first game, which ironically is the game that is free as well. While this issue is by no means game breaking, it's more of a wish that they would further support VR. I'm sure they have good reasons for it, but still something I wish they did. 

The other is that the roles don't really seem to be unique from each other any more. It's more of who got into the cage first, or who decided to go upstairs. Otherwise the roles only seem to come into play based on loading the game. Which made for a bit of confusion when suddenly my friend and I switched places from where we left it at. 

All in all, I'd say the story is strong, the puzzles are fun and challenging, and There is likely a hidden ending that you have to do everything right/find everything, to get. 

Either way, if you love puzzle games, and working together with a friend. You will like this. Especially if you liked any of the previous installments as it maintains the same spirit of the other games.

In case the devs read this, One thing that would be really cool, not sure how feasible it would be for you, is to mimic a feature that the sequel Silent Hill games had. At least some of them, and that is to allow variable difficulty for the riddles. Which would change the riddles making them harder or easier. As well as different. You couldn't play it on easy riddles and then go to hard and expect the answer to be the same. It changed it up making it more difficult as well as different, which added additional replayability. By making the game have more puzzles, that were based on a difficulty bar. Thus if you aren't very good at puzzles you could put it on easy and still  enjoy the story of the game without cheating, looking up guides with all the answers, and feel more fulfilled knowing you solved it. And then if you wanted you could play the game again with higher difficulties instead of just playing a different role.

Played every game in the series so we were here forever... literally. First of all, this time there was more story to discover than in the first three games. You can tell they tried to not only give you the puzzles one after another but they tried to cohesively bring them together to achieve an end goal. The attention to detail was present in the visual aspects of the game (esp. in comparison to the older parts of the series) but also in the lore (even though its still confusing af). Very intense and moody atmosphere, nice music, strong voice actors. The gameplay itself (movement and interactions with each other etc.) was really smooth this time. 
Now for the main part: the puzzles. The basic principle of each puzzle stays the same of course: you try to solve something with your partner. This time they added new twists to the puzzles though, e.g. there were sound-based puzzles which not only challenged us to think differently but also resulted in very funny moments as you try to mimic the sounds. 
The only negative aspect of the game is that there is some buggy content which sometimes restricts you from solving the puzzles. After you lost all your braincells (and nerves!) trying to figure everything out and start retrying all the 'solutions' you've already tried before you finally realize the bug and eventually solve the puzzle. 
Overall we absolutely recommend this game (and the other ones in the series ofc) and want to see more of its kind.

I've played every game in this franchise, and have been looking forward to this for a year or more - and can honestly say it was well worth the wait. It has some of the most unique and ambitious puzzles out of the entire series, and was an overall treat to play through. Highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys playing through cooperative puzzle games; this franchise always does the genre justice.

Really hoping these developers continue to create these types of games, as I'd love to come back for another unique experience in the future.

Although the ending, well - wasn't ideal in my opinion.
Very good.

This is a case of trying to fit in too much and muddying it all down. I was extremely disappointed in this entry, and felt wholly drained by the time the credits rolled.

We Were Here is no longer about working together to solve puzzles and escape. The focus is now on finding more and more convoluted ways to tell a story. The focus is about creating cryptic scenarios meant to be confusing because you don't have all the information. The focus is on story elements that have been blown so far out of proportion that the gameplay, puzzle design, performance, and overall experience have been sacrificed.

The puzzles are where I'll start. WWH 1 and 2 has some fantastic puzzles that were creative and engaging, providing challenge, intrigue, and a unique cooperative experience. I fondly remember struggling, and overcoming, the lava staircase, the king's play, and the minecart elevators from the previous game. These were moments when, step by step, my friend and I worked through the task we'd been set and succeeded. But these new puzzles are sedentary, and come off as exceedingly arbitrary. You'll find yourself in a room, you'll stay in that room until the puzzle is done, and once it is done you'll pop down the lane for another puzzle, because this game series has become a puzzle fetch quest. This makes each new puzzle a chore to be crossed off, not an exciting, mysterious trap left behind in the ruins of a crumbling kingdom.

This doesn't even touch on the performance issues. Some areas are nigh unplayable, with serious frame dropping and hard stuttering. You're telling me my computer will run Elden Ring without a hitch but your rip-off Donkey Kong pirate dock level is too much? 

By the end of it, when the game had me believing that this old, decrepit kingdom with castle walls and torch sconces had working, industrial-age factories but hadn't invented a dumb waiter I could use to hand my friend, who was five feet away, a wooden bowl, I gave up. Don't buy this, even on sale.

The game is also significantly longer than the others but has less replay value due to more content being shared between players. There are a lot of locations where players can meet up and switch paths as well so it's a lot easier to miss achievements on a second go round.

The We Were Here games are a fantastic puzzle co-op series that I would recommend to any puzzle lover. It's obvious how much the developers love these games because of all the heart and soul that has been put into improving each one. We Were Here Forever is the fourth installment and by far the best for many reasons which I will detail below. 

1. Playtime: It is the longest game in the series from my partner and I's experience, as we finished our first run in approximately 9 hours. Of course playtime can vary depending on the person you're playing with and how fast the two of you figure out the puzzles, but from playing all four games with the same person, We Were Here Forever took us the longest.

2. Puzzle Quality: Each puzzle in this game was an absolute blast to figure out. I love how complex the puzzles were, and how there were often so many more layers to the solution than originally anticipated. I've always enjoyed the puzzles in this series, but in this game they were definitely a cut above the rest. I won't say any more on this for fear of spoiling, but trust me, you'll be blown away by some of their designs.

3. Graphics: The graphics in this game are the best in the series by far. This is the only one of the games that I actually took screenshots in because of how pretty some of the scenes were. Overall it looked very polished while still keeping it's original feel and style. Due to these graphical updates, the experience of the game was very enhanced.

4. Achievement Hunting: As an achievement hunter, I love the way that the We Were Here games are designed when it comes to Steam achievements. Some puzzles have completely different roles, visuals, and deduction for each person playing, so the developers split the achievements for those puzzles into two separate ones. This encourages people to replay the game to get all the achievements and see all the puzzles from both sides. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND DOING THIS FOR EACH OF THE WE WERE HERE GAMES. It's so cool to see each side of the different puzzles, and so much heart and soul was put into each one. I am glad that they did the same in this game, especially because each side of all the puzzles is a drastically unique experience I wouldn't want to miss.

Of course, as with any game, there are a few flaws that I wanted to mention in case the developers are looking for some constructive feedback:

1. Optimization: While the game has fairly simple graphics and I have a decently robust computer that does not struggle with graphically heavy games like Witcher 3, for example, the game lagged a good amount. It was usually in areas where things were loading up in the background, but the lagging was quite substantial. If the game was optimized a little better it might make the overall experience smoother.

2. The Lore: Honestly, even though I've paid attention to the lore in each of the games, by the end of the fourth game I am still extremely confused as to what is going on. There are a few details I am solid on, but most of it is pretty confusing. In saying this, I did enjoy the more story-based scenes in this game. 

In conclusion, I highly recommend the We Were Here series, especially We Were Here Forever. I'd recommend playing the other games first, in order, to get the full experience, but I just had to write a review for this game because of how much I was blown away. Kudos to the developers for making an amazing series that always has my partner and I coming back for more.

Let me start of with this:

I thoroughly enjoyed played this game with my friend, just as we enjoyed the previous games. 
However, we enjoy both the puzzle and story aspects of the games; 
If you only enjoy the puzzle component then unfortunately this is not the game for you as it is (a conclusion?) a story game more than a puzzle game (whereas the previous games were more puzzle based as the story was less of a focus).

My friend did experience some visual bugs on the rare occasion, but these were easily solved with a restart of the session. Otherwise, I encountered no bugs or performance issues.

TLDR: Play if you want the story, don't if you just want the puzzles.

The later in the game, the more puzzles are problematic. The "which puppet goes on which seat" puzzle was unsolvable with the given clues, so we consulted a walkthrough. Later, sending light rays through lenses and mirrors sounded cool on paper, but just wasn't the least bit fun. Even later, one of us walked around in an underwater maze with limited air supply, the other walked around in a maze on land, and none of us even knew what we were supposed to do.

Add to that the confusing story (are we figments of the King's imagination? Is this all a dream?) and the way-too-long non-interactive parts (sitting in a chair lift for minutes, moving through an idle monochrome hillscape, waiting to reach the destination... yeah right, that's good game design), and all I can say is: Not recommended, don't buy.

Hands down best story and co op puzzle game i've ever played to this day. The series was amazing and got better and better each game. Played multiple playthroughs to check out each side of the game. Really test out our brain with me and my friend and makes you think outside the box for a lot of it! Communication is vital in this game and sometimes timing is everything. Highly recommend this game to anyone that has a friend they play with that likes to test their brains with puzzles!

I really enjoyed playing this game with my cousin. I have played all the previous games through with him as well, and I can confidently say this one has a lot of advantages (and a few problems) that the others do not.
Pros:
The graphics are gorgeous compared to some of the oldest titles, the world feels cool and immersive. I enjoyed the vast majority of the puzzles, which often had more flair than previous games where you would describe symbols to the other person over and over again. You can also steal stuff from your friend, as there is more choice in this game as to who goes where, and you get to spend more time in the same area than you did in previous titles. I really enjoyed being able to play rock paper scissors and make crude gestures at my friend.
Cons: 
Some of the cut scenes are egregiously long and frequent. Additionally, there were moments where you have to carry these big heavy things around for no reason, and they make you slower. The only plus here is you can steal it from your friend, so you just mess around with it for a long time rather than getting anything done. The ending was also a little disappointing in its unrealistic outcome, but it is a minor problem.

Overall, a great game. Biggest gripe is the wait time for cut scenes I don't care about, biggest plus is more freedom in who does which portions of the puzzles, something the other titles didn't have. 8.5/10, would recommend.

I was exceptionally excited for this game, as even with some issues with We Were Here Together the experience was very fun and my friend and I had a great time. Which is why I am so frustrated with the major pitfalls this game. 

I would offer issues with gameplay but, sadly, the game doesn't even play as of writing this. Initially we made it to the second area of chapter 1 but encountered a game breaking bug where an important mine cart threw me out (and randomly my partner as well) so we could not go to the new set piece and progress through the puzzles. We tried many fixes and reached out for help with some limited feedback, repeatedly being sent a doc of common bug fixes, none of which seemed to apply to the in-game problem. Regardless, I decided to follow through with all their advice. Good news is I no longer have to worry about falling out of a mine cart because the game doesn't even open anymore. So that problem is technically solved. Upon opening the game, it now white screens and crashes, every time. 

I know making games is really difficult and this is a very recent release and I hope these issues eventually get addressed but there are just too many problems currently for people to play this game. Your ability to have a functioning game at all seems to be based on random chance. If these problems are solved and I can play past chapter 1, I'll be ecstatic to move on with my friend whom I kept needling to buy this so we can continue to enjoy the franchise. 

I wish the best of luck to the developers and hope I can change this review to a positive one in the near future.

So far the best in the series, by a small landslide.

For my brain, this really is the perfect blend of puzzle-solving. I love games that encourage talking -- co-op games are fun because they’re social, after all. We Were Here Forever understands this, making both players independent and codependent in equal measure. But always together, solving big puzzles, where each player holds a unique piece. 

Ultimately, it’s a game about listening and sharing. 

The presentation is really well done too. It feels much more cinematic than the previous titles, just with how set pieces and puzzles are married. There’s some proper storytelling and themes baked into them too. There’s urgency. There’s moments of both awe and dread, as you figure out the scope of a task; suddenly understanding how all the moving parts fit together. 

Highly recommended if you enjoy co-op games, and have a partner at the ready.

We Were Here Forever is the worst game of the series.

There is too much time spent simply waiting through cut scenes, or having to slowly walk while carrying some random heavy objects. This is doubly frustrating when replaying for the achievements, because none of it can be skipped. The puzzles themselves are also grossly unbalanced. All but 2 of them felt like only one person was actually solving, while the other person just stood around waiting to press a button or place an item.
The story is shoved in your face, as your camera is literally dragged to follow whatever event is happening. This gets increasingly frustrating when having to redo a puzzle, or even just to try and replay the game to experience the other side.

My partner and I loved the first 3 games. The puzzles were unique, exciting, and both sides felt like equal participants in finding the solutions. They missed the mark on this game though, padding the runtime with unnecessary running back and forth and sitting through long dialogues. And the ending is equally unsatisfying, having no choice but for one of you to just sink after a certain amount of time. It would have been more enjoyable to have a secret way to both survive, since this if probably the last game of the series.

I would only recommend getting this game if you wanted to "complete the series", but if it's your first time playing these coop puzzle games, I would suggest playing through any of the previous games in the series. You will almost certainly have a better time with them.

"It Takes Forever"

The game has some really smart and fun to play puzzles which I adored despite some minor bugs and confusion. Some of them remind me a lot of Alice Madness Returns stuff which I'm not sure is purposeful but feels quite nostalgic and the puzzles have pretty brilliant mind-bending twists to them as well. We've had lots of fun figuring these out with my partner as far.

There is a serious downside at the moment though. The game's graphics, interface and the slower character moving speed seem to have been designed VR style for some reason which is cool (maybe possible future updates?). However, the puzzle areas in the game are quite enormous in size which makes walking around and thus also solving some of the puzzles >incredibly slow<. And then some of the puzzles are also designed so you need to test different solutions before getting them right, which takes long too. Connect that with the bugs and it'll sometimes take you over an hour to solve a puzzle that'd otherwise take you max 15 min. That's very frustrating and can be a terrible waste of one's time. 

Don't get me wrong. I love the epic big scale environment designs and I can see what the devs were going for. But personally I think the mechanics and walking patches within that could be designed much better to save us walking long ways around same place multiple times.

This is a game I was looking forward to for a long time. The hype was real and I worried the game might not quite live up to it. However, I was wrong! We Were Here Forever completely lives up to the hype and is absolutely worth its full asking price!

That is, if you have a friend. Just one friend, that's all you really need. Keep that in mind.

Like the previous games in the series, We Were Here Forever places two players in the boots of arctic explorers trapped in a mysterious castle, taunted by a wicked jester and wondering what dark tale might have revolved around the mad king and his ruined, snowbound realm.

Communication is key, as the game requires players to talk, relay information and guide one another through the various puzzles and challenges the game presents. I won't say much on the puzzles, other than that there is a wide variety of them. Any player will probably like some more than others, and I can think of one puzzle I particularly disliked myself. However, no puzzle overstays its welcome too badly, and thus has no chance to sour the experience, as the next puzzle then takes over and the players get to move on to new adventures.

Communication is also made a little more challenging and thoughtful by the radios used in the game, as when one player is transmitting, they cannot hear the other, and if both players transmit at the same time, they block each other out and cannot communicate at all! Now, sure, you could work around this by using voice comms outside of the game, but I'd recommend against such a workaround, as it will remove a key element of tension and challenge from the game.

The game has evolved from its predecessors in pretty much all areas. The tech, the visuals, the sound and music are all improved with each iteration. The odd accents (Dutch, I think, maybe?) of the voice actors might throw you off, but this is easily justified by the story and locale of the game. In some places, mostly around are transitions, even my beefy gaming PC started to experience some slowdown, but this also remained brief and never took place in areas where time or precision was of the essence.

A key note I can't help but reiterate, though: this game is good, but it can only be as good as the connection you have with your co-player. There is an option to play with random strangers, but personally this does not feel like a good method for playing a game such as this. Find a friend, grab a radio and get puzzling!

As the fourth game in a series, We Were Here Forever is a title that knows what it’s about. The gameplay isn’t particularly flashy, and the story doesn’t feature a series of dramatic set pieces to get your adrenaline up. Instead, the developers have stuck to what they know: building unique and interesting puzzles that demand a kind of teamwork very rarely seen in other games. The game improves on its predecessors in every way, without losing the magic that made the series unique in the first place. If you’re not interested in puzzle solving, then this game is going to be an extremely dull experience; alternatively, if you are, then I cannot recommend it highly enough. 

9/10

To celebrate the final installment we went back and replayed all 3 previous games, and the charms still there.

An extraordinary piece in the series, exactly like every release, they get better and better!

This is by far my favourite Co-op game on steam now.
The gameplay in the previous games were stellar, but this one is the crown piece in the series!

We Were Here Forever is a solid installment in the We Were Here franchise. It provides some innovation with a non-linear section of the game and more puzzles where both explorers are interacting in the same space or can choose their role just prior to the puzzle instead of being forced. Unfortunately, it is not as strong a We Were Here Together which had more consistent puzzle quality, better difficulty curve, and less focus on the story of Castle Rock. Though We Were Here Forever far overshadows the frustrating and clunky We Were Here Too.

Definitely worth playing if a fan of the series. New players should start with the free We Were Here or the superior We Were Here Together.
Puzzles are bootiful, well crafted. Very long game but kept us entertained for 20 hours over the span of the week

Best puzzles game to play with a friend out there. I am glad to say I enjoyed the entire franchise and I am a big fan.

Super fun with a friend! Love the series and hope they keep making more. A couple of small bugs at the start, but everything else was super fun, loved the voice acting. Highly recommend the bundle and all the games in the series. Thanks for another great adventure! (~8 hours to beat the game)
unreal game.

The game was great, until it wasn't.
First half of the game (up until the moment you have to go to 3 different places to get parts for the machine) was great, amazing even. Definitely the best this series ever had to offer. Puzzles were interesting and level design was great. 

Then you had to get those three parts and the quality of puzzles just drops drastically. It seems as if their goal in puzzle design turned from "Engaging puzzles requiring cooperation" to your generic logic puzzles.
 
First one on the cementery wasn't terrible, just kind of meh compared to the previous ones.
Second one in the mountains, again just worse compared to the previous ones.

But the third one in the nautilus was just god awful. Underwater walk was just boring for one player who barely got to do anything. Both pipes and that underwater garden can go fuck themselves. And that god damn kraken. I've spent so much time on that kraken and finally decided to look up how to solve it. And wouldn't you know, I've been doing what you're meant to do but the game just doesn't work properly. You literally have to look up the solution because the game is bugged and you cannot do it properly.

Besides that in game voice chat was bugged like hell. And Ending was really disappointing.

I really don't want to mark this as "recommended"  because you can't get passed a certain point on your own due to a bug, but that first part of the game was really phenomenal enough to justify the price tag, so I'm gonna do anyway (Just know what you're getting into)

Played this game with a friend, we've also played the other games prior to this and looked forward to this coming out.

Some interesting puzzles in this one though I have to say, some of them were painful to get through. This game felt like it has so much filler cut scenes just to get from one place to another and not for the sake of loading. 

Constantly having to carry something back and forth for no particular reason was so draining. The only thing we found entertaining when locked in these cut scenes was to use the emote wheel which I'm thankful they had. There's something so funny about pointing to your teammate during serious voice acting.

During the grave digging puzzle, we had to reload the game several times as it kept bugging out. There were numerous bugs during our playthrough and my friend also stopped getting any of the achievements for whatever reason.

The portal puzzle in particular was really fun and different. The potion making one would have been better without the time limit in my opinion as it took a few frustrating attempts. The mirror rotation was fun to put together. The majority of the rest were just painful and I honestly think we finished them out of spite.

Overall there were lots of memorable moments, but there were more negative than positive ones for me.

The game was really fun and amazing to play, tho me and my friend really wish they would have made it a lot longer. It feels somewhat shorter than the previous one, most of time was spent in cut-scenes.  The design of the game is amazing and very well made.  However me and my friend do like some challenging puzzles, were you will have to sit and think for awhile, or racing your heart out due to the timer running out and you are about to die and fail your perfect streak for that zero deaths achievement you were working on. 

So puzzles were way too easy. Also they were not changing when you failed and had to do  it again, so one some of the puzzles you could just press each item until you knew the correct 3, as the game were never changing the correct one up. So was pretty boring in the end.  

 Were expecting it to get harder and harder the further in the game you got, instead it turned out to be the the other way around, with some puzzles you barely had to think as you already had the obvious answer in your head. 

Also was expecting a grand final, with a pretty hard puzzle, instead you got to a room where you did not have to do anything except a few short tasks,  so the room was completed is less than 3 minutes or so.

I hope the next We Were Here game will be a lot more challenging and also way longer, we mostly finished it the same sitting and both came out rather disappointed. We both wanted a way more challenging and longer game. 

So to sum it all up,  the game was fun and looks gorgeous, but way too easy to play and not long enough.    3/5  stars

Have you ever wanted to relive the feeling of being in second grade music class forced to learn sheet music, while you cry but still don't understand?  This game is perfect for you! 

Relive the feeling of being a stupid second grader who doesn't know what 2+2 is.
Your dad keeps yelling "WHAT IS 2+2? WHAT IS IT?". But you can't grasp the idea of simple math. 
Tears flowing down your face, vision blurred from crying, you push on and persevere. 
But that, is just a lie you keep telling to yourself "I'll be fine if I just push on"
 
You end up cheating and looking up the answers from the back of the book. 
Somehow you manage to feel accomplished.




Even though you cheated.

TL:DR: 
It's a real mixed bag, the art has improved greatly over each game, but the story has become more annoying, puzzles range from great, to something I never want to touch again and the game actively wastes time to pad the runtime. There is also a number of bugs that you will come across. 

I am glad this game exists for the 2 player puzzle genre, it's great to have it as an option but at many times this game has been infuriating to play through. Sometimes, the puzzles are obtuse but generally it's traversal and story that really weigh it down. EG. There is a collect x amount of this and place it elsewhere section of the game and it is so slow to do so, it felt like a waste of time. This combined with transitional cut scenes that take far too long make the game really drag.

Also there has been a large amount of bugs, for example, I've finished the game but stopped getting achievements after half way through - the result of another bug earlier in the game where lack of clarity and bugginess, forced us to reload, sequence breaking what was meant to happen. Another example, I stood in front of my partners exit point and it broke their cut scene, forcing a reload because it locked them in place even after I moved.
This is the best video game series, there is no contest, all of the We Were Here games have taken themselves to new levels with each installment. If you haven't played these games its a must!

We Were Here Forever is the pinnacle of its series, which started out humbly but made itself something amazing. WWHF finds itself a place in the highest order or asymmetrical co-op games that it shares with games such as Hazelight's catalog of masterpieces. The fun of solving puzzles with a friend where you both play an instrumental role in the process is unrivaled for me, and WWHF pulls creative, crazy, and above all else fun challenges out of its hat for players to enjoy together. The plot will really only make sense if you played the previous games, but even as someone who did (albeit no recently), it was nothing to really write home about. It did its job and that's all it needed to be, but it likely won't blow you away. Overall, the game and its series have played a role in defining asymmetrical co-op as a genre and this game delivers that fun in spades.

An excellent puzzle game for you and a friend. If you're new to the franchise, you will enjoy this game if you like puzzles - especially escape rooms and cooperative communication. If you're returning because you enjoyed one of the other We Were Here games, rest assured this is Total Mayhem's best game yet, with much higher production value and higher quality puzzles than their previous games. 

In particular, I thought the puzzles in this game were elevated by how their puzzle mechanics blended wonderfully with the cosmetic theme of each area. My only critique would be that sometimes it felt like one person got the 'better' end of the puzzle slightly too often - but perhaps that's subjective!

Enjoy - this is an excellent game and a wonderful addition to the series. There is no franchise quite like We Were Here - it's becoming a staple of the puzzle game landscape for good reason.

Spoiler alert, just letting you know. 

[spoiler]This game - hell, this whole series - makes me suffer emotionally in such a fantastic way. Very few games are able to pull off a set-in-stone bittersweet or bad end and make me wish that there was a way to get to a happy ending. I've followed this series from the very first entry, and each time, it's made me search frantically on the internet to see if there was a way for my girlfriend and I to get a happy ending. Each time, I've met with failure. True to every game's moral of the story, one must always stay behind.[/spoiler]

Spoilers aside, however, from a puzzle game's standard, We Were Here Forever is top-notch in my opinion. Playing with a friend online in a game that forces the two of you to coordinate in ways you never thought you'd ever have to in order to progress is nothing short of an amazing feat, but for Total Mayhem, it's just their average Tuesday. Highly recommended, if you've got a buddy that you can test your teamwork with.

The system requirements are a bit higher (also no Mac version) and a select few puzzles are frustratingly hard, but besides that, another excellent We Were Here game. Fun puzzles, creative levels, and beautiful themes.

I played through the full We Were Here series with a friend of mine and we were both hooked. We came for the puzzle gameplay and stayed for the story to see it through to its completion.

The puzzle gameplay itself was very solid, a rather broad array of different puzzle types that combined logical and spatial thinking as well as rudimentary problem solving skills all combined for a rather enjoyable experience. 

That said while I do sing the games praises I do also admit that it has some flaws that could be improved upon. There were three particular problems I had with the game as a whole.

1 - The general pacing of the game. Once you hit the "free roam pick your path" segment it feels like the game wastes a fair chunk of your time with excessive travel and transitions. Like, come on, a five minute gondola ride through terrain that was basically identical the whole way?

2 - The final puzzle in the water section. [spoiler]While I do understand the concept behind this puzzle I think it would have been much better to just have both players up front being able to hear sounds and work on the translation together instead of one person trying to replicate sounds. We weren't able to get the creature sounds to come through the walkie-talkies so we ended up resorting to just some screen sharing to have sounds shared between us. The idea of the puzzle was great, the execution not so much.[/spoiler]

3 - The ending, god the ending. Big spoilers here. [spoiler]The final tower puzzle was fun and felt frantic (even though there was no real time limit) and it was an interesting way to see the story concluded for the King and the Jester. But did you really have to go for a Titanic in the section afterwards? It felt so arbitrarily forced and pushed that only one of them could survive on the little raft. Both of them could have clutched onto it or one sat and held the other steady or something and let's not forget that in the underwater section one of the survivors will have been in sub-freezing temperature water for a good ten to thirty minutes for the mines puzzle. Overall the forced death in the finale left a very sour taste in my mouth. It sincerely felt like after this long, perilous journey together we would finally get a happy ending with the conclusion of the story, only to have it very cruelly ripped away from us for no real reason.[/spoiler]

Despite my complaints though I would still recommend this game for those of you who are looking for a good co-op puzzle adventure. If you're going to play this I seriously recommend that you go back and start with the original We Were Here and work through the entire series to get a better grasp and understanding of the overarching story.

My friend and I just recently played through the entire We Were Here series together. Each game, in and among itself, was wonderful. Each title grew on the experience of the puzzle escape room-esque environment and, in my opinion, got better each game. I must say my initial views on the franchise as a whole were bleak but this was well before i stepped into the world - a classic example of not judging a book by its cover!

This next one in the series was just wonderful. From the start backtracking through Castle Rock through new environments and puzzles all the way to the end of the final chapter we were encapsulated. I also loved the 'ah-hah' moments we had coming into each puzzle. Overthinking was our biggest flaw, but the game didnt punish with 99% puzzle completion resets or deaths. Instead we were encouraged to rethink our position, read the clues multiple times, swap perspectives, and come to the conclusion together.

Bugs we experienced in this game to this end: During the final sequence of the Underwater section of the Nautilus section (encountering the creature) after a failed attempt, and then a role change, the console which imitated the sounds bugged out, stopped displaying the codes all together, and also played the same sounds for every dial rotation. Fortunately, since this was the second time we played this section, we remembered the questions and were able to answer correctly, but others may not be as fortunate.

I am extremely excited to have read that there may be more coming, and I am looking forward to the opportunity to immerse myself in this franchise. Keep up the wonderful work guys and thanks for keeping this series running!

The puzzles are expertly designed and it is very clear the developers have learned and grown into the genre well. It's a shame this franchise ends with its best game as it leaves me wanting a lot more from Total Mayhem, but I'm happy the franchise got a game I can consider absolutely perfect. 

Also make sure to play through every game with your best friend. From personal experience, that's what makes the series special.

I really enjoyed this game. I played all the games in the series and this was a great addition. Some of the puzzles were so much fun and unlike any puzzles I have done in other games. 

With that said there were some small issues I had with the game. I have seen a few mentions of these things and wanted to reiterate them because they were kind of annoying from a player perspective.

1. There was a lot of walking or travel from puzzle to puzzle. It felt so unnecessary. It was long for the sake of being long and it really ruined the immersion. You couldn't do anything during these times so it led to picking up my phone or changing screens till the game decided it was ready for me. Some of these times there was story line which felt much better but usually it was just silence.

2. Some puzzles felt very lopsided. While I enjoyed some of these puzzle a great deal others left me feeling a bit underwhelmed. Some were so one sided that if you weren't the one solving the puzzle there was nothing you could do but sit and wait. It was a bit annoying when all the information was with one player and not split between both in a way that was fun for both.

That said I'm glad I bought this game and it was well worth the wait from the last one. I really did enjoy it overall and the little things weren't enough to make me dislike it in anyway.

This game is easily one of the best if not the best coop puzzle game I have ever played. The whole series is absolutely amazing from start to finish. Brings out the best in you and your teammate and is suitable for any duo whether its a best friend, significant other, or in my case my favorite person in the whole world my little brother. This game will keep you entertained while at the same time leading you through a fun and wholesome story line to back up its very enticing game play.

The 'We Were Here' game series started with a small game where one person was in a room filled with answers, and another was in a room filled with questions. To see the idea of explorers from throughout the series working together, seeing familiar faces or really just familiar walki-talkies is a delight. This game series and We Were Here Forever specifically has left a lasting dent on my mind, and has quenched my thirst for coop puzzle solving. The idea of puzzles that have no given rules, until you figure them out, and the necessity for describing sights and sounds that the other player may not hear or see strengthens bonds and gives a good laugh. We Were Here Forever allows the player to get hints. This means that everything you need to solve puzzles, and get help solving them comes right with the game; No searching google for answers. Overall We Were Here Forever has blown my expectations out of the water. To see a game series start out fairly simple and grow into this amazing game makes me proud to be a member of its community and makes me excited for the future of We Were Here or any branching series made by these great Devs.

The puzzles were largely fun, and interesting. However, the game suffers from three major pitfalls:

First, the pacing is absolutely awful. All of the cutscenes that move character between areas take 3x as long as they should, and a lot of the game feels like they artificially extended the playtime through pointless walking and waiting.

And second, too many of the puzzles had an imbalance of information, to the point where one person was doing 90% of the thinking and problem solving, and the other person was just bored waiting until they could test the possible solutions.

Lastly, the optimization was terrible. I have a VERY solid PC, and the underwater level was still a permanent ~20 fps the entire time we were there. This is pretty unacceptable from a studio that has already released multiple titles.

Overall, it was still a decent game, but because of these issues it left a bad taste in my mouth and so I feel the negative review is warranted.

Great co-op puzzle game to play through with a friend. Best to play through the first 3 games before attempting this one though, as you'll miss a lot of the lore if you don't.

Otherwise, it's more of what you'd expect at this point: better puzzles, better graphics, better game length. The first game is ~1 hour, the second game is ~3, the third is ~6, and this one is ~11. All of them are worth the price even if you feel the time return on investment isn't as high as other games.

The main gimmick is puzzle solving where each player is given separate but related information, and you have to use good communication to figure out what each of you needs to do. It starts out pretty easy but ramps up through the game as you'd expect. Grab a friend and put your brains together!

We have not finished the game but we encountered a situation that we are hard-locked and not able to proceed due to a big design failure of game mechanism. Spoiler alert!

This happens when we are playing the "spin-your-room" puzzle, where we have to rotate our room to create a portal by matching icons on the two sides of adjacent rooms. In the second part of this puzzle chapter, there exist two versions of world: Outer world (with key, egg, sun rooms, etc) and inner world (with bird skull, moon room, etc). 

When the players approach the end of the puzzle, player A will find himself in the clown-wand room of inner world and he can get to the key room of outer world with the help of player B (Note that the player B is currently at a ghost-mask room of inner world). Then player B goes to the crowned-grenade room by himself. Now player A should help player B to get to bird-skull room, and then player A goes to egg room WITHOUT the help of the other. Then, after a few steps, the puzzle is solved.

The failure of the game design is: When player A gets to the key room, he can go to egg room and then to the final room by himself. Imagine that you are the player A and you quickly get to the key then to egg then to final room by yourself, but then the other player says "hey I still need you help". Then you realize you should help player B to get the bird-skull room before you entering the egg room. You want to get back but you cannot because there is no way out in the final room. In this situation, you and your friend are hard-locked in the game. You are locked in the final room and your friend is locked in the crowned-grenade room. This is a big failure of design and you have to start from the very beginning of the first part of the puzzle with pentagon rooms. 

I have to doubt if there exist any other design failure that cause hard lock or soft lock of game process. If the developers think this is not a failure this is a feature, then I have to give a negative review.

This game is one of the most creative stories I have ever seen, hands down. It took a simple idea, threw multiple perspectives, areas, and puzzle concepts in, and worked out beautifully. I originally enjoyed the simple puzzle patterns, the occasional shift of intel control between players, and loved the endings when we would rejoin. As the games continued, I got more immersed, the story got more intriguing, more sweet yet haunting. There were some really frightening moments, some moments where I felt control torn from me entirely and yet it all was fascinating. The main thing I wanted to say is that me and my friend ended up getting theatrical in the end, and I almost cried when I couldn't save him. Hope to see more from Total Mayhem.

Like every new installment into the series, this installment  has really made me feel like co op puzzle games could be a major hit if done correctly. With previous installments in the series, knowing that you were set on one role made the game feel as though it was one sided. Through the first two games in the genre, you would either be one role of telling another player what to do, or you would be the other role of explaining the puzzle to the one trying to figure it out. And through the third, they had tried to branch and even out the roles where both players are working through a puzzle together, and gave a good short story to add on top of it. 

The forth game has been an amazing summary of the positives in the series to date. Working through a problem together instead of a explanation-solution is extremely satisfying. The puzzles felt really enjoyable to solve and work through, similar to the third game in the series, and trying to replicate and explain noises to a friend for one of the puzzles was extremely hilarious and makes me want to experience more of these kinds of puzzle co-op adventures. I think the story is fantastic, and makes me wonder if the next game in the series will be called "We Were Here Forevermore".

If anyone hasn't played through the 3rd game, I would highly suggest going through that game before trying out this one. I would say it is about an hour or two less in length, however it still has a similar format to what I've talked about above. This game has a great story that builds upon the third one, and I feel as if the 3rd and 4th game in the series was a great turn into massive improvements on the series as a whole.

Puzzles? Fantastic!
First playthrough time with a friend? Almost 10 hours (The 3rd game in the series was around 6-7, I think.)
Story? Builds off of the 3rd game, however is very well done. 
Highly Recommend? YES

A very good game overall, if short.

Very well constructed puzzles, relying on communication, but not saying so, often hinting at this requirement for such puzzles. Never punishing for not meeting the time constraint, only taking a portion of your time to reset as opposed to having to reload from a checkpoint.

All the puzzles were visually stunning, and the story element was amazing! The fluid splitting of puzzles, flowing between being together and being apart while dividing up tasks was very well handled.

Some of the control handling such as inventory felt very slightly clunky, but not problematic (it would flick to the end then the start when using a mouse wheel)

Overall a very nice story leave off, even if it was a bit short compared to the other games, but 7-11 hours is not bad for a series finale which has a good track record (except for we were here too, sorry), BUT it still has a cliff hanger to it... Just saying :P

As a fan of the series since the first game came out, I expected this is wrap up the story fully, which it didn't do in too much detail as it still left me with a huge set of blue balls, similar to Firewatch. I'm not sure if there are alternative endings and if there are, I will definitely play again. I was expecting both characters to survive due to the standard endings of the other games ending in only one making it out, however this ending was very obvious. However, the game play was interesting and the puzzles were very different to the puzzles we had seen previously. I wouldn't expect them to make another game, but I do hope they release some sort of final cinematic to see the POV of the surviving player. This would be a welcome addition to the series as I feel it would fully conclude the mysterious lore.

Apart from this, I thoroughly enjoyed playing the We Were Here series and have been anticipating the final game for a while now. Fingers crossed they release some more context or even a new series with similar but revised elements.

This game is the best of the series for many reasons, but it also contains issues that hinder enjoyment and immersion in the series. TLDR at the end.

The We Were Here series was never a technically impressive series of games but this game was a vast improvement over the previous entries. However, my friend and I have experienced a few technical issues with the game.  Between hitching, player collision with environment, and a soft lock, it was not an environment I wanted to explore, as frame rates would decrease greatly depending where I went.

It is worth noting that my pc is on the lower-end and while it is entirely playable, I would expect a game with a simpler graphics style to perform better, especially with how many loading screens the game puts you through. (With lowest settings, I averaged 60 frames, dropping to 30-40 in some areas.)

The story is more or less easy to follow, the animations and voice acting giving much life to the player characters and the Jester.  However, as this is a co-op game, it is hard to follow what is going on with the story as you banter with your friend, sometimes overlooking what the story may be trying to say.  

The puzzles are the best in the series, avoiding many of the pitfalls of the previous games (particularly the decreased usage of "symbol-to-symbol-to-action" style puzzles), instead focusing on a mixture of physical movement and brain teaser style puzzles.  However, with this experimentation, we found that some puzzles were much better than others.  Notably, there is a part of the game where you must relay sound to your teammate, and he must be able to interpret that and give you something in return.  While unique, it was so difficult to relay that it resulted in me just putting my headphones against my microphone for him to actually hear the sounds.  I could not imagine this experience with someone who was deaf or hard of hearing.

Game design was overall good with some odd decisions.  In a part of the game where you are given the ability to choose the next area, you are told to bring back several objects back to an area to progress the plot.  However, to bring these objects back required both people, one of which was slowed down by carrying the object.  It was then followed (several times) by a 50 second sequence of waiting, putting the item where it belonged, and then going [b] back [/b], waiting another 50 seconds, which finally ended with starting the next area.  At certain points we just wished to get to the next area and move on.

There were also several points where we were just sitting in a cut scene of sorts for minutes at a time.  The worst instance was a 3 minutes wait where there was no music, no dialogue, or anything intractable.  They were infrequent but noticeable.

There was, however, a remarkable puzzle that really brought out the best in the team's capabilities.  I won't spoil it, but you will know it when you get there.  There were quite a few enjoyable puzzles that, while frustrating at first, had good payoff as we slowly solved it.

TLDR:  Great game.  Playable, but poor performance on lower-end machines.  Story is good, but nothing revolutionary.  Puzzles and interaction with friend alone make this game worth it.  Occasional, odd game design that you will sometimes just have to ignore.

Honestly, I don't even know where to start with this game. It was absolutely breathtaking. Every puzzle was something new and fun, and in my opinion the puzzles were better than any of the other we were here games. The small bugs didn't break the immersiveness of the game at all, and the ones I experienced are fixed already. The longer experience, the absolutely amazing graphics and the masterful soundscapes made this game my absolute favorite game that I have ever played in my life. You really feel like you are these explorers, with only your brain and communication with a friend to help you escape. The story in this game was significant, coherent, not shoved in your face all the time, and always in the back of your head. The level designs, specifically Nautilus and the Music Box, are all incredible. And the fact that you meet up with your friend and stick with them for large portions of the game makes it all better, and more emotional at the end of the game. I've truly never had a game make me sad before. Nothing in story got me so invested as this game did. When I woke up the morning after I finished the game with my friend, I decided to watch the ending scenes again, and I just cried when I saw them. If you are looking for a puzzle-solving, emotional, and overall fantastic adventure with a friend, then the we were here series is undoubtedly the best series for you.

This game has a game breaking bug that prevents further progression at the graveyard. One player is supposed to interact with locations marked on a map that the other player must describe. After the first one, they simply cannot be interacted with. Have spoken with other players in the official discord for this game and they have also encountered this error and had to try multiple restarts to work around, however, it is not guaranteed to work after a restart. For a puzzle game to have a bug that simply prevents progression I cant leave a good review for this game, shameful because I enjoyed the prior 3 games.


edit: took a break from the game for a while to allow bugs such as this one, black screens, low fps, broken checkpoints, etc to be fixed . Now the game has gone from buggy to unplayable. Not only do invites fail to connect you 80% of the time, but now the game invite spams you repeatedly even if your friend has only sent one, making the game reminiscent to unintentionally installing pop up viruses onto your moms basement computer after looking at porn on the wrong websites.

Do not buy until several bug fixing patches have been released, through 12 hrs so far and have experienced a bug that did not allow partner or I to progress through story, a bug that threw us through the map, a bug that will not currently let me load from our checkpoint, thus functionally stopping our progress, and have had multiple areas that cause FPS drop / lag for no reason.

Story seems great, puzzles are decent, but due to bugs and performance issues this is not a worth buy until patches come out.

EDIT: Came back to the game after two week break in order to give devs time to release bug patches...
There is now a current bug that many people are experiencing in which infinite invites are sent to one person, not allowing them to properly join most of the time, and when they do... the invite screen is permanently stuck so they cannot click or play anywhere outside the window when the game launches.   Therefore barring my friend and I continuing our play-through or really playing the game at all.

I understand the studio is small and has a lot on their plate right now, but realistically just wait until you release in order to have a decent product... Sorry if this is harsh but just upset with how enjoyable and clean the 3 other iterations in this series felt in comparison.
Another good entry in the saga, recommended as the ones before :).

We just finished the game, I have only one thing to say:
The game is expensive for what it is.

Side gameplay:
The first half of the game is nice, but many puzzles suffer from a problem: Only one player solves the puzzle, the other just follows. It's annoying to be the second. Small mention of the jester's universe that we liked.
The other half alternates between puzzles that are as boring as possible and require the description of complex images (The city, I think of you and your shitty projector...), elevator phases without cinematics, loading to put an object and then going back through the same loading...
The vault is nice, but the sound of the revenants is HORRIBLE, the nautilus is fun (really) but the phase with the sounds was a purge (unless you can transmit the sounds with the talkie, I do not know, we used discord)

Scenery:
The scenery is either in near total darkness or forgettable. Except for the Nautilus, we really liked these sets! To a lesser extent, the jester's world is an honorable mention, but nothing crazy either.

Lore:
The little story we experienced fits on a postage stamp, while it was developed over almost twice as long as the previous one. I personally also find it hard to make the link with the previous opus.

Bugs :
Quite a few bugs. Cinematics that get stuck, white screens that stay 2 centuries during some loading, interaction that gets stuck... We honestly had a hard time finishing it.

The end:
[spoiler]Why did you make this stupid remix of titanic? We spent 5 minutes pulling each other out of the water and not understanding anything before the game decided I had to die. It's stupid, why would you want to kill one of the players? And why couldn't we just stand two on the damn board?! In the previous games, it added drama, betrayal and all that... Here, it's just "nope lol", the game is over, the kingdom is destroyed, we'll never come back for sure, what was stopping us from just fading to black after helping our colleague to get on the raft and hear the ship? I don't understand this ending.
Not to mention the final mission that had absolutely EVERYTHING that indicated that we were in a hurry, the king getting angry, the epic music, the tower being ripped apart by the king... But nothing. Paradoxically, it was the easiest puzzle of the game since it was almost exclusively about pulling levers. In fact, there were only levers. It's kind of like in "We were here Together", at the end, the jester looked at us while we were doing the knight puzzles and decided who was going to be sacrificed.

By the way, is it just me or is the jester technically the protagonist of the game? When you think about it, he manipulates us during the whole game to assemble the magic ray, HE uses us to carry the piece of contract that he HIMSELF put on us, and we're not even the ones destroying the castle. Basically, he don't even need us, since he basically do whatever he want and speak privately with us without the king noticing.[/spoiler]

The scale and quality of this game is amazing. Shame that it kinda worked massively against it.

Ignoring all the bugs (which can make some puzzles unplayable; like the sound wheel with the kraken just not working or the puzzle pipes actually giving us the wrong pipes (the 1st puzzle gave us 3 of 1 and 1 of the other. We both thought we were missing something, but it was just the game not working)) and some parts being very slow to load. Or that you have to do sooo much walking. Like, why have the ski-lift be so long for what reason? Wasting time? Like this game did? Even ignoring that the story builds up to nothing having the jester this big threat, and then he says "Darn you foiled my plans" after trying to stop you once...

No, the one part that really fails this game is the puzzles. It does have some fun puzzles but half of the "puzzles" in this game are not puzzles at all. The last part where you aim the laser is just flick switches in order with no real fear of doing anything wrong. So there are two problems that occur in most puzzles. It's either very one sided, where you never really feel like both players are working together or you have puzzles that are very linear with no real way of messing it up.  This game tried to make the scale huge, and in doing so, they lost the ability to make focused and planned puzzles. 

Some examples:
The Laser "puzzle" at the end - It's just find the switches and flick them in order. No fail condition if you somehow did anything wrong here
Piano puzzle - The guy with the cards solves everything. Piano guy just waits for inputs
Graves - The puzzle never changes. You can brute force it with ease
Scuba diver - The scuba diver is in a "maze" with like no way of not going the right way. Does nothing than just let the other guy do all the work
Resistance leaders - I like how this gives the answer to the previous puzzle for no reason. Anyway, you can just look from above and easily use logic to get the answer

I've been disappointed. It's got a great theme, and it can really immerse you with its story, but the puzzles themselves broke our immersion, and sometimes broke our game. WWH's core mechanic does follow in this game: a "librarian" who holds all of the information, and an "adventurer" who follows instruction and explains what they're seeing. It is, however, impossible to tell which you are going into before you enter the area with the puzzle.

This can lead to many one-sided puzzles where one person is telling the other person what to do the whole way through. Not all puzzles were like this, but there were enough that it left the adventurer bored staring at one thing while the librarian did all the thinking.

There were 2 instances in which something malfunctioned, and we ended up being unable to progress because of it. And no, it wasn't because we missed something. We reset and did it the proper way without being locked in after loading a checkpoint.

Excellent game. Really fascinating puzzles that are satisfying to solve and aren't unnecessarily hard. Only one puzzle didn't entirely make sense to me and my partner that played through. It also has a lot more story than the first three games in the series. The puzzles had my heart beating and my head being scratched. For a lot of levels, I kept saying "this is such a cool puzzle" or "I would've never thought of even making a puzzle like this!"

The only subpar things are the following:
-You need a friend to play; playing with a random person isn't gonna work. 
-The ending was unsatisfying and disappointing to me from a narrative perspective, but it wasn't entirely unexpected. I can think of a better ending that would've been more satisfying to me, but it doesn't ruin my experience with the game or anything. 
-You can't really play through it more than once since you already know the solutions. I don't think many are randomized. You can play through twice just to see the other side of the game and what your partner saw, but there's not a whole lot of reason to play through more than that. 

Regardless, this game is one of the best I've played. It's well worth the price and the journey just to play through it once. Highly recommend.
good game

This game is the fourth installment in a unique type of co-op puzzle solving. With my friend I've played through - and thoroughly enjoyed - every single game, testing to see which one of us is the most valiant (and which the most selfish) ... and finding each and every time that I'm definitely not the hero of us two (sorry Shark!). 

This fourth game is substantially longer than the first three games, and the world is beautiful, the scenery much more vast and immersive than in the previous games (although WWHT was gorgeous too) and the puzzles very diverse and entertaining. A few were absolutely unique and made for a wonderfully frustrating and challenging experience. Some seemed to be a little too 'easy', or maybe we were just too experienced in the whole puzzle-solving ways of the We Were Here games. I definitely missed the pressure, too; in this one no lava slowly rising to the grate you're standing on, no winding steps slowly giving away beneath your feet. The final puzzle lacks a certain intensity that I definitely did feel in WWHT (and kind of hoped for) but the ending definitely did do what WWH games manage without fail.... Throw me in a week-long depression and question just what kind of friend I really am. 

Truly, I love these games and they're a unique kind of cooperative gaming that I have never found in any other game, and I so very much recommend it to anyone who wants to experience this fun, heart wrenching and immersive game. And when your friend waves, you better wave back <3

All the puzzles have been set in with intriguing concepts and the environment the puzzles are put in feel right with the location and really make each area fun to move around in and look around. This game has been a big step up from the other games with its graphics and how more story-driven we are as the characters when moving around to move to different areas from how it felt back in We Were Here and We Were Here Too. Big improvement!

The environment I can tell has been put in with a lot of effort and only being somewhat halfway in the game so far I can say I would recommend it to a pair of friends to play for themselves knowing that the content given so far (Up to chapter 4 as of writing this) has felt worth its price and there is only more content to come which I look forward to doing.

This entire series has been an enjoyable journey. Easily recommendable to anyone looking for a cooperative puzzle experience with a decent story. This is the first game I've purchased on release date since I think Borderlands 2.

Things I appreciated in this installment include the change in and variety of puzzles. We overthought some puzzles, we easily destroyed others, we were happily challenged by yet more puzzles, and we discovered I am not great with visuals. Between this game and the previous ones there has been a nice decrease in the number of times I had to describe three similar looking squiggly lines with excruciating details or ask the pivotal question "What color is his hair, though?" only to determine I might have a touch of colorblindness. Even if I did not love every puzzle, this game has a great medley and, very happy to say, we generally felt successful after solving each puzzle instead of confused as to what we did to win.

I will say that on a few occasions, and maybe this is just my experience, it felt as though I encountered the majority of the "sit and wait for the other person to solve the puzzle for you" problem. In previous games, this was fairly well balanced in that the person with the answers switched back and forth regularly. With players choosing their own path frequently in this game, it may happen more often that find yourself waiting patiently for your partner to solve the puzzle while you twiddle your thumbs. Again, this was purely happenstance in that I happened to pick the path that lead to being the errand boy while my friend solved things. In general, I felt happy knowing I had some amount of choice in where to go and what to do.

Finally, let me admit the story falls flat for me. While I would need to replay each game in succession before solidifying this opinion, I do not see much solid connection between the previous three games' story and the conclusion of this one. Honestly, the story contained within WWHF seems oddly disjointed at times, or at least rushed and ill planned. The story does add to the overall experience of the game, something the game can't do without, but the plot does not integrate with the story the way it does in games like the Myst series, where Myst almost explains why the puzzles exist in the first place. In the WWH series, you get story, you get puzzle, but you rarely see any relation between the two elements (rarely, because there is sometimes a connection, such as the play at the end of the first game). [spoiler] PLUS THEY SHAFT YOU ONCE MORE AT THE END FOR GOOD MEASURE NOT THAT I'M BITTER. [/spoiler]

All in all, great series if you have a friend to play with who also enjoys puzzles. I genuinely will miss this series if this is the last installment, but will 100% keep an eye on this publisher.
