I want to start off by saying, this was my least favorite in the We Were Here series, but it's not a "bad" game. I'm just making this comment because I'm just disappointed with it.

Upscaling/Lag
====================
 - The devs try to make the areas "bigger" in this game, which made everything very laggy when loading in new sections (Which happen as you play, no loading screens). Most of these open areas are just filled with walkways on the way to the next puzzle. However there is one section that was laggy even after loading; The Moonlight Section. This part would lag if you ever faced the direction the light was coming from.


Puzzle Imbalance:
==========================
- This game has too many puzzle that have one player actually doing a puzzle and the other standing around, waiting for input or to update the other player on color/noise/symbol changes. While the other games had puzzles like this, due to players being forced onto certain paths, the developers were able to balance out which side of the puzzle each player was on, but in this game, you and your partner are always together so there's no knowing which side of the puzzle you'll be on. If you're as unlucky as I am, you will be stuck on the waiting around side of puzzles more often than not.


Buildup to Nothing: SPOILERS
=============================
 - There is a moment halfway through the game where one player gets a scrap from a satanic contract strapped to their arm. With how the other games played out, my friend and I expected this to play a major part in the finale of the game, but it's only for a cut-scene at the end and plays no other part.
 - There's also a moment where the king commands the jester to come attack the players before a three way split to different sections that we would be doubling back to in order to complete each section. We expected the jester to start coming after us and put more of a time trail on the puzzles going forward, getting increasingly harder after each section, but the jester never shows up.
 - There's also a few puzzles early on that have no consequence if you fail, but when you when the Jester says something along the lines of "I didn't expect you to get through that one alive." This made my friend and I think that there was going to be a Chapter 3 to the game in which the Jester takes over the redoes the first puzzles but makes them more dangerous or have some sort of twist to them. But these puzzles never show up again.


The Good Bits:
=====================
 - The Music Box was a really fun series of puzzles that had the players working in the same space, having to communicate and do things together in order to solve the puzzles.
 - There's a brief puzzle with an orange and blue light that had both players sharing an inventory of pipes and using logic to get the lights to the correct output.
 - The Potion-Making puzzle was very fun in how we had to deal with such limited resources together and a time limit. It requires the players to take a step back and plan out their moves before restarting.
 - These types of puzzles are what this game sorely needed more of. More puzzles of both players using logic, strategy, and planning to make it through different areas.

Great game so far, most puzzles are unique and fun, the only problem i have are some gamebreaking bugs forcing us to restart the game completely. Some of these are:
-Game freezing making the players jump so far in the air getting them stuck behind structures or making them fall from the map
-Opening doors pushing the players inside the walls
-Bug making the player fall through the gap between the bridges (i think it was in the 1st chapter in the maze part), making it impossible to complete the level
-Getting softlocked in the jester's dice puzzle by allowing one player to cross the portal to the purple doors while the other one is stuck
-Game not giving players enough pipes in nautilus level or giving them the wrong ones making it impossible to complete the puzzle without the reset
-Disappearing sounds in the nautilus lvl (the translating of the kraken sounds). It randomly makes one of three necessary sounds every 30 seconds. From what i've read people say on the forums it's clear that's a bug. It's possible to complete the lvl without the reset but it's extremely annoying.
-Bugged voice chat (found it in the level after the kraken one, but can probably be found in any other part of the game), making it so both players hear the other one only in one headphone and also both players can speak simultaneously.
Overall enjoyable experience, but expect to find at least a couple of bugs each chapter.

Me and my partner played the first 3 games together, and then realised the fourth one was releasing soon, we knew we had to get the completionist on the first three before smashing out this one. We were so pumped to get this game the second it came out, and how could we resist that juicy 10% off sale?

Now the game, I will not lie has been a buggy mess, and it was especially worse when there was no Australian servers for the first few days. However the devs were really onto it and fixed everything as soon as they could, I know my partner wasn't taking any of the shit the first few days but then we both realised something in our hearts. We are the smartest, and the funniest, and the best, and the only ones who should be together in such desperate measures.

The best part about smashing out a game so early is that there is no walkthrough, meaning that everything we did was legitty on our titties, which leads me to believe that our brain patterns have been altered, what if we are both genetically engineered to begin with?

I remember playing the first game several times and not knowing about how deep the lore actually went, but when my partner came along for the first time, the one I was destined to be with, I just knew that the one I had been waiting for had finally come, and I opened my eyes for the first time to see how good the lore actually is. As I write this review, I know my partner wants more of this, whether its part of the same series or not, as long as we keep getting more.

I have a bad feeling however that this is the last game of the We Were Here series, they say that all good things must come to an end, however I do know one thing is for sure. This door closes for me, but it has made way for another one to open, the path that I must walk with my partner. And I know that I definitely won't be treading off this path, no matter how long it is I will always stand by my partners side, this series has prepared us for the toughest obstacles that we can now face on our own.

I was asked several times by a few of my friends, "Who is this mysterious partner you keep referring to? And why are they so perfect?" Perhaps one day I may reveal this partner, however all I can say for now, is that my partner was a very unlikely one, and that I would have never foreseen being with them like this.

Just the thought of me and my partner having been through so much together, seeing each other leave one behind, as one of us turns our backs and keeps walking, getting separated and coming back to each other. I do know that if I was ever met with a choice similar to the series in the real world, I know what I would pick. But I would not think of them as the "Worst Friend Forever". After all, I was always first to get left behind or die each time, and I don't plan on changing the outcome.

All that matters to me is my partners happiness, but how can I make someone happy when they are faced with such a difficult choice? If the time ever comes, I hope that my partner will understand what I have done, and that everything I did was to make this special someone happy. I do know that our ups heavily outweigh our downs, and that is enough for me. I sleep easy at night knowing that the choices I have made for my partner will keep a smile on their face.

To think that in the little time I had with my partner, it feels like we have known each other for years, decades, centuries, hell even eons. There will always be a place in my heart for my partner, whether we drift apart in the future, or if we end up staying together. I know damn well that I prefer the latter of that sentence, but I will keep this up as a memory, so that I may never forget the amazing times I had with my partner. We will tell everyone indeed that We, Were, Here.

EDIT: After the most recent update my partner and I were able to finally finish the game. Was a great game, probably the best in the series so far. There were still bugs but nothing game breaking that had us not able to complete it.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

This sucks to write due to the fact that when the game works, it's fucking amazing.

BUT, it is basically unplayable in its current state. Spoiler warning ahead:

My partner and I have to play this in multiple sessions due to time constraints. This was working perfectly fine until we progressed to the graveyard level. Every time she tried to load into that level she would be met with a black screen. We tried all the fixes in the book and they did not work. This meant that we had to progress without saves. Seemed to be working fine, we finished the Graveyard section and placed the part in the.. gun? We then progressed to the Kraken puzzle. We ended the session there and then started again the next day. Once completing the Kraken puzzle I was locked in the room and we were unable to progress as the doors to the control room shut too fast. We restarted and then the levers to finish the Kraken level did not work. We restarted again. They worked that time and we progressed to the potion making. We finished the potion making and got the next part. Upon reaching the gun where the part goes in, we noticed that that part we previously had gotten from the graveyard level no longer existed. We then went back to the Graveyard level to try and complete it again and apon falling into the well, I was unable to pick up the pickaxe. Meaning we can not progress again. Not only that but the host is the only one who can hear sound effects on the graveyard level?

The puzzles are AMAZING and this is by far the best We Were Here game so far (I have played them all).. BUT.. it's basically unplayable in it's current state. We were fine with quickly re-playing the level but we are blocked again and again by bugs in the game hardlocking us into a restart.

I think this was a great game. I've read through some other reviews, and I agree with some of the downsides. There are some pointless time wasters(riding on the lift, walking through long random corridors) and a few of the puzzles feel as though one person has all the information/tasks and the other person is just chilling for a while thinking, 'I wish my partner would hurry up.' Ultimately though, I didn't notice those much because I was having a great time with the puzzles. There's a bunch of innovative weird solutions. The storyline was interesting, and more goal oriented than the other installations, where you are just trying to escape through a bizarrely circuitous route through the castle. Took me 16 hours to complete(probably a little slow) but I think that's a lot of puzzle solving time for the price. Worth full price in my opinion.

If you love the previous games you will totally admire this one. They have outdone themselves regarding visuals, puzzles and mind boggling solutions. Of course you can also play this if you havent played the previous installments but its suggested to understand the story a little more and maybe get a feeling for how these games are played. 
Chefs kiss at the jester again and his voice actor. Just cant get enough of his cackles and giggles. He's clearly the best character of the series.

The only thing, that really makes me pull my hair are the bugs in its current state. If you run into the blackscreen/whitescreen bug at any time, you have to continue without the proper save function. Which means, if you reach chapter 4 and dont push through till the final, you might be stuck in a somewhat loop of having to repeat the puzzles every time you start up the game. There are also bugs where you get stuck and have to restart a chapter.

I honestly hope the devs will fix all of these issues before the bad reviews hit the games overall "very positive" review state. 

Tl;dr

Amazing game if you have a friend you want to [strike]yell at [/strike] [b]have a fun time with![/b] 
Don't expect the game to take your hand tho. The solutions are there but aren't always as obvious.

If you like puzzles, escape rooms and a playtime of 10-16hours or more if you switch roles to get all achievements, then this is for you!

Let me start by saying that this whole series has been a fantastic experience for me, one I won't ever forget. I can't recommend this series enough and wish to see more co-op puzzle games like these.

The atmosphere and design of this game were on point. You can see that a lot of effort has been put into that, which I appreciate enormously. It made everything even more immersive. The communication between you and your partner was vital and got pushed up a notch to solve certain puzzles (I won't go into details, I don't want to spoil). The puzzles were not too tricky and not that hard to solve either. Some of their visuals blew my mind. 

I love how the two characters are together for most of the game. I felt a great sense of freedom due to it. In previous games, it was pretty set who had to solve which part of the puzzle. In 'Forever' it depends on who walked first or opened something first etc. I love the little breaks between the puzzles (where you had to travel from one place to the other). Those made it more immersive for me. The break allowed you to play rock, paper, scissors, talk about your environment or share ideas about what you think will happen next. Were the puzzles gave me a more dependent feeling on each other, the breaks gave me the sense that we were in this together as friends.

Therefore the end hit even harder than in the previous games... It gutted me.

after playing the other 3 We Were Here games, this one definitely had a lot more polish in its presentation and ambition in the amount of content included in the game, especially taking into account that replaying the game allows for (mostly) different perspectives and interactions with the various puzzles.

The only gripe I had with this entry of the series is how during some puzzles, one of the players merely provides information to their partner, while the other player is the only one actually interacting and solving the puzzle. It did make the game a bit boring at times having only the option to reexplain information and wait for the puzzle to be solved, an issue not present in any of the previous games iirc (both players used to almost always interact and contribute to the solving of their parts of a level to complete the puzzle)

Still, this game is a good entry in the series. The storytelling was compelling and the visuals/atmosphere were fantastic. Hope to see more :)

+ *MOST* of the puzzles were improved over the previous game in that both players got to do stuff versus player1 reading a single book and player2 doing all of the work. Both could advance the puzzle

This game is a major step-up in quality of puzzles, story-telling, and environment compared to the first three, especially noticeable upon entering maybe the most amazing / mind-bending puzzle room I've ever witnessed.

One or two of the puzzles are noticeably worse quality / harder to follow than the rest, made worse when it felt to us that the puzzle had become bugged (maybe it hadn't, though) BUT the sheer quality of the remainder of the game is high enough that these few experiences aren't enough to tarnish my overall experience.

It's not the longest game, but from my experience with this genre of games this is definitely on the longer side, and each game in the series has been progressively longer; I would not call the length of this game a downside. [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35145066/] My review page.[/url][/i] 
[i][url=https://www.twitch.tv/nightserg] Follow me on twitch![/url][/i] 

[h1]The gist of it:[/h1]
We Were Here Forever the final(?) entry in the series has finally launched but is it as good as the previous ones? No, it's much better! It's a fantastic puzzle-focused coop game and we need more. 

👍 [u]The good parts:[/u]
+Level design and the environments.
+The puzzles ofc.
+Much better story-telling than previous ones.

👎[u]The bad parts:[/u]
-Minor bugs that made us restart an entire chapter.
-Some puzzles like the final one were super easy. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
If you played the previous ones, you know there's some story about a king and how he did some bad things and some jester but it never made much sense. Luckily the story finally becomes much more focused and clear as there are finally story cutscenes with dialogue and everything. 

You are back at Castle Rock trying to go through the Jester and King's endless puzzles but this time something changes. You manage to escape and find yourselves outside the castle where you find the plans of some rebel families that stood up to the King. I won't spoil more but this time around it feels like there's some actual lore behind everything as well as a proper ending, well except for one minor thing which I did not like at the end. Don't think there was an alternative to it. 

In any case, this is not some story that will blow your mind or make you emotional, the series was never about that, but I appreciated that they did gave us something better than previous games in this regard. 

Story rating: 7.5/10

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Just like the previous games, We Were Here Forever is a coop puzzle-focused adventure game where you and your partner have to progress through really tough puzzles in order to escape Castle Rock and its vicinities. 

You'll have parts where you can switch back and forth puzzles with your partner which helps in figuring out certain puzzles but there are also parts where you are both stuck on your selected side and you'll have to coordinate via voice on how to advance forward. 

Most puzzles will require you both to really think hard but there are a few such as the final one where they are extremely easy. The last puzzle was a bit disappointing, I was expecting something much more with an ompfh. Overall as I don't want to spoil you with what the game will throw at you in terms of puzzles, there are going to be some path-blocking ones, there's a cooking simulator one, and so many more. They are all unique and different from each other, not once will you get bored. There's also a hint system tho it's mostly useless as it only tells you how to start figuring out the puzzles which anyone with an average IQ will do.  

Fun and tough game and I'm curious what the devs can cook up next, assuming they'll still do coop/puzzle games. It's a rare genre so more is always welcome. Perhaps something sci-fi next time such as Portal 2 coop? 

Gameplay rating: 8.5/10

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Ah, voice acting, finally you won't have to look at weird cutscenes without a voice and surprisingly it's really well acted. 

The soundtrack is great, no complaints here, and I loved that there was a music type of puzzle as well as one with figuring out words out of sounds. Really well done. 

Other than that, the sound effects such as the atmospheric ones and whatever else are generally quite good, no complaints.

Audio rating: 8/10

[h1]Graphics, performance and tech analysis[/h1]
I'll start with the bad real quick which were some bugs that forced us to restart an entire chapter but the devs said it had to do with servers so who knows. There were other minor ones as well but nothing worth talking about. 

What's really impressive this time around is the scope of the levels and their design. Long gone are the days of small rooms with puzzles, this time around everything around you feels masterfully crafted like a huge metroidvania-like map filled with puzzles, minus the backtracking. The way the levels and the puzzles are placed and how they work well with each other is perfect. They outdid themselves and I can't wait for what they do next.

As for the game performance, it's a bit iffy at times, frames can drop even on a high-end pc to 50s but overall it runs smooth.

Graphics, performance and tech analysis score: 8/10

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you're a fan of the series then I don't have to tell you to go buy it and if you're new I suggest playing them all tho not mandatory since We Were Here Forever can be easily played even as your first game. 

[h1]Final score: 8/10[/h1]

We Were Here Forever was an extremely fun game to play through but in comparison to the previous game in the series, I'm not sure it lived up to expectations. 

Most of the puzzles were unique and fun to solve. Some of them required a decent amount of thinking while others you needed good team coordination/communication. There was one puzzle that we thought was troublesome. Maybe we're just stupid but we thought the clues provided weren't very clear. Also it was the first time we used the "Hint" feature in the game and they were literally the most useless things ever. One of them was "try to use deduction if you don't know where to place these". Yeah thanks for telling me a basic human problem solving skill. 
Personally I found some of the puzzles kind of boring. It just felt for a few of them that 1 person didn't have much to do.

The story was decent. Just the same stuff that's been going on the past few games. It does go more into depth of what's happening but I didn't care much for it.

The biggest problem in the game for us was all the waiting. They make you ride on like a snow lift multiple times that takes a solid like 20-30 seconds for no reason except the 1 time there was a cut scene. There are other instances too where it just takes too long for the game to take you through a pointless ride.

The graphics were great and a step up from the previous game. Soundtrack was fine, didn't really stand out at all. I only encountered one bug where I couldn't see the images on the buttons I was pressing. Quick restart fixed it though.

The final puzzle of the game was super easy. I'm pretty sure this is the last game in the series and for a final puzzle that sucked. Nearly every other puzzle was more difficult than the final one and kinda disappointed.

Despite all the negatives, it was still an extremely fun game and I do think it's worth full price.

Absolute 10/10 for the entire series. I loved the simple mechanics that still allowed for really cryptic and interesting puzzles, which were really challenging, but all the clues were there, and it was really fun trying to communicate with my friend to solve everything. I also loved the vaguely creepy nature of the setting and the story. The fact that the overarching narrative was another puzzle for us to piece together all the way through was really clever, and really fun to collect the information on. Fantastic game, would recommend.

I would say this game is pretty good, but caveat that on a couple of things. One, I played this with a friend and we used Discord to communicate, which means I can't evaluate the matchmaking or in-game communication system. Two, it's May of 2022 and this game is still new and definitely has a lot of bugs. None of them were game-breaking for us on our playthrough, but we did have to restart the game once to clear a softlock and we ended up glitching the ending cutscene out pretty badly.

As a part of the We Were Here series, I'd say it's on par with the previous entry (We Were Here Together), but for different reasons. This game is visually more impressive and has a greater emphasis on story, and there's less consequences for, shall we say, taking your time in solving the puzzles. However, WWHT had the superior puzzles and more polished gameplay.

Recommend playing the other games in the We Were Here series first if you haven't already, and then picking up this game after it's been out for a few months and the developer has had a chance to patch some of the bugs.

Finally, Jack and Rose both could have fit on the dang door. Come on.

An amazing game and upgrade from the previous games in the series. Graphics and puzzles wise. There is a lot less confusion due to missing hints and it is much clearer what went wrong. That isn't to say there weren't moments when me and my friend got stuck, but the instances were far less frustrating than in the last games in the series.

As of our playthrough (finished 6 days after release), there are still a fair few moments with framerate lag. They aren't super frequent, or at least we didn't pay it much mind. For a person whose first game might be We Were Here Forever or isn't a huge fan of the series, they might be more annoying or frustrating.

I look forward to whatever Total Mayhem Games decides to make in the future.

We Were Here Forever is a great 2 player online co-op puzzle game that relies on communicating with your partner.

Best part of the series yet! The storytelling has been improved with cinematics. While there is an overarching story, this game works as a standalone because the focus on the story is about setting the mood for the next puzzle. The puzzles are less abstract, more intuitive and there are more of them. This doesn't mean they became easy, there will still be plenty of moments where you are stuck trying to figure out a puzzle, but they won't be as frustrating to solve. As usual, the puzzles work by exchanging information with each other and figuring them out with logic, some of which reset after a few attempts or by the timer running out.

The game currently has some issues that should be easily fixed. At the end of the octopus puzzle, I was still stuck in the chair while my partner could progress to the next puzzle. Loading up the save for the next puzzle gave a black screen to whoever was hosting. Luckily we could work around this by replaying the octopus puzzle because of the nice chapter select. In some of the bigger puzzles, the FPS takes a big hit, not just on my mediocre PC, but on my partner's beefy PC as well.

Overall, this is a fun time, it's more and better!

For achievement hunters:
Play the game from both sides and reach both endings, has a chapter select. If one of you has a weaker PC, make sure your partner is loaded in the game or you'll have to replay that part for the achievement to pop.

Best part of the series so far! Very fun and diversified puzzles without repetition. Every puzzle feels very well thought out, works nice and helps to explain the story. If you enjoyed a We Were Here Game before you will absolutely love this game. 

Also works a lot better for colorblind people than older titles as there are no exclusive color puzzles. If color is used in a puzzle it is always matched with a shape or something similar. 

In my playthrough we only encountered 2 small bugs were we had to restart the game, which is of course a bit annoying. But thankfully the game is almost exclusively about understanding and solving the puzzles, so even after resetting you will be back up to your progress in a few moments.

Overall, just disappointing. I won't call it bad - you've got your two player puzzling and it works - but for the final(?) game in the series, the one with the longest development time and the one with the highest price tag, it feels a big step backwards from its predecessors.

It's hard to nail down exactly why, but I think it feels too tame, as if they approached this one with the mindset of really making a commercial game (the original was a student project IIRC), and were worried of scaring away players. There's no tension of having to solve a puzzle before you die to some encroaching hazard (increasingly-panicked chatter on the walkie talkies that can't both receive and transmit at the same time was genuinely one of my favourite parts of the previous games), and the puzzles are so self-contained - no more running around trying to figure out what you should be doing, instead you're typically sealed in a small area with only the puzzle elements, leaving the experience feeling overly-curated. "Here's the next puzzle, solve it using these parts," goes the game, "I'll be waiting to escort you to the next puzzle."

On top of that, the puzzles themselves feel worse than in the previous games. Too many of the puzzles have both players simultaneously interacting with the same elements, leading to most of them ending with one person figuring it out and dictating everything to the other player. They feel more like single-player puzzles where the second player only exists to physically enter their half of the solution and maybe answer specific questions about details you know are there but can't see the exact details of.
The few asymmetrical puzzles beyond that seem to blitz through the interesting asymmetrical puzzle solving and go straight to the execution. Rather than collaboratively working out a solution you tend to see what you're supposed to do straight away followed by however much time of just repeating information back and forth, or worse one player is left really bored as their half just has so much less to do.
Really, the asymmetrical part of the co-op puzzle solving was what made the series unique, and to see it stray away from that feels like they've squandered what made the games what they are.

The game's longer than the older ones. There's more story as well, which may be hit-or-miss. I couldn't care less for it as it was the series's mechanics that held my interest, but the friend I played through them with was interested in the story. Either way, the individual puzzle quality has suffered for both. There were a couple I came out of thinking 'that one was pretty decent', but there's nothing memorable in there.

As I said at the start, I can't outright call it bad, but the development time and the price point both set expectations that the game consistently failed to meet. For half the price I likely would have been satisfied with the experience, but at full price it's just too bland.

At some point in the game you have to repair a machine where you need three parts that you get in three different levels. But every time we finished a level and got a machine part, the previous machine parts were reset. After we had the second machine part, the first machine part was reset, so we did both levl again. Then we got the third machine part and the other machine parts were gone again now we have to do all lvl all over again and they are not short.We tried reloadig our savegames etc. but nothing worked 
Conclusion: It would be a very, very good game with very good and fun puzzles, we really had a great time...so far...I would  not recommend to buy the game until the bugs are fixed, otherwise ur enjoyment on the game quickly turns into frustration.But who knows maybe we only unlucky.

somethings that I really like about this game:
- Nice variations with the puzzles. In the end, co-op puzzles are just me telling you the missing info you need and vice versa, but there's a nice variation to it.
- good level of cooperation required

- Incorporation of time limitations

Somethings that irks me with this game: 
-game breaking bugs that my friend and I have to restart our games to fix. Like items missing, critical interactions that aren't there/happening, etc. 
- puzzles were fun, but I totally lost track of the story. Story was forgettable and not captivating. 
- Starting the game turns out to be part of the puzzle too. there were a lot of issues in the beginning setting up the lobby/session, syncing to steam cloud issues that we have to fix by restarting steam. 
- game load time was very long for someone with an older PC too. 
- the walkies were more of a hassle than a challenge so we used discord instead.

Some of us had crashing issues too (don't spam your radio for the hell of it), we also ran into some bugs where one of us was glitched under a bridge and the other couldn't use a switch to move it since the person was "on it". 

Fun to argue with your partner with and without guides when you need it, but feels like a glitchy mess right now... Maybe give it a few weeks, but I'm not revisiting this after 13 hours and still didn't finish it.

I haven't actually finished the game yet, my friend and I just about hit the halfway mark. The two of us have played through all the previous games in the series together, and so far, this new entry has been a blast!

This entry has a wonderful balance so far of easy "you do that so I can get over here, then ill pull this so you can get over as well" puzzles, and difficult "hold on a second while I draw this out" puzzles. The game play is very similar to the previous games, but it is absolutely worth the price for the amount of hours of enjoyment we've gotten already.

tl;dr: More than worth the price, especially if you've already played the previous games and are hungry for more, make sure you bring a friend :)


note: The game was released only a few days ago as of writing, and we have run across our fair share of bugs and even one soft lock, but the devs have been really active in the discussion forms and I expect that over the next few weeks most common bugs will be cleaned out and I'm honestly not worried at all about it given the reputation this dev has built for itself.

Overall Rating: 8/10
Game is an excellent addition to the We Were Here series. For those looking for a fun co-op game to play with a friend, look no further than this series.

As far as criticism's go, my only major one is that the game runs just a tad too short, was really hoping after seeing the cliffhanger at the end that you'd follow through it and continue for one more area, but it just ended and left it open for yet another sequel/or DLC.

Overall puzzle quality is a slight step down from We Were Here Together, which had the best puzzles of the entire series so far.
I do understand the developers decision to forgo almost any time based puzzles for the game due to the whiny gamers that left bad reviews on the last game for having them. But time based puzzles bring a tension to some puzzles that makes them very interesting and memorable after you've solved them. Sad to see them almost entirely gone.

Also a number of bugs in the game that can softlock you and require you to reload the game in order to progress.

By far the longest one (about 9-10h for our first run), with the most polished story and the best cinematics.
Some of the puzzles were very creative and left me and my partner speechless, on "how can you even craft a puzzle like this?".

A few different takes compared to the last 3 games, like the slight "open world" touch, the fact that you are not separated from your partner for longer than a few puzzles, and the absence of timed puzzles that kill you if you are out of time. Those can feel like pros or cons depending of your preferences, but I like that the developpers are still trying new things with each of their game.

Overall the game is very great, and definitly a must-buy if this is your kind of games. The price feels very low for the amount of work they put into it.

Sadly the worse game of the series. The creators change their focus to big areas with many riddles in it. You need to navigate your mate, but you are so far from each other, that you can’t even tell what’s on the other side or even where the mate is at all. This game is more frustrating than fun and its not because the riddles are too hard, but because of the gameplay.

definitely a unique experience as a coop game, the visuals, the story, gameplay and the puzzles are very outstanding from other games (which there are not many). I do recommend this game because of how well it's designed, no doubt there was a lot of thought put in and a great job in every aspect. however there are some frustrating things you should take in count before playing:
-bugs. you will have to restart chapter because items won't spawn/work/exist as intended, or the map itself doesnt work.
-fps drops, i had my game most of the time on 90fps, and some areas i was perma droped to 10fps.
-game starts with great puzzles that get harder mid playthrough, and then don't challenge you anymore. it's like at the end they gave you some timing mini games to fill up the story with mostly no effort put in.
-unexplained puzzled. imagine entering a room with 20 different buttons and levers and 0 hints or explanation whatsoever on whats going on, and you keep on trying just to fail and keep on guessing until something works.
-game doesn't focus on story. of course you'd usually have to play first games to understand what's going on, but either way there was very little story presented and it felt as if it was there just to give the game a visual subject. you finish the game still wondering what is the story.

bearable, end of the day it's a great game that has more to offer than it's down sides.

The further you get the less the game becomes puzzles and the more it becomes a simple test of your patience.
Too many timers in place of thought, many that are literally just trial and error.

I've played the other "We Were Here" games, and I gotta say this one definitely tops the others. 

You don't [i]need[/i] to play the other games in the series, but there is lore and it ties in fairly well with the other games. I appreciated the voice acting and cutscenes in this game: they didn't feel out of place or unnatural in any way. As for the storytelling delivery, it's always a joy combining the lore with the puzzles. Especially in Chapter 2, there were some nice touches to understand some characters.

The puzzles themselves were great. Very interactive (which is good given the type of game). Sometimes you can't guess when you'll split up with your partner to go off on a co-op puzzle which I really appreciated. Some of the puzzles were a bit long, but it never really [i]felt[/i] long: I spent more time thinking about how to solve the puzzle than usual.

I recommend the entire series. 10/10. I did only play with a friend and never jumped in a random queue, so I can't comment on that.

Played all the previous installments of We Were Here with a friend and we were really excited to see this game get released, however currently there are too many bugs and performance drops to enjoy it. Certain areas were so laggy that I was getting nauseous just playing the game and had to take breaks. We made it almost to the end of chapter 5, and then encountered a bug which stopped us from progressing (had to pull two levers but nothing would happen). Restarted the game, and from that point the save was bricked and whoever would host the game would load with a black screen and be unable to do anything.

We decided to load from a checkpoint instead, which didnt set us too far back. Had to repeat a couple puzzles but knowing the answers already we got it done relatively quickly. We proceeded to finish chapter 5, and collected the final piece of the 3 piece contraption... however returning to the location to install it the pieces for chapters 3 and 4 were no longer there. We cant progress with replaying two whole chapters, and even from the chapter select the finale isnt unlocked. 

Sadly, unless we find a way to edit the save file and unlock the final chapter I dont think we will be finishing this game. If anyone knows how to do this please let me know. But currently, with the number of bugs and performance drops I cant recommend the game. Really sad we wont be able to finish it without starting over from chapter 3.

A fun little jaunt! My chum and I got 13ish hours of it. A decent little story, interesting puzzles, good for a play through with a pal but there is the odd puzzle that only has one solution, so you might want to wait a while before doing a second play through so that you forget all the puzzles!

We Were Here Forever expands on the three previous games before this and creates a far more accessible and enjoyable experience. None of the puzzles really seemed as difficult as the hardest Together puzzles, but at the same time, none of the puzzles were as flawed as the Together ones. Overall, the difficulty curve is far more consistent. The world is beautiful, with an art style that is both eye catching, but kind to my GPU. It has a far more "open-world" feel, with the need to go back to previously explored spots (I'll keep it at that to avoid spoilers). 

There are certain things about this game that are missing compared to the previous games (which personally is to its benefit). There are infinitely less "mix and match" puzzles that require stupidly detailed descriptions of symbols that make no sense. These puzzles were designed with the intent to make both players simply learn, and once they've learned the trick, they can figure it out and finish. That design choice is intuitive and goes a long way to support the pacing. The game does not need to constantly separate you to make a puzzle difficult, which is refreshing. The moments of separation actually matter, and is not just an expectation. Your partner FEELS like your partner, because you're consistently with each other, playing rock paper scissors, or just doing some other silly thing. Overall, highly recommend this game.

Let me start this off by saying I love the WWH series. The first 3 games kept getting better and better. However, this game feels like a very major step back. Almost every puzzle was extremely linear. For example, [spoiler]in Jester's box with the portals to other rooms, there was only 1 path in every spot. You just had to find the matching symbol and line them up.[/spoiler] I also felt as though there was a lack of actual teamwork needed. The only reason you need a second person is to flip an arbitrary lever every so often. The choice to have the players interact more was, in my opinion, detrimental. When both players have the ability to see both parts of the puzzle, what is the point? This doesn't even begin to touch on the waiting cut scenes. (Looking at you ski lift).

If this is the true end to the series, then I'm disappointed, and wish I had stopped after 3. As I said at the start, I do love the We Were Here Series, but this does not feel like a We Were Here Game.

It's a great coop only game. It's longer than any of the previous games in the series (took us 11hrs to do first run), and the quality is higher. Puzzles are varied and never too difficult. There does appear to be a way to find people to play with, but I would highly recommend grabbing a friend.

I do have some criticisms:
* The game forced us to accept an EULA. I don't know why that is necessary. Because it shouldn't be.
* The game has an account system - god knows why, but at least it's optional.
* Performance is certain parts, most notably the underwater part is quite bad
* Some of the puzzles require one of the players to do majority of the thinking while the other player got not  much to do, which kinda is a problem
* We had some connection issues mid game, where my friend simply could not connect to their proprietary servers. It would appear the game does not support Steam P2P and requires some bullshit online servers. What happens when the developer decides to shut them down?
* The potion puzzle having a time limit is anti fun.
* There are some inconsistencies in quality. Some loading screens are "live" where the game still has things happening, but most of the time it's a black screen. Another one that jumps out is the Rockbury cart ride, where certain things are clearly not animated when they should be. Certain interactions are not animated in 3rd person such as pushing revolving lever things. In most cases when you interact you cannot look around to see if your partner is fucking around or not.

Excellent game. finished it in about 12 hours. I'ts a co-op puzzle game which requires communications to figure puzzles out. They're very creative. Also, the exploration has been expanded ever so slightly from the previous games. I would love to see the exploration expanded on a bit. I really enjoyed taking in the scenery. Maybe adding some hidden collectibles in the next game? Only a few puzzles felt too easy, quick or otherwise not interesting. Everything else was a blast and they are all designed well. Also, I liked how some of the puzzles force you to learn the lore/plot, lol.

If you have someone to play this game with it's worth it. I recommend going back and playing the previous two games first, or at least the game before this one. Not required though.

Only negative - there is no accessibility mode. The puzzles fundamentally require you to be able to hear sounds and see colors accurately. If you're deaf or colorblind you may have an issue finishing this game, as your co-op partner cannot help you with these things, but actually relies on you to communicate these things to them.

By friend and I just finished it. Like all the previous installments, I really enjoyed it. The puzzles are solid and extremely creative. 

Favorite puzzle is the puppet head/matching the scenes puzzle. It requires the players to learn who the people are without doing a massive lore dump. Its a very creative way to for us to learn about the world in order to solve the puzzle.

I highly recommend the series, although be careful if you get too frustrated with puzzles.

I didnt see anything for accessibility, and I can see some puzzles being incredibly difficult if you are color blind. Keep that in mind as some things would just be harder or even impossible.

Overall, I recommend any We Were Here game, as they offer the best asymmetrical cooperative gaming experience you can have.
That said, the rest of this review is a comparison between this and the previous instalments of the series.

The good:
- Best audiovisual quality in the series.
- Longest game in the series.
- Richest backstory in the series.
- The We Were Here formula we love.

The bad:
- The script of the playable story feels not so good as does We Were Here Together, the previous instalment of the series.
- Some puzzles (and even the narrative) seems not as asymmetrical as expected from an We Were Here game.
- Constantly regrouping with your partner loses the sentiment of being by yourself and lost. It also leads to poor checkpoints, which affects the replayability negatively. Describing the environment to your partner used to be a big part of the journey, but it's less present in this game.
- The music box puzzle will make you literally sick. 
- Sometimes the game controls your camera, which is as annoying as it can be.
- Launch week bugs and performance issues.

- Updated ranking:
- We Were Here Together
- We Were Here Forever
- We Were Here Too
- We Were Here

Too short. That’s how I would summarize my experience playing this 4th "We were here" game.

Pros :
[list]
  [*]Art + atmosphere : It’s been a long journey since the first game (less than 1gb of storage space overall iirc). Beautiful.
  [*]Story : As for Art + atmosphere this game series has come a long way since the "We’re stranded in a snowy mountain, let’s take refuge in this castle". We Were Here Together was already a step in that direction but Forever is really going in the more "Outdoor experience".
  [*]Co-op puzzles : I know it’s the main theme of the game but there’s not enough games like this one where two people have to cooperate in order to solve puzzles and progress through the game.
[/list]

Cons : 
[list]
  [*]Too short. That’s also how I started my review but it just leaves a bad aftertaste in my mouth after we played the last chapter. I was half joking about a DLC/season pass on voice but it really felt short. We finished the game in 3 night sessions. [spoiler] 2h15 for the first evening (1st chapter), 5h for the (2nd and 3rd chapters), 2h for the (4th, 5th and 6th chapters).[/spoiler] We then launched a new save of Together because we craved for more.
  [*]Straightforward puzzles : You don’t have to guess what you should be doing in order to solve the puzzles, you just solve them. I was able to solve a few puzzles with almost no active interaction with my friend
  [*]Passive/active puzzles :  There's quite a few (enough to be noticed) puzzles where there’s someone solving the puzzle and the other one listening to the instructions of his/her partner. You can’t choose either so we know that if we play the game again (prolly in a few months in order to "forget" most of the puzzles) we'll have to b careful before "going our separate way".
 [*]Lift waiting : Some areas where you don’t do anything and just wait for the lift to transport you were really too lengthy
  [*]Technical issues : 
  [list]
    [*]Black mass of pixels trying to engulf the host (it was only me and I thought i was a game feature at the beginning)
    [*]Fps drops in some areas
    [*]Audio bug for one of the puzzle [spoiler] where I couldn’t hear what noise the kraken was producing[/spoiler]
    [*]Subtitles issues : We played in a non English language so we used subtitles. Most of the times it was good but in some areas when I was mouse hovering over some text, there was no carriage return for the text to start a new line when it went over the "translation box" right side.
  [/list]
[/list]

My pros/cons list seems to tip on the cons side [b]BUT[/b] I will [u]still recommend this game[/u] because of Co-op puzzles. I really crave for this type of games. It’s a big bias but this kind of games where you have to work as a team of 2 to move forward is a really nice feeling for me when I'm playing a video game. I understand how it must be difficult to come up with new puzzles for 2 people to solve them together but so far the job has been done. I wouldn’t mind less story for a longer/more difficult 5th game.

TL;DR Game is good but short. We (my friend and I) need a 5th "We Were Here" game already.

One of the best co-op games I've played since It Takes Two and Portal 2 co-op. Has fantastic and unique puzzle design with a story that is detailed but not complex or hard to understand. With the exception of a couple puzzles in here, most of these puzzles are pretty decent head-scratchers. Tough in a refreshing way but very much solvable. I don't think I've had this much fun trying to figure out HOW a puzzle works rather than just the puzzle itself. NOTE: As of writing this review, this game has a plethora of optimization issues resulting in fps drops any time an area is loaded, deloaded, etc, as well as a pretty decent amount of bugs that usually occur due to clicking an interactable to many times or something not triggering. (spoiler I guess:) During the graveyard/robbing section we had to reset the level about 4 times for it to actually work. Which was very frustrating. Despite these issues the game shines through and makes them more minor inconveniences then anything. Plus these are things that can be fixed with a couple patches. So in conclusion, while I highly recommend playing this, it would not hurt to wait for these things to be fixed before playing.

- Out of my 9h playthrough, I would say more than 1h is just walking around to go from one area to the other or to bring back an item to a specific place

- There are some really uneven areas / puzzles throughout the game. Sometimes you'll get puzzles that are very easy and you'll storm through an area, whereas some other times you'll spend more than 1h in the same area.

Other than these, I'd say it's a pretty good game to play with a friend, especially if you enjoyed the other games.

(20-40 fps, even with ideal settings.)  

other then the bugs, i would rate We Were Here Forever a 9.5/10, and would recommend playing We Were Here Together first if you've never played any of the games in the series. Great progression to the escape-room style coop puzzle series. Definitely gets way more creative in this installment, in a great way - both in terms of puzzles and atmosphere. There still felt to be some outstanding bugs and questionable performance at times, but fortunately with a slower paced game like this, it doesn't hinder the experience.

There's a couple parts which end up feeling a little tedious, but overall its a lot of fun with a friend and a ton more content. 

There's no need to play the predecessors to jump into this, though it may be worth playing the original (which is free) to see if you like the style, but otherwise I'd definitely recommend giving it a shot.

The lore and backstory for 'We Were Here Forever' is extraordinarily deep and engaging particularly in comparison to the mystery and vagueness of the last three games story wise. Unlike the past three games (which i also highly recommend particularly before playing this) which reveal very little lore wise behind the actions of the two explorers 'We Were Here Forever' completely changes that dynamic diving much deeper into the lore which myself and many others have very much been looking for. This game and the whole 'We Were Here' series is a must to experience with a friend. 10/10
A great experience, definitely check out the full series.

For the finale of the game, the puzzles and ending were somewhat underwhelming.  A lot of these puzzles consists of one person looking at a key and the other person doing the actual puzzle, which gets pretty stale after awhile.  I feel as the other games were a bit more creative in how they formatted the puzzles, but after four games I can get why some of these may have this same-y feeling.

On the ending: 
[spoiler] What's with that? The Puppeteer just gets away and that's it? Your partner dies and the story ends on a bright light of...something. It feels like this is just setting up for another game which isn't very satisfying at all. [/spoiler]

All in all, this game was enjoyable to play through with a friend. If you're looking for a fun co-op game to play with your friend or you've gone through the other We Were here titles, this isn't a terrible buy. I just have mixed feelings on it.

The music alone is really nice and I would love to see a soundtrack available for download! :)

All together, We Were Here Forever stands to this date my favorite puzzle game and I am excited to go through it again! 


The only issues I have had so far are sometimes the walkie-talkies would stop working for an entire chapter (restarting would fix) and in the last portion of the game, there is a animation to get up ladders which was kinda buggy but other than those two small bugs, smooth sailing.
yass

Starts off really strong but imo the quality / enjoyment of the puzzles drops around the midway point directly after a cutscene, depending on which side of the puzzle you end up on.  One of the three puzzles paths that you get to choose which order you do them in (has no impact other than order) is pretty awful for the most part in terms of enjoyment. Where only a single puzzle in that entire path was actually enjoyable (the path leading to the right).  Overall the We Were Here Series is still one of the best available co-op puzzle games and a real blast so there really isn't anything like it to want me to change my review to a no.  It's just that my enjoyment peaked really fast.  It might not be like that for you, but it was for me.

I also think the ending was kind of abrupt.  Without knowing if they plan to make another game in the series, I think that they should probably do a paid (let's be honest here and admit that their work is worth paying for - I want them to produce more and am willing to pay for it, shocker.) DLC to change the ending sequence with more puzzles involving -spoilers- because I think that would be really cool and would A) feel better as a whole or B) make it obvious that another game is possible if they felt like continuing the story which I feel isn't wrapped up in a way that gives closure.  If you've played the other games or have read the description for WWHF then you already know how these games go.  So not sorry if you feel like I've 'spoiled' something here.  I don't feel like 'we won' when the credits rolled.  The part that actually matters isn't spoiled by reading this and you aren't even given an idea of what I'm talking about.  You just have to see it for yourself.

I feel like this needs to be in caps.  THE GAME HAS PLENTY OF ACTUALLY ENJOYABLE PUZZLES AND IS WORTH THE MONEY!!  With that being said, I have complaints about a small handful of them.

Fairly major (and some minor) complaints below that I can still live with enough to rate as a recommend.  *Spoilers*

**SPOILERS BELOW, LAST WARNING**

Major complaints. (Flaws with the design itself)

The town. after being thrown out of the castle.  One player is mostly just sitting around waiting for the other person to do something with what they have on their side.  I was literally just standing around waiting for a large portion of the time spent there.  I would describe a quick scene and then it was just me waiting.  They had books to read, and objects to interact with.  Once an object was given to me, it was really obvious where it belonged.

The chapel.  Again, mostly just sitting around waiting.  All I had to do was explain what I was looking at and then wait for the other person to do everything else, which took way too long for how much I had to do on my side (bad).  There wasn't really any active involvement on my side and I firmly believe that both players should have something to interact with at the same time, or there should be an active timer ticking away so that the act of describing stuff feels important because its literal life or death (see previous WWH games).  Only a single puzzle in that building required *active* (good) communication between the two players to solve, and it was the last one there.

One of the puzzles in particular down that right path (mentioned earlier) expects too much from the players.   It involves both information overload and a lot of the interactables being useless & confusing bloat, and then on top of that expects the players to be able to either recreate or accurately describe "noises" that are required to solve what's happening.  My friend argues that they think it was a bug that I couldn't hear the noise for myself, but I argue the developers made it the way it was on purpose because one of the core 'mechanics' for lack of better word is to explain what is happening on your end so you can solve puzzles.

-gap so it doesn't look like one big wall of text-

So while I disagreed with my friend about it being a bug, I think that puzzle would have been better received if both people heard the noise.  They failed to describe the noise to me even after my mentioning of a machine on my side that as I claim "makes random noises" at me when I pull a lever on a machine with symbols on it.  We swapped places and I immediately notice that the symbol is obviously paired with a noise, but that wasn't enough to convince them to begin to describe it to me.  We swapped back and I was just given a screen-share with audio for the puzzle.  We were both tired and running low on energy and did not even want to begin making "noises" at each other in order to solve it.  The enjoyment and time spent was simply not worth the amount of effort required to solve that particular issue and we both agreed to the screen share solution.
A previous WWH game did something similar with matching the noises a clock (iirc) made and that was perfectly fine but that's where the idea to match noises should've stopped because that puzzle was simple noises with very easy to make real world comparisons like "a singular thunk on wood" type sound.  The previous entry example was enojoyable.  This game's was not.

Minor complaints. (Things that could be a problem because of how I played)

The underwater section on that same path was brute forced.  They wandered off while I messed with the stuff in my room and it worked by the time it was relevant.  We literally didn't have to communicate with each other aside from one time they got to a symbol before I had it lined up.

The light puzzle on the left path was solved REALLY FAST largely due to PURE LUCK of how I had already placed the puzzle objects.  This was an "oh, okay...that could've been more fun if I didn't accidentally do the puzzle correctly by pure chance".  It was solved properly with a few rotations after I had everything in place but could've easily been a whole ordeal.

On the same left path, the traversal "puzzle" didn't really feel like it was testing our noggin's in a meaningful way.  Felt like padding.

So yeah.  Even after all that I would still say this is both worth the money and the time to play with a friend.  It's good, for the most part.  And I look forward to more.  Please...Please give me more.

A must play (series not just this single game) that in my humble opinion, is better than the 2021 GOTY It Takes Two. No less than a 10/10 rating, fully worth buying at any price.


Every area was incredibly well thought out and produced.
Puzzles were as usual spectacular (especially the toy box).
And to top it all off, a perfect ending to the perfect game series.

Great co-op, amazing puzzles, creepy story and a tough decision bringing friends together or splitting them forever?
We Were Here Forever has it all. All you need and all you've searched for.
Take your torch and find your way, don't let Jester bring you astray.

I love this series! The game currently crashes for me, but I think that is expected when a game first release.

I've played all the previous games in the series and this one seems to be the most broken of them all. At first I couldn't start it at all, the game froze when loading data from the server.
Then my journey with a friend began, we went through the first 2 chapters and ended up at a crossroads in the middle of the city. The biggest mistake was that we went to the right into the underwater world. It turned out to be the 5th chapter right away, and everything would be fine if there were no bugs in the game that lead to a black screen that remains even after a restart and you can’t play further. The only fix is ​​to launch the checkpoint from the menu (bypassing the save), but in this way the progress of the game is reset, because we accidentally skipped the 3rd and 4th chapters and started the fifth one right away (at least hang a sign). Now every time the game crashed, we had to replay half of the game to reassemble the damn telescope.
Question to the developers - why did you make it possible to select chapters out of turn, if this leads to broken saves and the need to go through the same thing 3 times?
Thumbs down for optimization - when loading a location, even on a high-end PC, the fps drops to 10-15. Wow
This is a good cooperative puzzle (which is rare), but the impression of the game was bad.

If you're looking for a fantastic two person co-op experience then look no further. 
Grab a friend and get really angry at eachother for not being able to explain the basics of a door and weird symbols!
The story is an incredible step up from the previous games (which are also out right fantastic) and the puzzles are challenging and really interesting. 
At the time of my review there are a few bugs like framerate stuttering and a puzzle or two that gets you just stuck, but the game is good at leaving checkpoints so getting back to the same spot will be no issue at all.

I whole heartedly recommend this game, even at full price this game is a steal!

As a huge fan of the previous We Were Here games I've been waiting for We Were Here Forever for a long time!
And I'm more than satisfied. It's a perfect continuation of the previous games (both puzzle- and lore-wise) and still manages to surprise and introduce tons of new puzzles and content.
Can't wait to finish the game, yet don't want it to end so I hope it's long!

I've played for 2-3 hours now and encountered some bugs, though. Mostly non-significant, but there's a huge bug that makes the in-game voicechat stop working (sometimes you stop hearing the other person until you press and release the push-to-talk button again), so I hope it gets fixed soon.

Total Mayhem has gone a long way since the first We Were Here game, and the direction is on point. Keep it up!
They just keep making their games better. So many improvements from the last one. Would definitely recommend this. :)
